Now that I'm not, it's that much more fascinating to watch scenes like the first time Diggler is before the camera having sex with Julianne Moore, not just because of its admirably unapologetic realism but because of how gifted a porn actor must be. There are so many strangers watching, unexpected interruptions and overall lack of familiarity with the situation, throughout all of which you must maintain an erection, relentless stamina and making the act look as sexy as you can to non-participants who are watching it.In terms of Dirk Diggler's character, Anderson reflects the very intimate and fragile male issue of the fear of impotence by constructing a major character stumbling block out of it. As Diggler grows more and more addicted to cocaine, he finds it more and more difficult to achieve an erection when he needs to, winding up internalizing this panic and frustration and beginning the crumbling of a big house of cards. Anderson has the confidence and humility to portray this obstacle under an inevitable magnifying lens, as Diggler's "one special thing" is his thirteen-inch penis.The most resonant talent that Anderson shows specifically as a director is that the film is high brow in terms of production values and the effect and quality of the story and the acting, but it is essentially a movie about a guy's amazing penis, and the film offers hilariously crude sex humor and pitch-perfect individual degrees of stupidity in the characters, and in the uncanny depiction of terrible quality in the porn films within the film, the Brock Landers/Chest Rockwell films for instance, mostly in the cast's hysterical portrayals of horrible acting and the horribly staged and filmed action violence.Paul Thomas Anderson's films are mysterious wonders, because each of them, in their own respective ways, is about so many things. Boogie Nights is a period piece about the porn business. It's about a group of people that coagulate like the hierarchy of a large family through the years. It's about a dense young man whose penis leads him to stardom and leads him into a lot of trouble. It's about the control of less intelligent, less sensitive people over the compliant intelligent and sensitive ones. It's about fate and coincidence. The pleasures and dangers of sex and drugs. The id of the 1970s and '80s. Everything about this dynamite stick of talent is grippingly unanticipated.Not many films have been more blunt, even disillusioned, concerning sexuality. Porn movies are a business to these people, not a distraction, and one of the charms of this period entertainment industry drama is the manner in which it showcases the day-by-day behind- the-scenes routine life of pornographers. The range and diversity is reminiscent of films by one of Anderson's biggest influences, Robert Altman, but there is also some of the consistent charm of low-budget breakthrough films of the 1990s, in scenes that stay poised riskily flanked by hilarity and graphic violence. Throughout all the characters and drama, Anderson's script focuses on the emotional facets of them. Boogie Nights has the value of most of the great movies, in that it is constantly buzzing and animate.

Review title: A film of greatness in every way, that really gets down and boogies
Review_body: Another of these really long films to come out in early 98, the never dull BN is a mesmerizing look into the porn industry, a few sex scenes involving a lot of skin, implied, not as raunchy as a lot of people will expect. Mark Wahlberg, still in one of his best roles, plays the troubled street kid, who earns the name Dirk Diggler, with his discovered talent who's approached by Reynolds, a big time porn director, in one of his best ever acting parts. The two form a friendship, where Dirk becomes a friend among many other crew and cast, and becomes the next big thing. The period of late 70's to the breaking of the eighties is well captured and unhurried. Everyone is great where Wahlberg, competes well against some real acting heavy weights, (you'll know who I mean). Exceptionally good, was Julianne Moore, fantastic as a B porn actress fighting a lot of demons, only finding solace and happiness in what she's doing, while really she's floundering in despair, as fighting boldly to gain custody of her son. This film shows you what happens to retired porn stars, when seeking a new career or dream. One such instance threw me into a shockingly momentary disillusion. But this film is very inspirational, and how it tells you to "Never give up on your dream", especially in Dirk Diggler's case. There is a couple of coincidences in this film I didn't buy, and a little of repetition, hampering the great film, but the hampering really just becomes void, as we we don't have to forgive it, the films so good. One example involves a washed up Dirk Diggler getting pummelled by some gay hating punks, in a car park, while just after a limo just so happens to roll past with Burt and hot Heather Graham ( Rollergirl who never takes her skates off- EVER- I like that) getting it on with a high school jock who use to diss her. Shortly after, she in a much deserved revenge, as well as one I lapped up (You go girl) starts mashing the guy's face with her skates, after an offended Burt that is, tackles and punches him. There is some explosive violence, including one shock suicide scene, that's Wild Bill's doing, but like the sex, it's in the small number. My favorite scene is the one near the end, in an edgy, drug/money exchanged with a coked up Alfred Molina, as an young Asian kid, intermittently letting off firecrackers to intensify the nervousness, enwrapping Dirk Diggler and co (mo wearing Thomas Jane, you'll hardly recognize here, in still what I consider his best acting. BN is one hell of a movie ride and one of the best films of 1998. I have so much good stuff to write on this, but this is such a small offering. If you forgive the faults I mentioned, just sit back and watch what is a rewarding and insightful look into a industry was shunned, but it's how we see these shunned people lived, partied and boogied. The stick out hampering part is the ridiculous elongated penis, Marky Mark reveals at the end. Not only is it patently fake, it could do the Markster some mischief if tripping over it.

Young Eddie Adams, played by then relatively unknown Mark Wahlberg, is a dishwasher and a all-around dropout, who gets noticed by movie director and invited to shoot films with him. The movies just happen to be of the pornographic nature, which doesn't seem to faze Eddie all that much. He promptly changes his name to Dirk Diggler and the film follows his and his associates' career through the late 70s and early 80s. All the way from the golden age of porn right to the onset of video tape.For a film unabashedly about adult entertainment, the film is surprisingly non-raunchy in nature. Sure it's rated R, but there are very few sex scenes and it's more about the things that happen between the shoots. About the business itself and the kind of people it takes to undress in front of the cameras and do the naughty, as it were. It also has a great style and a lot of talent behind the camera. The soundtrack is well-crafted and contains a pleasingly huge amount of hits from those two decades. The costuming, the camera-work and the colours all harken right back to the 70s and it is one of the better period pieces about the decade I've yet seen.The acting is also superb. This is one of Wahlberg's earliest films and definitely one of the ones that put him on the map as someone with great acting chops. But the real star of the show has to be Burt Reynolds as the director Jack Horner, a man anguishing with the changes in his chosen medium, struggling to have his films seen as something worthwhile, perhaps even art.I'm sure this film has its critics solely because of its subject matter. But if you can get beyond that or if it doesn't bother you in the first place, Boogie Nights is a great film. Superbly crafted, well-acted and with a style of its own.

Mark Wahlberg, Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, William H. Macy and John C. Reilly star in this 1997 drama. This takes place from the late 70's to early 80's centering on young man, Eddie (Wahlberg) who rises to fame as a porn star, Dirk Diggler, but falls into the dark world of greed and drugs along with his friends & colleagues. Reynolds (Smokey & The Bandit) plays director, Jack, Moore (Hannibal) plays porn actress, Amber, Graham (License to Drive) plays waitress turned porn actress, Rollergirl, Macy (Fargo) plays Jack's assistant/producer, Bill and Reilly (Step-Brothers)
plays Dirk's pal & co-star, Reed. Don Cheadle (Out of Sight), Phillip Seymour Hoffman (Capote) and porn legends, Nina Hartley and Veronica Hart
also appear. This is a good drama and Wahlberg (Ted) & the cast are great in it. I recommend this.

Review title: The Highs and Lows of the Porn Industry
Review_body: The late 70s and 80s were seen as a Golden Age of the Pornography Industry in America, based San Fernando Valley. This was a period known for pornographers attempting tell a story in their films. With his first major film Paul Thomas Anderson uses this period as a backdrop for his wonderfully told drama.Eddie (Mark Wahlberg) was a 17-year-old high school dropout, working as a dishwasher at a small nightclub. Eddie is spotted by Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) who hears that the kid was well endowed. After Eddie was kicked out his home by his mother Jack and his partner Amber Waves (Julianne Moore) takes Eddie under their collective wing. Eddie quickly makes friends with porn actors Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly) and Rollergirl (Heather Graham). Jack convinces Eddie to become a porn actor himself. Eddie renames himself Dirk Digger and he quickly becomes one of the biggest name porn stars around. Eddie/Dirk believes in Jack ideal of telling a proper story in his porn films. But fame is a fickle thing with the porn industry changing and Eddie/Dirk's own person problems pushing him back.Anderson shows his talent as a director early on in the film with an amazing opening sequence with was a 3 minute long continuous shot. He expertly handles the drama, showing both a colourful party side to the late 70s/early 80s to more darker elements which was bound to happen considering it's plot. Anderson perfectly treads a fine line between comedy and tragedy. Anderson mixes in a lot of style to his film with some well handed shots, excellent cinematography and some stylist camera tricks. There was an strong influence from Martin Scorsese behind this film. The plot does have a similar to films like Scarface and Goodfellas where the protagonist starts from a low point to getting fame, money and power to them losing it because of their own arrogance. Boogie Nights is also shot in a similar style to those two films and the ending was a little like Raging Bull, but Anderson's skill made it seem more like a homage then directly coping those films. Anderson mixes in a few themes into his film: one being an very unorthodox way to fulfil the American Dream and use what ever asset you have available to you. They is of course an in-depth look into the plot industry with Anderson showing that whilst some actors may have a tough or unusual background they were willing and happy within the industry and Jack is made out to be a more noble type of director, wanting to at least tell a story in his films. There is also a darker look into why people get involved and the world of excess that inhabited this world but Anderson was darning to show some sort of a positive spin. Anderson also tackles how the porn industry changed in this period and became more of horrid mass produced product.There is a great cast in this film. Wahlberg, Reilly, Reynolds, Moore, Graham, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy and Robert Ridgely, all offer good performances. Wahlberg is of course very good in the lead role and his character grows and changes throughout the film and showed the emerging talent he was about to become. Boogie Nights was easily Reynolds and Graham's best film, showing the two are good actors, showing their dark side in the process. Moore and Reynolds were very believable in the mentor role of the film and that Moore's character was filled with heartbreak and tragedy. There were simple, powerful scenes in the film involving some of the characters, such as between Reynolds and Ridgely in prison, a wonderfully handled scene and a small scene with Hoffman crying in his car, a bitter, raw scene that was very real. Hoffman is one of the best character actors in Hollywood.An excellent film that shows American film-making at its best.

Review title: This is an underrated masterpiece that is a must see
Review_body: Boogie Nights (1997) is a movie I recently watched on HBOMAX. The storyline follows a young man who hasn't lived up to his parents expectations but has found a way to make a living and get rich in a way they definitely wouldn't approve - porn. He quickly becomes famous due to his long member. Life in the 70s as a porn star contains many unique highlights but also many potential pitfalls. This movie is directed by Paul Thomas Anderson (There Will be Blood) and stars Mark Wahlberg (The Departed), Luis Guzmán (Traffic), Burt Reynolds (Smokey and the Bandit), Julianne Moore (Magnolia), Don Cheadle (Crash) and Heather Graham (Austin Powers). The storyline for this is so unique and well told. The depiction of the 70s was excellent as was the soundtrack. The acting is outstanding and the writing and dialogue was perfect as was Damon as the main character. The circumstances are hilarious and the end is perfection based on the storyline. Overall this is an underrated masterpiece that is a must see and an easy 10/10 that I'd strongly recommend.

A shocking, but honest film about the porn industry in the 1970's and the price people had to pay for drugs, stardom, infidelity. Wahlberg makes a new name for himself as a John Holmesian clone who becomes the biggest star in the history of adult films because of his "very effective machinery." Burt Reynolds gives the finest performance of his career as the director, mentor and father figure of the young star. He shows us a character. Not a parody or a joker. He's a true character. He steals the film! Julianne Moore and Heather Graham also star.

One of my favorite films of the last 20 years. Funny, sad, wildly brave visually. This is brash, bold filmmaking, featuring amazing use of music - both period songs and score. Somehow this manages uses the world of porn film-making to examine families, American politics in the 70s and 80s and all sorts of serious themes while also being a flat out blast to watch. It was criticized a bit on release for plagiarizing Scorsese, especially 'Goodfellas', but to me this is homage in the best sense. Taking great work done by others and building on it to create something new. Indeed, the excitement I had on first seeing it reminded me of my first falling in love with Scorsese's kinetic work as a young film fan many years ago.

Review title: An everlasting tribute to San Fernando valley as everything about this film is true.
Review_body: Paul Thomas Anderson's film "Boogie Nights" must be universally hailed as a somewhat near perfect approximation of San Fernando valley based American porn film industry.It is quite a cute,harmless fun type film which can easily be watched with family members as there is hardly any controversial matter in this 150 minutes long film.Boogie nights is a comic film about porn film industry where artistic success is highly ephemeral and innovative methods to generate material success are frowned upon.It makes us laugh about the vagaries of people involved in porn industry as porn industry insiders and veterans are perceived as bad people.This is because a large section of society continues to consider their actions as wicked."Boogie Nights" is not a film for sleazy minds as it focuses more on human element of adult film industry.All dramatic scenes have comical touch to them as they appear too good to be true."Boogie Nights" clicks as it suggests that as long as there is fascination in human minds about visual representation of human sexuality,porn films would continue to be made in the world.All said and done, "Boogie Nights" will always be analyzed as a good representation of an industry where actors do not act but are made to perform in front of cameras.

Review title: Perhaps the most touching analysis of the porn industry ever made
Review_body: In one of this film's most crucial scenes, porn director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) explains that his aim is to make an adult picture with a story that's compelling enough to keep the audience focused on the plot and not just the hardcore sex scenes. He wants to move the viewers, rather than arouse them. That sequence neatly sums up what Paul Thomas Anderson has achieved with his second feature, the stunning, oddly heartbreaking Boogie Nights.Set between 1977 and 1984, the picture tells us how lives can change thanks to the adult film industry: it is the golden years of porn cinema, and Jack Horner is the most successful filmmaker in that sector. He gets particularly lucky when he meets Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg), a 17-year old waiter with an unusually large manhood. After a night of drinks and sex in Jack's house, the young man happily accepts to become his new star, and the results show pretty quickly: Dirk Diggler, as he is now known, is the hottest name in the business, which means he can get whatever he wants, whether it's a fast car, nice clothes, ladies or drugs.Such "happiness", however, is not meant to last: being a porn star might change your life, but "change" does not necessarily mean "improve". The trouble starts when Floyd Gondolli (Philip Baker Hall) tells Jack the future of the industry is videotape, meaning there is no more need for professionals. As is that weren't enough, most of the cast and crew have problems of their own: Jack's leading lady, Amber Waves (Julianne Moore), is in the middle of a bitter custody battle with her ex-husband; Rollergirl (Heather Graham) is uncertain about what to do with her life; occasional collaborator Buck Swope (Don Cheadle) has trouble finding a real job; producer Little Bill (William H. Macy) has to deal with his adulterous wife. But the biggest liability is Dirk: filled with drugs and having an ego the size of his "torpedo" ("It's my big d*ck and I say when we roll!"), he and his partner Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly) make increasingly dangerous "business" deals with the wrong people, slowly making him realize super-stardom isn't that glamorous after all.On a technical level, Anderson gets more ambitious than he was while making his first film, Sydney, and delivers a flawless exercise in style with echoes of Scorsese (the beautiful opening tracking shot, the expert use of music), Altman (the brilliant handling of an ensemble cast, especially in the swimming pool sequence) and Tarantino (some of the characters and the dialogue, plus the off-screen violence). But what impresses the most is how he succeeds in getting a touching story out of an unconventional subject: rather than offering a two-hour montage of explicit sex (there are only two such scenes in the entire film) he focuses on the people involved in the making of this kind of flicks, with particular attention to how their lives are affected by what they do. Those expecting naked bodies are watching the wrong film: this is a chronicle of the experiences of flawed human beings in a peculiar context. Despite the premise, the movie is less interested in hardcore material than it is in the characters: layered, real and affecting, not to mention played by one of the finest ensemble casts in history (the standouts being Reynolds, Moore and Wahlberg), they are the real selling point of Anderson's poignant opus.Sex has always been used as a tool to tell stories. This film's greatness lies in taking that tool, using it to establish the setting, context and characters and then throwing it out of the window: Boogie Nights is not about sex, nor was it ever meant to be. It is a picture about life, loneliness and suffering, and that's what makes it one of the finest movies of 1997.

Writer/Director Paul Thomas Anderson probes the adult film industry of the 1970s in this classy, but imperfect, fictional story that spans the disco years, beginning in 1977, when porn movies were actually shown in movie houses. Set in the San Fernando Valley of Southern California, the basic plot pivots around Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds), king of adult film-making, who eyes a nightclub busboy named Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg). Soon, Eddie morphs into "Dirk Diggler", hot-to-trot porn star whose got the goods.But the sprawling plot encompasses a vast array of colorful characters that orbit Horner and Diggler. And therein lies one of the film's problems. The plot is overdone. It's too epical. A lot of fat could have been trimmed from the 180 pages of script and the roughly eighty speaking parts. As is, the film exudes a sense of grandiose self-indulgence.Even so, the film clearly paints porn as a for-profit business, a rather grubby, cold-blooded one at that. Horner's detached perspective insures his product's financial success, if not his workers' emotional needs. Splashy disco music enlivens the entire production, though I could have wished for a better selection of 70s music.Casting is fine, except for Wahlberg. I've seen more convincing looking porn stars-to-be sacking groceries at the local Piggly-Wiggly. Burt Reynolds makes an ideal sleaze seller. And sweet Julianne Moore convinces as a 1970s liberated woman.As much a celebration of 1970s disco culture as a primer on cinematic erotica, "Boogie Nights" oozes all the glitter of that era, with colorful costumes and funky production design. As such, it reminds me of "54" (1998), a film that is to New York City what "Boogie Nights" is to Southern California.Energetic, expansive, and chaotic in tone and plot, "Boogie Nights" thematically cautions that 1970s porn "stars", though superficially attractive, took too seriously their star status, myopic to the reality that times change, and that youth is fleeting.

Boogie Nights (1997) is a pretty famous film. It received a lot of praise, including many positive reviews and major award recognition like the golden globes and the Oscars. This is also the film that credited with jump starting Mark Wahlberg's Hollywood career. The film stars Mark Wahlberg, Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Philip Seymour Hoffman, and Don Cheadle. The acting from every one of the cast members is spot on, great performances all around. I especially liked Moore, Wahlberg, and Reynolds. Don't get me wrong, everyone else is still very good, but those three just really shined in their individual roles, enough so for Moore and Reynolds to get academy award nominations and Wahlberg to be thrust into a very successful Hollywood acting career. Boogie Nights is all about the pornography industry, well actually its more about these specifics people in the pornography industry, and how it affects their lives. I liked how the movie handled the individual lives of each character, they really gave ample amount of time to every persons storyline. The dialogue is written in a way that pulls you in and keeps you engaged. I wouldn't say that Boogie Nights is a 10/10 or that it's absolutely perfect, but it is a very well made film that deserves a watch. 8/10.

Not sure what to say about this film. It's just so much fun, sometimes it's serious, it shows the problems of 70s porn industry, it wasn't the cleanest business, but it's also a very funny film. You can watch it either for fun or historical importance.

Review title: You got the touch! You got the power!
Review_body: A great ensemble piece, this movie covers years in the lives of its characters, which gives it an epic feel. The first part of the movie is pretty fun, with everyone enjoying success. Then, it gets dark, and you feel like you might never know happiness again. Boogie Nights is not a movie I usually watch back, except for a few key scenes (such as the recording session). It's got a lot of talent, and they are all putting in awesome performances, but they capture the feel of lives spinning out of control a little too well. It was well worth a watch, and I'm sure many viewers will enjoy seeing it back. Just not me, I guess.
It was about time to watch this movie. Second favorite of PTA after Magnolia. RIP Burt Reynolds- great acting and always funny,you will be missed.Great movie and performances.

There's sex, drugs, and rock n' roll aplenty in P.T. Anderson's "Boogie Nights," but what makes this film stick with its audience long after the credits roll is the strong sense of family. OK, they're a family that makes the Louds look like the Brady Bunch (obligatory '70s ref there), but they are a real family, with a father figure, a mother figure, a distracted daughter, a rebel son, and a ton of aunt, uncle, and cousin-figures that each bring their unique issues to the mix.This is a recipe for overload in any fictional medium, but particularly a movie, where tight is usually right. Any other director would have trimmed away Little Bill and Becky Barnett faster than a disco downbeat, but P.T. Anderson does a very rare and brave thing. He not only puts these characters in, but allows his camera and script to linger on each of them, way past the point of no return in anyone else's movie. But rather than boring you, the result here is a depth of detail and lived-in feeling that brings you aboard for the whole run. It's what makes P.T. Anderson a great director. Yet it may also render him incapable of making a great movie. Discipline is not his strength."Boogie Nights" is close, though. It's a very good film, a high 8 in my book, and a movie I can get lost in over and over again. Maybe it's because I came of age in the late 1970s, and see it recaptured here in a way it has never otherwise been, in all its confused, giddy, over-the-top glory. The pace of the first half of the film is languid and measured, never rushed, yet as a whole it chugs along with an assurance that makes it hard to accept the filmmaker was only making his second major picture.People talk about the opening scene, and it's very good, but there's other highlights. The pool party at Jack's, for example, is a marvel of storytelling economy, moving through several episodes without ever feeling like any are being shortchanged. We get an earful of Reed and Eddie's first meeting, awkward pauses and all, then get introduced to the Colonel and his coke-happy date, to Scotty Jay and his crush on Eddie, then Eddie rechristening himself (in a hot tub no less, how SoCal) "Dirk Diggler." All that plot is thrown at us, but the biggest takeaway for us is a sense of the characters, because P.T. Anderson is the kind of director who makes character-driven films first.There's a lot of great detail on the porn industry subculture that feels very real and lived in, and the humor is outrageous at times (Dirk's audition with Amber, Scotty Jay's obvious gawkiness around his dream boy, Buck's image issues) without ever feeling pushed or artificial. You get a lot of depth here, the kind that rewards repeat viewings.The second half of the film loses me a little. I understand the story changes with the new decade, but it suddenly becomes so oppressively dire that the viewer, once swept into the story, has to pull away from misery overload. It's hard to pick a single excessive moment, maybe its just the way all of them come together to create a perfect storm of melodrama.That said, the Raheed Jackson sequence is the standout of the movie; a brilliant way of wrapping up Dirk's odyssey and bringing us back home. The suspense build up is incredible, and it's the one time that the film's main co-star, its soundtrack, is allowed center stage, transforming banal pop smashes like "Jessie's Girl" and "Sister Christian" into something operatic, even anthemic. We know Dirk's going nuts because the guitar break in "Jessie's Girl" tells us so.P.T. Anderson is a director I will always watch, but he does let his characters' emotions carry him away (more in "Magnolia" than here, but here, too). It's a tribute to his underlying genius that even at his most baroque, he manages to draw you into his world and hold you there like nobody else in the business. He's the kind of talent that will only improve with time, and it will be a pleasure keeping tabs on his development.

This movie is memorable thanks to terrific performances, soundtrack and most of all atmosphere.  You can almost smell the cheap cologne Dirk would wear to go disco dancing.  The firecracker scene topped it all off.  Add the wonderful Julianne Moore, and it doesn't get any better than this.

Review title: Paul Thomas Anderson Struts His Stuff
Review_body: Paul Thomas Anderson is amazing when it comes to bringing to life believable characters (I'd argue my three of his films are essentially character studies- "There Will Be Blood", "The Master", and "Phantom Thread"). He knows how to take a character and flesh them out so that they all seem to have urges, dreams, cares, and fears about the world that Anderson places them in, and in giving these characters more depth, the world feels far more tactile. The character relationships shift and change as things happen throughout the movie. Almost every character in this movie is dynamic- when we're introduced to them in the beginning, they're one way, and by the time we leave them, they're different. What's so impressive about this film is the way that Anderson works in all of the different character arcs without making the story feel overly complex, complicated, or an hour too long (there are some scenes in this movie that probably could've been trimmed, but for a two and a half hour film, it seems to move quickly). While the main story revolves around Eddie/Dirk's rise to fame, this movie is essentially an ensemble piece- we spend time getting to know each and every character in their own separate scenes, fleshing out the members of the adoptive family that Dirk joins. I do want to mention, that while I think this script is great, I'd say that Anderson's later scripts show a lot more complexity and depth.

Review title: Ninety minutes of fun material in a clunky two and a half hour movie
Review_body: It is amazing how a movie can fall apart just as quickly as it comes together. For a while, Paul Thomas Andersson's Boogie Night's recalls Goodfellas; a subjective story about a nobody who becomes a big somebody. Unfortunately Andersson is not content with the movie being that simple. He wants to make it bigger and bolder, and about halfway in, it turns into an ensemble feature. The whole thing doesn't come together very well. The plot grows increasingly stagy, and the characters are given no room to grow. Where as Goodfellas grew tighter and more intense with each chapter, Boogie Nights grows tiresome. Its self-indulgence is frustrating because for a while I was really enjoying myself. But just when things are looking good, Boogie Nights ceases to commit to the direction it started with, so why should we stay committed?.

Review title: An example of film making at its most incredible.
Review_body: Boogie Nights is one of the best films to come out of the 90's and I'd go so far as to say it should be in the IMDb top 250. I can actually understand why many would dislike it, due to the subject matter. I personally feel however as many do, judging from the aclaim this film's received by viewers and critics that it's topnotch film making.The direction and acting in this film surpass good and reach the level of brilliance.There is not one scene in this movie that isn't amazing. The individual characters reach out and touch you. Given that this is a movie about the porn industry, one wouldn't imagine the sex scenes could be handled with such sensitivity but they are. The direction is among the best I've ever seen-and I've seen a lot of films.The film isn't about one particular personal individual's story, it's about many.It's a character study about people who have many layers to them and who maybe in an industry most would find alien but who still dream the same dreams and have both bad and good to them. Boogie Nights draws you into their story from the beginning, and though the film is long(I believe almost 3 hours) you honestly don't even notice. And when it ends you kind of don't want it to....I'm not easy to impress, meaning there aren't many movies I'd give a 10 of 10 rating to but this is one. Beyond the multiple character study, is the use of music in the film. I have never, in all my years of seeing movies seen music tell a story as well as in this movie.There was such flawlessness to it, you know it's not something your gonna see everyday.Burt reynold's performance was perhaps the best I've ever seen him do, and Mark Wahlberg is incredible(I'm astounded there are still people saying he doesn't act well. I don't know how anyone viewing this could possibly think that)but the person who really surprised me was Heather Grahem(Rollergirl) who is absolutely fantastic in her role, in particular the one memorable scene with Burt Reynolds in the Limo, towards the end.Again, I'll echo other IMDb reviewers in saying this movie is not for everybody. But I still think this was topnotch.10 of 10.

I never saw this when it came out, so I didn't drink the P.T. Anderson Kool-aid. I haven't liked his other movies so there was no rush to rent this. Hard 8 while being miserable, bleak, and nothing I ever want to sit through again, was at least competent movie-making. This is Anderson's first big success and he's already gone Hollywood. It's an empty viewing experience. I'm not a prude by any standard, but is there any other place Hollywood movies about drugs, sex and porn go other than descent and misery? Gee, with such ignorant characters, I thought things would always be swell. The idea that somehow plots made porn more valuable before the industry moved to videotape is utterly ridiculous. Plot has always been in the way in porn movies. This didn't need to be 3 hours. It puts no ideas into play that do not issue directly from the mouths of one character or another. Long before Magnolia's contrived epiphany sequence Anderson was so uninterested in decent storytelling that he did it here too. All three characters have epiphanies compressed into a single day. I guess that was simpler for him to grasp. But hey, the "long movie must be respectable" gimmick worked and this garnered a bounty of nominations. So he's done it twice since.

Review title: First his name was Eddie Adams, later Dirk Diggler and finally Brock Landers
Review_body: Sometime ago I watched a video of Paul Thomas Anderson in which he express the big interest that he has in porn films and how this industry could've produce better films and in consequence a complete genre and not just sex in video tape. Paul Thomas Anderson put his own believes of porn industry in the character played in a terrific way by Burt Reynolds. His name is Jack Horner, a director whose biggest dream is to make a "real" film that can keep the viewer in suspense because of the great dramatic story and, at the same time, exciting with the beauty and with the "big cocks and tits". Soon as he meets Eddie Adams (Mark Walhberg), he believes that he has found the new star for his films. And that's how the story of the young Eddie in the porn industry begins.The film begins with a sequence inside a night club where we can see all the persons that will be part of Eddie's life and later we can see them outside the porn industry, living their daily routine. But soon we can see them inside the porn industry and after only one party, the story of the new Eddie begins, the story of Dirk Diggler. All of them will taste the real success with Dirk as the main star, winning lots of prizes and helping Jack to make real his biggest dream with a series of films about Brock Landers, the new character of Dirk. This sort of exploitation films are an amazing success and for Jack are his firsts "real" films. But here is the beginning of the end and the beginning of the "horrible 80's" when there is going to be $ex, DRUGS and Rock & Roll for Dirk and pals. But we all know that the excesses can destroy any person and the erectile dysfunction can destroy any porn star and here the film focuses in their lives after the total success and how everybody is having a real bad time with many problems due to society's bad look to porn industry and to a period with many excesses. In Dirk's decadence, after trying and failing in the music industry, there's a brilliant sequence that can resume in a perfect way how the things are going for Dirk and his friends. That sequence is the one of his first drug deal, with the appearance of Alfred Molina, which ends in a total mess. Is funny for us and a terrible experience for Dirk and pals but there's always a solution if you get back in what you know and when Dirk is back, Brock is back.Well I haven't mention most of the characters in my sort of a summary but I must say that all are amazingly well developed. The cast is just superb with the best performance that I have seen of Mark Walhberg. Julianne Moore has a powerful performance in a really moving character; Reilly, Macy, Hoffman, Heather Graham, Guzman, etc are just memorable, all of their characters with funny and sad moments.Finally, I really love the amazing cinematic style of Anderson here with a unique view to the porn industry of the late 70's and early 80's. I used to say that "Magnolia" was my favourite of Anderson but right now, after watching all except "Sidney", I can't say that I have a favourite because I love them all!PS: somewhere I read that this film is the "Scorsese film" of Anderson so I'm more than sure that if you love "Goodfellas" and "Casino" you will love this one too. I f*cking love "Boogie Nights"!

Review title: VIEWS ON FILM review of Boogie Nights
Review_body: Boogie Nights remains to this day, my favorite film of all time. It's a firecracker of a movie and a kaleidoscope of colorful, 70's pop culture. Paul Thomas Anderson pays homage to a host of brilliant directors like Martin Scorsese, Stanley Kubrick, Robert Altman, and Quentin Tarantino to guide his camera and volt forward, his supreme storytelling style. With a plot that involves the trials and tribulations of everyone involved in the adult film world, Boogie Nights has a cast here that is full of interesting, quirky characters, it has a couple of enthralling (not to mention elaborate) steadicam shots, and it possesses a soundtrack that tracks gleefully, the rhythms of all the fabulous, energized jump cuts. Mark Wahlberg as the lead and well hung male adult actor (Dirk Diggler), gives a startling, breakthrough performance. But it's Burt Reynolds who bests him as his go-to porn director. Burt's star never shined so bright as it did here (and this is over a 50 plus year career). Look for a drug deal scene gone amuck, a donut shop scene posing as a Mexican standoff, and a disco dance sequence that gives you your Saturday Night Fever fix.Overall, this is what invigorating, epic, staunch film making is all about. A giddy masterpiece!

I'm so disappointed after seeing this film... it went nowhere close to where I thought it would go.Boogie Nights, although having an interesting subject, executes it very poorly. There are no big happenings in the film, there are many unnecessary characters like the stereo guy, there's NO SUCH pornography (it shouldn't even be Rated R) and there's a clearly plagiarism of Pulp Fiction.Furthermore, it gets to that famous point that you don't care for any of the characters anymore. Even thought it kind of entertain, I wouldn't give a second shot neither recommend it to anyone.

Review title: The Shortest Three Hours of My Life
Review_body: In a nutshell, "Boogie Nights" is a rare movie in that steps out of the lines in terms of categorization. The movie surfaces around the pornography business. Even though there is a fair amount of steaming seductive scenes, it's content is not overly gratuitous. There is a lot of humour delivered here, it's mostly dark and at times a bit hard to swallow at times. A plethora of the settings and situations were not intended to be entertaining, but one couldn't help but to be intrigued by the scenes as they were very entertaining in spite of it almost three hour duration.The structure of the film is not very perpendicular that makes this movie stand up above the rest. There is no spoon-feeding in terms of delivery by director/writer Paul Thomas Anderson, instead it's customized to play with your mind which is obscure in the film business. Can anyone name me a moment in a movie where they install a very lustful sex scene and turn it into one very mundane effort that continues on for so long? "Boogie Nights" succeeds in its attempt to show how unglamourous the sex industry really is as it's nothing more than all in a day's work.Set in the 1970's and 1980's, principal characters in the movie include Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg who was very dominant in his role), who is taken by awe by a porno guru Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds who was also quite impressive) as he transforms Adams into a porn star and goes as far as to change his name to Dirk Diggler.Diggler's rise in the porn star business is weaved by other performers that share the world he's gotten himself into. There's the doped up porn queen Amber Waves (Julianne Moore), who's like a mentor to Dirk because she is off limits from seeing her own biological child. John C. Reilly was a standout as Dirk's best pat Reed Rothschild. Heather Graham was brilliant and beautiful as Rollergirl and feels her comfort zone is when she performs using her roller-skates. Then there's Buck Swope (Don Cheadle), who likes to dress like Gene Autry and has further ambitions to open up a video store. And finally there's Little Man, (William H. Macy) who has bottled up anger because his wife constantly commits infidelity on a regular basis and shows absolute no remorse for her actions. Director Anderson follows his narration much to the tradition of Robert Altman by executing his story in a vignette approach.The constant rags-to-riches story as a whole is both funny, terrifying, melancholy, but still succeeds in lifting your hearts at the the right time. One of the more engaging scenes is when Dirk cuts a deal with a druggie. The problem is the crack he's selling is superficial and the dealer's pad is filled with goons while this is happening, firecrackers are being lit all to the song of Night Ranger's "Sister Christian". This scene was perfectly executed that the fear and tension comes to life and while you're watching the scene the fear takes charge into the rooms you're sitting at. If thats not top notch directing, than what is? The performances were brilliant, but it was Reynolds and Moore that had the strongest performances. The feeling of the 1970's and 1980's looks very authentic (even the poster of Cheryl Tiegs on Dirk's wall looks groovy), and the music is truly far out. It definitely is one of the best films of the 1990's and though Anderson may have patted himself on the back a little too much, all the flaws can be forgiven easily due to the vibrant energy and the engaging performances.

Review title: I'm a star, I'm a star, I'm a star
Review_body: "Boogie Nights" is one of those rare movies that manages to find the perfect balance between comedy and drama. I mean, there are a lot of laughs throughout, but you always laugh with a lump in your throat. This movie just bathes in a general feeling of false optimism: occasionally it looks like everyone's having the time of their life, but it's all just an illusion. Particularly the ending, which I can't go into too much detail about, captures that idea perfectly. At first it's pretty fulfilling, but the ending gets less happy with every second you think about it. Apart from being a great, bittersweet character study, the movie also creates tremendous amounts of tension when it needs to. The scene with the drug deal that goes awry might just be the most bone-chilling scene I've ever watched. Everything about it is just perfect, right down to the use of silly 80s pop songs as the soundtrack. I was drenched in sweat after watching that part, magnificent how it gradually builds up to its unexpected climax. The only bad thing I can really say about this movie is that the practical effect in the last shot is laughably unconvincing, but even that's not really a criticism given that I can imagine them doing it on purpose. Awesome movie, one of the best movies the 1990s had to offer.

I saw Boogie Nights on IFC a few nights ago.I must say, this film is great.From the excellent acting, the characters to the soundtrack & plot, this is a great film.It has an all star cast featuring Mark Wahlberg, William H Macy, John C Reilly, Julianne Moore, Burt Reynolds, Luis Guzman and a few others.It's pretty graphic in terms of sex/nudity(it's about the porn industry).Also has quite a bit of drug use and some strong violence, but if you can look past that, you will see a brilliant film.It starts off in 1977, Mark Wahlberg is a dishwasher looking to earn a few extra bucks.A porn director then takes him under his wing and introduces him to the world of being a porn star.It starts off all glamorous and whatnot, however later on the consequences show up, just like in movies such as "Scarface", we see the consequences of the seemingly great lifestyle.The film spans from 1977-1984 and has an excellent soundtrack and some very good scenes! Boogie Nights is just a great movie! I recommend you watch it.

Review title: Proof that there are very few directors better than Paul Thomas Anderson.
Review_body: Paul Thomas Anderson has only made a moderate amount of movies, but each one of them that I've seen has had a common effect on me. I couldn't wait to watch them again, after they were over. My first impression of Boogie Nights was that it started off fairly slowly. For the first hour or so of the movie, I was under the impression that it was going to be the first PTA film that I didn't absolutely love. And then, a few absolutely fantastic scenes turned my opinion right around. I was so impressed, that I immediately watched the entire 155 minute film again. There are very few movies that I've had that reaction to, but in this case it was both pleasurable and enlightening. I still think that the second half of Boogie Nights is the stronger part, but the first half is also very good. This is a great example of a fantastic writer being paired with a dream cast. The main characters are all expertly written and acted, and that's to be expected. Mark Wahlberg, Julianne Moore, and Thomas Jane all gave the best performances of their careers here, in my opinion. But even the minor characters get powerful moments that stick in your mind after the movie is over. Actors like Don Cheadle, Alfred Molina, Philip Seymour Hoffman, and William H. Macy didn't have nearly the screen time of Mark Wahlberg or Burt Reynolds, but they were just as instrumental in making Boogie Nights as good as it is. Nearly every character is given an opportunity to make an emotional connection with the viewer, and that's astounding. As far as I'm concerned, this movie was overflowing with iconic performances, and there are two or three scenes that are easily some of the best I've ever seen in ANYTHING. Anderson is undeniably gifted at both writing, directing, and choosing the right music to enhance his work. I don't know if I like Boogie Nights quite as much as There Will Be Blood or Punch Drunk Love, but it really says something when a movie that's longer than average, never drags for a moment and leaves me wanting more. It benefits greatly from multiple viewings, and I'm sure my fondness of the movie will only grow.

"Boogie Nights" takes us back to the late seventies where we trace the path of a rising star on the porn scene. We are treated to an intimate look at the ins and outs of the porno industry as we follow Dirk Diggler from overnight success to inevitable decline.The first thing that must be said about this film is that the cast is outstanding. It's character actor heaven with the likes of John C. Reilly, William H. Macy, Luis Guzman, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Philip Baker Hall and more. Not only that, there are others (like Mark Wahlberg) who deliver the best performances of their careers.However, all of this acting talent would have gone to waste if the screenplay wasn't up to snuff. Luckily, Anderson's script was good enough to snag an Oscar nomination. It contains plenty of humour although the tone of the film gradually darkens until the characters hit rock bottom. Overall, the story is nicely balanced and presents a fascinating view of this 'family' of pornographers.Anderson's direction is well handled though some might feel that he was just a little flashier than necessary. On the audio front, the soundtrack is yet another component of the film that deserves high praise. Vintage songs are featured prominently and the selections show a keen sense of taste and aptness.All in all, I'd rank this as one of my favorite films of the 90's. However, I can see that the subject matter and approach may not appeal to all. Nevertheless, I think that this is Anderson's best film (so far).

I really enjoyed Boogie Nights. I would normally think twice about giving such movie an 8, but I think it was well deserved. One of Wahlbergs early performances that put him on the map. He kind of played the young dumb stupid up and comer. The rest of the cast was funny. It was a pretty deep movie. I enjoyed it a lot.Highly recommend8 stars

Review title: A smart, provocative piece of work by Paul Thomas Anderson
Review_body: Paul Thomas Anderson isn't just any Hollywood director, he's a filmmaker with a provocative sense of style and writing, and this comedy-drama period piece effectively proves so. This film stars a brilliant ensemble cast in what may seem like a solid non- documentary examination of the pornographic industry during the 1970s but is actually an inside look at the characters' adventures through the controversial entertainment business. With the stylish script, direction, and realistic depiction of the social satire in the 70s by Anderson; this film comes be a sassy and powerfully clever picture. Set in San Fernando Valley, California in the late 70s, this film introduces Eddie Adams (played by Mark Wahlberg), a seventeen-year old high school dropout who spends his nights working as a bus boy at the Reseda Night Club. There he meets adult film director Jack Horner (played by Burt Reynolds) who sees talent in the young man. After a meeting with Horner, his star Amber Waves (played by Julianne Moore), and a young runaway named Brandy (played by Heather Graham) nicknamed "Rollergirl", Eddie is driven into the eccentric world of the porn industry where he meets actors Reed Rothchild (played by John C. Reilley), producer Little Bill (played by William H. Macy) who struggles with his wife's infidelity, and music executive Bucky Swope (played by Don Cheadle). Adopting his stage name Dirk Diggler, Eddie ventures through the highs and unexpected lows of the Californian porn industry.From the exhilarating screenplay by Paul Thomas Anderson, the sassy disco soundtrack and costume design to represent the 70s (and 80s) settings, and the ambitious performances by the cast; it is easy to consider this Anderson's career-defining entry. Venturing through the lives of the characters and their ups and downs in the adult film business including infidelity and troubled fame, this film delivers plenty of surprises and wit from the hands of director Anderson, and the story falls nothing short of engaging and sweet, though it feels somewhat uneven in the second half. Of course, as pornography serves as the central point of the story, there is a heavy amount of sexual activity, raucous dialogue, nudity, and abundance of cocaine abused throughout, let's not forget the unexpected violence that breaks out between certain scenes; all of which can be significantly uncomfortable for sensitive movie-goers to sit through. But thanks to the stylish cinematography by Robert Elswit and the sharply written dialogue, it's all done in a way not meant to be gratuitous. When the story suspends from it's emotional heft, viewers are granted with some hilarious (and vulgar) dialogue, slick social commentary, and light- hearted gags, mostly from the mouths of Mark Wahlberg and Burt Reynolds, both of whom are deeply engaging in their roles; standing out from the overcrowd of underdeveloped characters. Though Paul Thomas Anderson may suffer a bad case of "ensemble cast syndrome" that results in some characters that fall shallow, his stylish quality in filmmaking and writing are effective enough to shade over these flaws.Boogie Nights is a smart, provocative piece of work that can be called one of the best films made by the hands of Paul Thomas Anderson. This film is full or surprises and intelligence that scale high above its vulgarity and rawness. Though this doesn't pack the same kind of popular status as other 90s film like Quentin Tarantino's 'Pulp Fiction' or James Cameron 'Titanic', it makes an important piece of modern cinema.

Boogie nights, in short, is amazing. Truly amazing. I know that the plot doesn't sound that interesting, but it's a great film. Paul Thomas Anderson has done some of the best films I have ever seen. I mean the man is a genius. His films are occasionally funny, very dramatic, and at times kind of odd.Boogie nights is one of those films. The film focuses on a high school drop out bartender named Eddie(played fantastically by Mark Whalberg). One night, a porn director named Jack(Played fantastically by Burt Reynolds) offers him a job. At first he doesn't accept it. Thewn the next day he gets to know the cast, and has sex. Then once he gets home his mom freaks out on him. So Eddie runs away. So after that Eddie goes to meet Jack and the cast. You get to know the cast. William H. Macy plays a guy who has been cheated on three times. Don Cheadle plays a guy who is trying to get into a stereo business. John C.Reilly plays an actor on set. Julianne Moore plays an actress that is fighting in a custody battle for her son. Eventually, Eddie comes up with his own porn star name Dirk Diggler. Also, Dirk becomes very famous. Winning many adult film awards including best cock and best actor. But as his career continues, his life begins to fall apart. Once everyone quits the business, their lives fall apart. Their lives are ruined by porn.I love the film's soundtrack. I also love how it shows how ridiculous the porn industry is. I also love how the film has a very happy ending. I still have yet to see Paul Thomas Anderson's Hard eight and Magnolia. Where I have I been for the past couple of years. These are amazing movies. how could this movie not be nominated for best picture? It was amazing. After seeing a movie like There will be blood, or Punch drunk love or especially, Boogie nights, someone should send Paul Thomas Anderson a letter saying " Please, make more". Boogie nights: A

Man, "Boogie Nights" must be like "The Breakfast Club" of the 90\s. Take a bunch of actors on the cusp of stardom, and put them into a multlayered complex movie. This movie just happens to be about the Porn industry in the late 70's-early 1980's. When I first saw this when the film just came out, the only person I recognized in the cast was of course, Burt Reynolds and that rapper-turned-actor, Mark Wahlberg. Nowadays, I can recognize everyone and just be agog at how much pre-starpower there is: Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, John C, Mcginley, Don Cheadle, William Maxy, Phillip Seymour Hoffman etc etc, This film just gets better and better with each viewing, and the firecracker scene at the ending becomes more hilarious then nerve wracking ( not that it doesn't lose it's power - After maybe 3-4 viewings, I always forget the conclusion of this scene, which increases it's brilliance because it's the firecrackers you remember, and it keeps you wondering.. what happens after this?

Review title: An Excellent Mainstream look into Pornography in the 70's/80's
Review_body:
What a bold undertaking to present a film to mainstream audiences showing them a tad of what the pornography industry was about in Southern California in the 70's/80's. This is when Pornography was going..."mainstream". This is when those doing these films wanted to prove this genre was more than just sex -- that it was no different than major motion pictures and the actors actually saw themselves this way.I think if a theme like this was done by others, it would have went way off base..some Producers/Directors trying to weed in social commentary or their beliefs -- while others just getting "down and dirty" in telling the tale...which would have indeed turned me off from seeing this film.Director Paul Thomas Anderson didn't go either route. He just let you decide what to make of it, all he does is show you the lives of these folks at that time when so many changes were happening to that industry, to the characters and the world around them. You learn that these actors/actresses were regular people, real folks. They hurt, they bleed, they wanted real love and committment, and they wanted to party and be "famous".Some had problems, but the idea that "hookers" and "morally bankrupt people" were all that made up this industry, you see here that's not all true. At this time, that was all being turned around.In "Boogie Nights" you view these characters reasons for getting involved in such an industry. The way its done is good. What happens to these characters are good to see as well, how much money and power they get, how it all goes away....all the things they get involved in...and what for? I love the transition from the 70's to the 80's when Video makes this industry grow even more mainstream. The challenges of those who do NOT want to change.
Not all good things happen to these characters. Southern California -- The Valley -- is known for its adult films NOW. This shows you how all that probably started and how "stars" were made out of those who acted in it. It is a closed knit industry, everyone knows everyone else and from what I understand, its hard to "progress" from adult films to Hollywood Films/Series but some have done so.I really like the 70's feel of the film, this is one of the only films to date that actually captures late 70's styles, clothes, hair, attitude which made it also fun to watch. The transition into the early 80's was nice too, leaving out one main event that eventually plagued the adult sex industry, but this film wasn't about that. It really stops at a certain time because it only goes through the main character's rise and fall in a very taboo industry. The casting of Burt Reynolds was smart as was sprinkling the movie with real adult film stars. Excellent performances from the leads Mark Walhberg and Julianne Moore and such memorable performances from Luis Guzman, Don Cheatle, Phillip Baker Hall, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Heather Graham, Ricky Jay, John C. Reilly, Robert Ridgley (Just wonderful!), Nicole Ari Parker, and Thomas Jane -- who looks like they just picked him up right from the 70's Male Stud Cosmopolitan Center Fold Spread and threw him in there!Boogie Nights is not for everyone, and its not for those looking to get a cheap "buzz" from porno-light. It's a smart film with smart acting and directing that makes it way above the pack for its theme and well worth seeing.

This is without a doubt one of my all time favourite movies. While Paul Thomas Anderson has arguably matured as a director (and many would say his later films like There Will Be Blood and The Master are better), I don't think any will replace Boogie Nights as my personal favourite from him.I first watched this back in 2012, when I was maybe just old enough to watch it, at the still pretty young age of 17. I loved (and honestly still do love) Tarantino, Scorsese, and De Palma, and you can clearly see that these directors were a big influence on Paul Thomas Anderson for this film. Some may see that as a detriment, but I don't think it's too derivative of anything else (though the opening shot does flirt with being very comparable to a similarly lengthy one-shot early on in Goodfellas).Anyway, the first time I watched this, I remember loving the movie so much that at about the halfway point, I felt that it was going by too quickly. So I paused the movie, did some other stuff for about half an hour, and then came back, because the movie felt too good to finish; I didn't want it to be over. Since then, I've never done this (admittedly odd behaviour) with any other film. Not even with the ones I've loved on the same level as Boogie Nights.What we have here is an ensemble cast- one of the best ever assembled- all operating at the top of their game, working with a young but incredibly talented director, and with an excellent screenplay and fantastic soundtrack carrying the whole thing along. Everything moves at a great pace, every actor and actress gets at least one extremely memorable scene to shine, and the film seamlessly flips around between being funny, sad, introspective, uncomfortable, and tense.I think I could give this close to a perfect score for the Alfred Molina scene alone. Without saying what happens, it's just 10 minutes of filmed perfection- so funny, so intense, so insane, and incredibly edited and scored with several 80s hits to boot. Most filmmakers won't make a scene that good in their entire career, and Paul Thomas Anderson did it in just his second feature, and managed to put said scene in a movie filled with countless other scenes that are almost all just as good.Boogie Nights is a must watch, for its great acting, stylish direction, memorable soundtrack, fantastic depiction of both the 70s AND 80s, and for its taboo yet always interesting subject matter. The fact that movies this good exist gives me an odd sense of hope, as if we can't be living in the darkest timeline if this timeline has blessed us with Paul Thomas Anderson, and he himself has subsequently blessed us with Boogie Nights.Watch it and rewatch it and rewatch it again. It never gets old, and it almost feels as though it hasn't aged a day. Boogie Nights is absolute perfection on celluloid.

Review title: It's my big d*ck and I say when we roll.
Review_body: Burt Reynolds immediately grounds us within the 70s world of pornography that seems to be at first all glitz and glamour. He is the most assured of this wild, sweeping cast - a porno king played straight. He takes his porn serious, thinks of it as an art-form, and aspires to elevate the medium to new levels even as the technological shift threatens to move from big screens to small. Not only is he the overseeing director, but he is the daddy of this f*cked up family, and even as his kingdom falls around him his arms will be wide open welcoming back his children and telling them to clean their rooms. But of course, this is not about him, but about Wahlberg's Eddie who strives to make it big after years of emotional abuse from a stunted upbringing. Anderson makes the porn star life as frenetic and glamorous as possible - from the opening take that sweeps around and unveils the crowded bar, to the whip pans and frantic zooms and camera light- bulbs flashing from all directions in the frenzied montage that says "you've made it". Of course, it's nothing that Scorsese hasn't already done before. And it seems that Anderson likes to pick and choose his tragedies as he pleases in order to serve the narrative; early on there is a hilarious encounter with a washed-up star that has just seen his second OD in just two days, and although this is foreshadowing, Anderson can't help but show this through a comedic lens because of the hazy, orgasmic high from Dirk Diggler's rise to stardom. Later, when the script calls for his fall from grace, drug addiction is again the vice, but it doesn't unfold in any real capacity. It's like Anderson needed a stereotypical plot device to engineer the darker moments and just throws cocaine at the screen without actually engaging with it at any deeper level. And that goes also for Macy's character, who exits with the most self-indulgent little nod you might see from a suicide scene. The rest of the 'family' have their own f*cked up problems, although the theory that leaving the family results in tragedy doesn't seem to hold up when you point the camera at Julianne Moore. Her own storyline is tragic enough; having lost out on custody of her actual kid, she spends her days codling and mothering Dirk as a way of compensating for her previous loss. But Anderson feels the need to condescend these heart-wrenching emotions by focusing on her sobbing after another failed attempt to win back visitation rights. How can we pity someone when we do not know the whole story, but are merely pushed into the act of sympathy because pornography is somehow being demonised? It works a little better for Don Cheadle's Buck, where we see the visible frustration at being not taken seriously because he acted in a few pornos.It seems that Anderson grows the story from these characters, the live-wire humour, the zany, half believable situations they find themselves in. There are smaller moments of characterisation that are allowed to stand for themselves. The sweet little "ki-yaa" that Buck and Jessie share in the car, both having somehow escaped from the toxicity of the family and made a life for themselves (although even then Anderson has to shove the most inexplicably coincidental bit of violence to kickstart it). And Heather Graham's Rollergirl, a bundle of sexual energy that glides around everywhere in her skates and almost makes us forget she is just a kid still in school. But if you pull away for the bigger picture it seems all too inconsequential. Philip Seymour Hoffman has a heartbreaking moment, and then just sort of disappears. Wahlberg's rise and fall seems completely determined by the script rather than actual cause and effect in the narrative - when he can no longer get hard, the cause is because of his drug addiction, but this hasn't been expanded on, but merely presented as a symptom of burn out in the high stakes porno industry. And Anderson adds dissolves to the crucial scene, instead of letting the built-up frustration from Wahlberg take its natural toll (this might be because Wahlberg has never really been a great actor, but at the time he seemed fresh). Why not let the film roll, like he does in that tense cooker-pot situation where the fireworks keep making the group jump and they slowly realise this is a bad idea? Wahlberg sits there frozen for a good 45 seconds as he comes to the realisation. It's also one of the only scenes where Anderson's use of 80s pop hits doesn't seem like an ironic touch (although that just might be because of Molina's fantastically unhinged performance - "He's Chinese...). These are the worn out tracks from the jukebox, the tunes that everyone knows even if they didn't experience that era. It's phony.

Review title: Ranks Among My All Time Favorites
Review_body: P.T Anderson hit the Hollywood scene in 1997 with "Hard Eight" and "Boogie Nights". But it was "Boogie Nights" that launched his career into the mainstream, and earned him several Oscar nominations. But it was robbed, BIG TIME, for at least a nomination for best picture. "Boogie Nights" is hands down one of the best American movies in the last 25 years. P.T Anderson is an undeniable master of drama, and he (really) should stand among the ranks of Tarentino and Scorsese. The way he weaved this tumultuous narrative was groundbreaking for any filmmaker of the time. The story is essentially a young man finally finding the love and affection he always needed from a new family. The only problem is, this family is in the smut business. It's a story as provocative as the centerfold of a Hustler magazine, but as thought provoking as "Citizen Kane". The performances are some of the best I've ever seen. Mark Wahlberg's screen debut as Dirk Diggler is arguably his best performance to date. Burt Reynolds is captivating as Jack Horner, the pornographer who dreams of making Oscar gold. Julianne Moore deserved her Oscar for her performance of Amber Waves, a former mother who finds her sense of family with the people she sleeps with, and not with the children she birthed. Also, you've got Heather Graham as Rollergirl, Don Cheadle, the always funny John C. Reilly, the even funnier Phillip Seymour Hoffman. Then, you have William H. Macy as Little Bill, or what can only be described as the ultimate cuckold. His shattering performance ranks with Steve Buscemi's Donny from "The Big Lebowski" as one of the funniest characters in all of film. Who else could forget the scene at the drug dealers house with the firecrackers and the.? OK for those of you who haven't seen the movie yet, I might be getting ahead of myself. I just get so excited talking about this film! Its scenes like that that make the entire film an unforgettable experience. This film clocks in at 155 minutes which is precisely one minute longer than Pulp Fiction, but like Pulp Fiction, every minute is enthralling. Its the greatest 2 and 1/2 hours you could possibly spend on Netflix. My love for this movie grows every time I think about it, and I want to share that love with all of you. Enjoy!

I put off watching this film for a while, and I'm not sure why. The film explores the golden age of pornography which went from the late 70's and into the 80's. The first half of the film is nice, vibrant, sexual, and just a great time. Paul Thomas Anderson has a bunch of actors that he uses in most of his work, and its a great bunch that don't fail. What starts off as a fun look at the porn industry, then turns into a dramatic and emotional tale that takes a look into the negatives of the industry. Won't give anything away, but you can see PTA's brilliance especially as the film winds down. Overall, its a very good film that is very much worth a look.8/10

Review title: A Brilliant, funny , bitter sweet movie.A Classic.
Review_body: Boogie Nights is one of those movies that you can watch over and over again.In the Vain of Goodfellas and Casino.It is a movie that will stand the test of time . The Film is about a young man ,Dirk Digler(Mark Wahlberg) who finds himself being recruted into the pornography buisiness by a film maker,Jack Horner(Burt Reynolds) because of his huge talent,and i'm not talking about his acting ability!. The movie takes us through his innocent beginings into porn and how it goes very wrong. For me this film is not so much about the story but it is about the acting,Mark Wahlberg,Burt Reynolds ,Julianne Moore,Heather Graham and William H Macey are all magnificent. At the start of the film you cant help but really like the people, they all have there own personalities. They all start of as a sexy group of people and after the drugs kick in they become inwardly ugly. In a way the film does take a down turn when their personalities change simply because you dont quite like them as much as before and that says a lot for the cast. The way the film takes us through the seventies and early eighties by bombarding us with a fantastic soundtrack can only be applauded. 9 out of 10.

Boogie Nights is an uncritical look behind the scenes of the porn industry as it moved from theatrical films to home video.  Burt Reynolds is outstanding as Jack Horner, film-maker and leader of an extended family of porn stars, technicians and gofers.  Julianne Moore stars as the porn veteran cum mother-figure to Dirk Diggler, teen-age discovery of Jack's whose god-given endowment leads him quickly to the top of the porn industry.Aided by an excellent ensemble cast, the film follows the entertwined lives of this little band over a seven year period, 1977 - 1984.  Some people make it, some are shattered, but Paul Thomas Anderson, director and writer, isn't judgemental one way or the other.  Movie-goers are just along for the ride, so get on board, this movie is a real treat.  Rent it at your neighborhood video store.

Review title: Another masterpiece from Paul Thomas Anderson
Review_body: After being stunned by the subtle artistry of Hard Eight everyone knew that Paul Thomas Anderson's sophomoric directorial effort would have to push cinema limits. And boy did it ever. It not only pushed aesthetic limits, but the limits of what you can actually get away with in movies. Boogie Nights is a film set in the 1970's adult film industry. Dirk Diggler wants to be somebody and he gets his chance after finding his way into the porn industry via a director named Jack Horner. Jack is a director with vision and he wants to elevate pornography into an art form rather than just, well... what porn is intended for. The film spans about ten years, chronicling the rise and fall of Dirk Diggler and the various characters he meets along the way. It's a fanatical ensemble piece with all sorts of spunk and nuance to it that sets it apart anything we've ever witnessed.The IMDb page for Boogie Nights wrongly categorizes it as a drama. This film is absolutely a comedy that poses as a drama at times, and it knows it is doing so. You have to face facts. The characters we are involved with here are all sorts of shady people. They are a bunch of sex crazed, coked up, short tempered sociopaths, and thats what makes it all so much fun. There is nothing like watching a coked up Alfred Molina run around in his underwear shooting at Mark Wahlberg and John C. Reily. The film does get dramatic at times, but there is that constant subtle undertone that says, "None of this is really supposed to be taken seriously. It's all for the pure insanity and the fun." Anderson has really done something ingenious with his script here. Jack Horner wants to create pornography with a story in order to draw in his audience in a different kind of way. He wants to enthrall his audience in the story and then entertain them with the porn side. But the result of his aspirations is the most hysterically awful plot lines and characters that you would expect from a porno. And what is even more hilarious is how the talented actors in the film pull off God awful porn acting perfectly. And the great irony of it all is that everyone else in the film is blown away by it and they treat it like master class material. There is a scene at the Adult Film Awards where Dirk Diggler wins multiple awards for his work, while we have just been witnessing how hilariously awful the acting is. The satirical levels on which this story works are just brilliant.But not only does Anderson show off his script writing and story telling abilities in Boogie Nights, he also proves that a great script can be raised to all new heights when it is directed so incredibly well. Anderson's eye for long tracking shots and aesthetically fantastic pans is displayed here in every fashion. The film's opening shot, which starts outside of a night club, follows Jack Horner and his wife in, then proceeds to show many of the main characters in the night club is almost three minutes long. But he doesn't use all of his talent up there. We are treated to plenty more of these brilliant shots throughout the entire two and a half hour film which never gets dull and never lets up on the crazed hilarity.Boogie Nights is a film that is driven so steadfastly well by everything in the film. Anderson's script is fantastic and it tells a wildly entertaining story. His direction moves the film along at a brisk yet deliberate pace which develops every subplot just as fully as the main plot. And he also directs his fantastic actors with the same level of keen poignancy. Every performance in this film is incredible, even the brief cameos from huge names like Phillip Baker Hall or the great Alfred Molina. There's never a dull moment in Boogie Nights, probably due to the fact that every last bit of the film is unlike anything you've ever seen before. Paul Thomas Anderson took some major risks making a film about porn, yet he does it with so much satirical class and hilarious playfulness that it is difficult to dislike the film whether you find the subject matter offensive or not.

Review title: The Three Stooges Go XXX in a Daze
Review_body: BOOGIE NIGHTS starts with virtuoso camera work and goes down hill from there. Loosely based on the career of John Holmes and the erotic film business in general, the film is alternately harsher and gentler than reality.  As a former connoisseur of erotic films, I can tell you MANY of the 35MM erotic films made in the 70s and early 80s are better than BOOGIE NIGHTS.  Even many of the erotic film actresses were better looking than anyone in BOOGIE NIGHTS. I was appalled at how stupid everyone was presented to be.  Anyone who has listened to interview with many of the top flight erotic film stars of that time (Paul Thomas, Ron Jeremy, Annette Haven, John Leslie, Jamie Gillis, Gloria Leonard, Sharon Mitchell, Georgina Spelvin, Harry Rheems) can tell you, "These people are NOT stupid." I did notice a couple of adult film people in this movie. Nina Hartley plays Bill Macy's wife (my, what goshawful makeup! Was that intentional?)Forget the gross errors (Burt Reynolds smoking a cigar near the camera while filming; references to FRESCA, when the product was off the market during those years; Bill Macy's blown line, "My wife has her a** in a d**k").  What about the shot in the bar when the camera is pointed off into space while Reynolds speaks, then pans over to him?  What about the terrible framing on Mark Wahlberg during the ripoff that climaxes the movie?  What about Don Cheadle's horrendous ignorance of stereo, even though he becomes obsessed with selling it? What about the guy telling Wahlberg to "get in his car" when he is driving a pickup?) My gosh, this stuff is amateur night. There IS some things to like in BOOGIE NIGHTS: a great performance by the late Robert Ridgely as Colonel James, and notable performances by Don Cheadle, Burt Reynolds and whomever the actor is who played Reynold's cameraman, as well as really fine period music. Anyone interested in the TRUE story of John Holmes (far more horrific than BOOGIE NIGHTS) should watch the special on E!  But I would like to make two points before I close. The box score on erotic film stars is not good.  Many die in their 30s.  The primary causes of death appear to be (in order) suicide, drug overdose, cancer and AIDS.  Second, does anyone besides me care that civil liberatarians seem more interested in cable TV and adult magazines for prisoners than whether prisoners are raped, brutalized or murdered by other prisoners?  I bring up that point because that appears to be the fate of one of the characters in the movie.

Review title: A gutsy effort... and extremely well-made.
Review_body: P.T. Anderson's Boogie Nights is basically a character study of porn industry participants between the years of 1977-1984. We see much of the film through the eyes of a young man who takes the industry by storm at the tender age of 17. We see his rise during the care-free innocence of the later 70s and we witness him bottom out in the early 80s.
