We are also introduced to several other performers, filmmakers, hangers on, and criminals. Cocaine seems to be the catalyst behind much of the action. This type of film might have been laughable if made by a director with less talent, but Anderson's unique style and skills make it a winner.Mark Wahlberg plays our young stud who takes the name of "Dirk Diggler". He's apparently a high school dropout with an enormous penis who catches the attention of a porn director played by Burt Reynolds. Wahlberg's performance begins as properly understated, then seems to grow with the character. Reynolds hasn't been this good since Smokey and the Bandit. The rest of the cast reads like a "who's who" of the more respected actors of our day. Don Cheadle is outstanding as a young man who takes pride in his "acting", but really wants to open up a stereo store more than anything else. Julianne Moore is is also very good as the maternal figure of the troupe who has basically adopted the younger actors as her own children to replace her real son lost in a custody dispute. There is simply not enough space here to give credit to everyone who acted superbly in this film.Anderson's skill with the camera is on display in numerous shots. Many have been used elsewhere, but he knows how to work them into his story. Many of the scenes take place in crowded rooms or at parties where all kinds of interesting things are going on. His technique often takes us from one room to another, then perhaps outside so we don't miss a thing. The use of soundtrack is perhaps the best of any film I've ever seen. In fact, it IS the best. With so many great songs of the period at his disposal, he works two discs worth into the story. Nothing seems excessive or out of place.If one fault can be found with this film, then I would have to say it would be too much violence in the last half hour. Any industry that deals in sex and drugs to that extent is bound to encounter violence in some circles, but Boogie Nights over does it. I counted no less than five extremely bloody scenes. In one, a VERY young woman overdoses on coke and breaks a blood vessel in her nose. There are several gunshot victims. But the most over-the-top scene would have to be the one where Heather Graham stomps on the head of a young man with her roller skates. The manner in which she comes in contact with him is contrived to the point of hysteria, then the scene ends in such a brutal assault that you'll hardly be able to control your skepticism. The fact that the consequences of the assault are not even revealed to the audience (at least not in any version of the film I've seen) makes you wonder why Anderson thought to include it at all. It was just a means for the young woman to get some revenge on a guy who made fun of her way back in high school. Nothing more.The film lacks any scene which inspires any true sexual feeling from anyone I've ever talked to. This was indeed intended. The sex in the film is all about business, though Graham's brief nude scene was well appreciated. The film is also lacking in any kind of judgment or moral lesson. We are merely introduced to these characters, then we see what happens to them. Despite a near documentary point of view, the film never bogs down or fails to keep one's interest. The film didn't make that much money, but it has earned the distinction of being one of the better films made in the 1990s. A reputation well-deserved.9 of 10 stars from The Hound.

Review title: Thomas Anderson staked his claim to auteur status with his ambitious pornography and family epic Boogie Nights.
Review_body: A boyish young waiter (Mark Wahlberg) makes it big as a performer in the adult film industry of the 1970s, only to succumb to excess a decade later. Although fictional, the film is based on a number of real porn actors and films from that era, and it features several cameos by real porn stars.Director Paul Thomas Anderson announced himself in sensational style with a sub-cultural epic that (un)covers both porn's heyday and its demise into videotaped product throughout the 1980s. With half-a-dozen or so performances that might have won Oscars were the clips not so R-rated, it's surprisingly sweet in its portrayal of an extended family of porno-folk, while never far from harsh truths about human desires.
Based on an adult short documentary!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Review title: No effects nor action, but still pretty good
Review_body:
This is one of the few movies, that succeed in entertaining without having to fall back on monstrous effects or a lot of shooting and I really admire all the people who worked on this film for that. Nowadays that is hard to come by I mean look at the most successful movie of that year 1997 and what do you get Titanic (effects), JP:2 (effects), MIB (effects), Tomorrow Never Dies (action), Air Force One (effects) and then comes the first one that does not have effects nor a lot of action and that's As Good as it Gets. You see my point here either there is a lot of action, effects or comedy in a film, otherwise it is not good (at least at the box  office) and that is why this one did not get huge sums into the cash register. OK this is maybe not as good as Titanic and some of the others, but I think you can watch movies like this more often than for example MIB or Air Force One, which are enjoyable at the cinema and then become boring fast. Still this is not a great film, but who am I to be the judge of that ? See for yourselves, but I know not many 155 minute films with so few action scenes are this good. Not a giant, not a small, but a deserved
7 out of 10

The director and much of the cast are also responsible for Magnolia so it's not surprising this is a great movie. The film follows the film career of Dirk Digler and is apparently loosely based on the life of the porn star John Holmes. Although not quite as disturbing as 8mm this certainly shows the dangers of being sucked into the world of porn. The people that make the money from porn ruthlessly exploit the people that star in the movies. Why Burt Reynolds didn't win an oscar for his performance is a mystery. Other notable performances are turned in by Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, John C Reilly, William H Macy and Mark Wahlberg, but that isn't surprising as these are some of the finest character actors plying their trade in Hollywood. For anybody who just wants to see what all the fuss is about, just watch the last 30 seconds and apparently it's not Mark Wahlberg !

Paul Thomas Anderson's epic film about the origin, rise and fall of fictitious porn star Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg) is an incredible contribution to film, hands down.  While many of his `regular' actors (Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Phillip Baker Hall and Ricky Jay among them) are excellent actors in their own right, he squeezes hilarious, ironic and gut-wrenching performances from them. Probably the most effective performance of course is by Mark Wahlberg. While this was not his first film, it was his first starring role and when the film was over he was `Marky-Mark' no more.  A lot has been said about this film, and there are far too many reasons to mention to illustrate why this film has very solidly remained in my top 15 favorite films of all time, but one scene I would like to mention is the scene near the end of the film between Wahlberg, Reilly, Thomas Jane and Alfred Molina.  Set in Molina's living room and involving a drug deal, Anderson directs this scene with such incredible finesse that it goes down in history as one of the greatest moments in the last thirty years of film. Between the palpable tension, the brilliant choice of music and the unbelievable acting by the primaries, this scene is important to watch more than once to experience how a scene should be written and blocked to tell a story with both unflinching imagery and subtlety at the same time.  I will see a mediocre movie and then put on this scene after to renew my faith in *good* filmmaking.This is obviously not a film for everyone due to its subject matter, but it is such an incredible and important film, it should not be overlooked.--Shelly

Review title: Smart and original script - that runs out of stream early
Review_body: Life and times of the 1970's porn setWhatever you say about Paul Thomas he is original. Who else would make a drama about the heyday of porn and cast Burt Reynolds as the lead? Not me, that's for sure.Despite what you imagine you don't see a lot of sex in this movie. And most of the sex you do see is cold and mechanical and not at all lovely. Wahlberg is fine as the young slow witted stud who is transported from dishwasher to stardom - only to come apart.(How much this is acting and how much is the real Wahlberg I couldn't tell you.)Reynolds is a revelation - the man can act. And even more surprises, he plays a porn director with a heart! The problem with this film is that having set the scene (and very well it is done) there is nothing left but to tear the scene apart. The movie is almost perfectly 50 percent good time - 50 percent hard times. Sliced right through the middle.The dialogue is good, but not good enough to heard twice and the whole thing slides away in to morals (people in porn have a stigma, remember) and murder. Fun while the fun lasts, but draggy when it ends.

Review title: One of the best DRAMA movies ever!
Review_body: Great drama film that is so flawless that it is definitely on the top ten list of all time great DRAMA movies.No weakness here and even to the naysayers who say that it was a tag too long,I must say that the extra minutes were truly a treat for every minute of this film was precious and essential to it's totality.I'm happy for REYNOLD'S performance here.Hopefully more films will come about like this one.Better than PULP FICTION!Better than GOODFELLAS!Better than SNATCH!Realistic movie fan's dream!Up there with GODFATHER and SCARFACE and GONE WITH THE WIND.That good.NOT FOR CLOSE MINDED PEOPLE........

Review title: One of the best films about porn.
Review_body: This film left me breathless. It was so good that I watched it several times over.It is rare that film industry makes a film about porn film industry. They usually do not like each other. Better to say "regular" film industry looks down on porn film industry. When I wanted to study movie directing, now famous film director Jasmila Zbanic said that I can not study since I watch too much porn???!!!??? First of all how did she find out that? Well I assume because Sarajevo was during my teen years and still is such a small town that all the owners of the VHS rentals of those times knew each other and shared information of customers interests. Zbanic owned one of the VHS rental places but she never had porn films for rent. Her mother was a big Muslim believer and she would not permit anything of that in her store. I rented those films from a different VHS rental places and she still found out. So to make the long story short twists and turns of history turned us so Zbanic became award winning film director, while I hm, became a IMDb amateur reviewer.I am so glad Ron Jeremy contributed to this film, he is such a great guy! I met him once briefly, very nice guy. Philip Seymour acted in this film. One more time R.I.P.Now this is a must see! Film portrays adult film industry well. It is very entertaining and full of interesting and funny twists and turns. No wonder it received so many awards, it really deserves. So if you did not have a chance to see it yet please find it somewhere and watch it!

1997 seemed to have an unusually high number of top notch films, and it's too bad that this one often got lost in the shuffle when it was time to hand out some hardware.  This was a terrific film in every way, and although I found it to be a little long, it was worth the effort to sit through the rare slow spot.  The ending was particularly entertaining, as it had an intensity that really got my heart pumping.  But even when the film had a more leisurely pace, it was no less compelling, thanks to an intelligent script and an outstanding ensemble cast.  And of course, the best thing about this movie was Burt Reynolds, who finally got some well-deserved respect.

Review title: A 2h 1/2 gracious limp jumping over 8 years in the porn industry
Review_body: I've seen 2 other movies by P.T. Anderson, Magnolia and There will be blood. All three are brilliantly crafted but disturbingly empty while the story lingers on and revels in distressing characters. So my opinion is P.T. Anderson should not write and be content with directing movies. As such it feels like a man-who-thinks-he-is-an-artist's work, with a lot of self-indulgence for the subject matter, and very little substance.In Boogie Nights the pornography business is seen as a nice family, with some occasional violence and an increasing drug consumption. Actually it could have been about a rock band or small time drug dealers. The pornography industry may be fascinating from the outside but it is more about people living from day to day and is thus not the least interesting, especially with the un-gritty look and feel P.T. Anderson gives his movie.Poor boy Dirk Diggler and his friends are neither bad nor nice, nor clean, not dirty. What they do has no meaning (sure, they are living from day to day) and they learn nothing, build nothing. OK some just happen to suddenly disappear in the process while one of them eventually gets a wife, a baby and the money to settle a 'real' business. Nobody's saved, nobody's doomed, everybody is just normal people: who cares about a movie like that? It is just episode after episode, starting 1977 and ending 1984, a patchwork of anecdotes making up for a story: style shall never be an excuse.

Who would have thought Paul Thomas Anderson could have created the masterpiece of porn? 'Boogie Nights' is a superb effort in directing. It is a fully realized and brilliant film. What I admire most about Anderson's vision is the scope. He has created a fully constructed world and placed well rounded and interesting characters to inhabit it. The dialogue has spunk and bite and the picture is perfectly casted.Sex is hard to make a picture about, pure and simple. What makes 'Boogie Nights' a masterpiece in my opinion is that it portrays sex in such a blunt way. Whatever sense of spiritualism and individuality achieved through sex is completely gone from these characters. They merely go through the motions. If I had to choose a central motif of what Anderson tries to convey in this picture it would be the dehumanization of sex. Julianne Moore, who gives the finest performance of her career as Amber Waves, has a brilliant moment in the film when she first experiences 'penetration' with 'Dirk Diggler'. She asks Wahlberg's character to come inside her. I'm actually somewhat taken back from having to write this down but this is the crucial moment of the film. There is a line between bodily fluids and seed and 'Boogie Nights' plays with that line, debates it.One thing about 'Boogie Nights' though is that it doesn't damn the porno industry, nor should it. The Burt Reynolds character Jack Horner is brilliantly written and has clearly understandable motives. He views himself as an artist and why shouldn't he? One person's porn is another person's art. There is some sympathy to be felt when Horner's craft becomes nothing more than home videos. To go from the glory of celluloid to fuzzy home video is a long fall. Horner is in his own delusional world and is brought out in an extremely well crafted scene. Horner says that he will find the next adult film star on video tape. The scene leads to a rape of the adult film star 'Rollergirl' on fuzzy scratchy tape. It isn't art and it isn't 'sexy'.'Diggler' is nothing more than a stupid prop in these porn films. He didn't get to where he was with his acting skills. He has one thing in the world and it really is fascinating how Paul Thomas Anderson creates a character around that notion. 'Diggler' has to be a thoughtless tank for the picture to work. He has to have the base animal instincts of what sex is. It makes the picture all the more tragic for 'Diggler' to truly grasp even the slightest bits of maturity through whoring himself out. 'Diggler' is forced to go through hell. Anderson is blatant in his subtleties about what plaque 'Diggler' and his sex life. The character isn't really complete until the moment when he is paid next to nothing to jack off in a car. In many ways 'Boogie Nights' is a tragic film but I think it's more than that. It has an extremely satisfying conclusion where 'Diggler' questions his existence and his role in life better than almost any cinematic character that preceded him.

"Boogie Nights" is the feature film debut of Paul Thomas Anderson, the young writer/director who has in the past decade taken the independent film circuit by storm to the acclaim of critics and audiences alike. If this sounds like Quentin Tarantino (albeit half a decade later), it's not meant to. "Boogie Nights" isn't as strong of a film as "Resevoir Dogs," but it's close.Calling Anderson's film a Hollywood story isn't really truthful (the film revolves around the pornography business), but it follows a more-or-less similar plot trajectory to any "rise and fall of a star in showbusiness." In this case, the film revolves around Eddie Adams, a seventeen year old who is spotted by hotshot porn director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds). After agreeing to "act" in one of Jack's films, Eddie, now known as Dirk Diggler, becomes an instant sensation and becomes king of the porn film industry. But with every rise there is a fall, and it's usually much harder than the rise to stardom.Actually, "Boogie Nights" is more than a biography. It's about a group of friends and coworkers who work together making pornographic films. Dirk is clearly the center of the film, but the other characters are not forgotten. The other characters are given due attention to their own little dramas. This is the film's biggest problem; there's way too much of it, and it causes the film to drag. In fact, many of these characters could have been written out entirely.The acting is outstanding all around. Mark Wahlberg is not an actor with a broad range. But even though he had to wait nine more years for an Oscar nomination, this is his best performance. At the beginning, Eddie is innocent and eager to please. But as he becomes Dirk, his ego gets inflated, and drugs start to take hold. Burt Reynolds is brilliant as Jack. For once, the big Hollywood type is not a sleazebag who would throw someone out on the street once they stopped making money. He's a father figure to Dirk, and although in the beginning his world seems brimmed with danger and uncertainty, but Jack's warmth makes it feel homey after a while. The rest of the cast is great as well: special acclaim has to go to Julianne Moore (has she ever given a bad performance?), Don Cheadle, and John C. Reilly.Paul Thomas Anderson is unquestionably a filmmaker, not a movie director. His style and his technique show a much greater skill than something you would see in a given movie at the multiplexes. He has a keen eye for detail (the setting is impeccable), and he makes sure that each shot is perfect. Not everything he does is perfect (the film needed a better editor-many scenes run for too long, and some just don't need to be there), but what is there is very good.

Review title: A wild ride of a movie!
Review_body: It's hard to know where to begin with writing thoughts about Boogie Nights. It's epic in so many ways and crams a lot into its 2.5 hour runtime - most of which is awesome.You can't help but get caught up in the infectious party atmosphere of the late 70s setting. The fashion, the lifestyles, the music, the sex, the drugs. It's all here in large amounts. The soundtrack for Boogie Nights is one of the best you'll come across.It features so many big name actors delivering some of their best performances at once. The characters are unique, real and often quite likeable. Drugs, guns, sex, violence, darkness, humour - there's really a bit of everything here for everyone.Burt Reynolds was perfectly cast in his role as Jack Horner. Mark Wahlberg delivered his best career performance and made his character surprisingly likeable. I think I fell in love with Julianne Moore in this - her intimate scenes with Wahlberg were standouts. William H Macy, Don Cheadle and Philip Seymour Hoffman through in ample doses of hilarity whenever they were on screen too.Many memorable moments, and at the same time a complete blur too - which is fitting for the time and place it's set. Recommend. It was a good time and wild ride!

Review title: Epic tale of world of porn
Review_body: This is a absolutely masterful stroke of genius by Paul Thomas Anderson the writer/director of this movie.  It really examines the pluses and minuses of the world of porn and consequences for your actions living in a world literally fueled by sex, drugs, and rock n' roll.  Only of the finest casts assembled with Mark Wahlberg, Burt Reynolds, Heather Graham, Julianne Moore, William H. Macy, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Don Cheadle, Philip Baker Hall, and others.

Boogie Nights is a very well done film from a young film-maker. Paul Thomas Anderson has crafted a great character driven story and set it in the porn industry. It reminded me of Robert Altman's style and was very impressive from a young director. The movie is casted perfect and the editing was well done. The movie is kinda downbeat, but it was an entertaining trip to the end.

If you want to get transported to the late 70s/early 80s and absolutely enthralled for two and a half hours, this is one to look up. There are so many good performances in this film it's hard to point out just one (Reynolds, Wahlberg, Hoffman, and Reilly spring to mind). PTA perfects the art of the single shot tracking sequence with some of the most impressive shots I have ever seen on film. The music choices are on point throughout as well. Above all, this film is just a well-crafted, absorbing journey through a crazy time period.

Review title: One of the best films of 1997!
Review_body: I rented Boogie Nights last week and I could tell you, when I watched the film I had a blast. If you think that when you watch the film you will get sicked by the porn. I mean yes, if your not a porn person who can't bother being by it, than this isn't the film to see. But the thing is, the whole film isn't really about porn. Well halfway through the film is about the porn industry but the other half is about the character development and the bad situations these characters go through. The actors played there roles perfect, especially Mark Wahlberg, John C. Reilly, and William H. Macy. The sex scenes, of course are terrific but mainly focus on the character's hype in porn films until there struggles. Excellent film, one of the best! Hedeen's Outlook: 10/10 **** A+

Boogie Nights is one of those few movies that can take a difficult subject and do something with it that most people can watch and appreciate. The porn-industry is a mess in more ways than one and there is much to criticize, and i know this movie has been considered to glorify the business. Something i don't agree with.The story about Dirk Diggler and his exploding porn-career in the late 1970's - early 1980's bears considerable similarity with that of John Holmes and the fact that Holmes has been an inspiration is obvious. The thing i most appreciated about this movie is the way that it shows both sides of the business. At first the upside where the young kid is introduced to a world of sex, drugs and rich friendly people. Then later the backside with crime, abuse and crashed lives. And it's all done with an excellent mix of comedy and drama as well as a distinct feeling when it comes to style. Visual as well as otherwise.Despite being a movie about the porno business, Boogie Nights is not very explicit. A correct choice in my opinion since more explicit scenes wouldn't have added to the movie, rather it would instead have run the risk of feeling like exploitation. Paul Thomas Anderson is a talented director and he manages to balance many talented actors in a good way while still letting it be his more than their film. Also i don't know what he did with Mark Wahlberg, but suddenly he could act! I don't like Wahlberg at all otherwise but here even he performed well.Boogie Nights is well worth seeing even if you completely despise the porno industry. There is room for more than one opinion here and Anderson doesn't really state his own. I rate this 7/10.

Review title: Jon Monsarrat review: movie about misery, lacking nudity
Review_body: Can we talk? Really talk?I figured this might be a good film to watch for some nude scenes. Sort of like "Striptease", which delivered plenty... er, so I am told.It is a story about how the porn film industry, while it has an air of festivity and fun, is actually loathsome, destroys people's lives, and is generally miserable. Well, guess what. The characters in the film are loathsome, their lives get destroyed, and it made me fell as miserable as watching the downward spiral in "Leaving Las Vegas" (where at least the characters were interesting and well-acted).I was not looking for a good story, good acting, good much of anything. But the film was STILL awful, and at rock bottom a movie about porn should have had more than few seconds of nudity. (There is a quick shot of Heather Graham.)Who should see this film:-- Nobody, even if you think you might want to.I'll give "Boogie Nights" a generous 2 out of 10 for Heather Graham's sake.

Paul Thomas Anderson is renowned for making weighty films filled with masterful directing, writing and acting. There Will Be Blood (my first taste of PTA) almost immediately became one of my top five favourites, resembling one of Stanley Kubrick's very best. I gave Magnolia a watch more recently and the whole thing astounded me with its emotional depth and richness. I'd been saving up Boogie Nights as many consider it Paul's greatest film. At a mere 26 years old, he created a critically-acclaimed masterpiece that blew his debut (which is still a pretty good film) out of the water. I couldn't wait to give Boogie Nights a watch and it didn't disappoint.I know it's not a popular opinion, but I still think There Will Be Blood and Magnolia are far better than Boogie Nights. However, that just shows how talented our Paul is as a filmmaker because Boogie Nights is a seriously terrific achievement right from the opening sombre music. We're then hit immediately by a blasting 70's pop track and a sweeping camera which takes us into the mind of Madonna when she was working on Confessions on a Dancefloor. A beautiful retro disco with all the main characters being introduced with perfect camera timing I don't know how Paul managed to do it but it's a fantastic piece of camera-work and it almost feels as though he's showing off a bit.The film is a rags to riches tale, with more than a touch of irony to it, of a young and naïve dishwasher who's whisked away by Burt Reynolds to become the biggest porn star there's ever been! The first half is the more entertaining and funny half. It's full of infectious energy and memorable characters who jump off the screen. For a film about the porn industry, there's surprisingly little smut aside from an extended sequence where Mark Whalberg films his first sex scene with Julianne Moore. It's extremely lively and full of fab scenes such as another impressive Steadicam move around a pool party and a fun montage showing Dirk Diggler's rise to pornographic stardom.The darker, second half is the more interesting one for me. We're suddenly plunged into the 80's and watch as everyone's lives go spiralling towards hell. The once friendly Dirk has turned into an egotistical cocaine-addict and Burt Reynolds has become a desperate director pimping his surrogate daughter out to strangers on the street. It's a sad chapter which adds weight and morality to the tale. The film could've been a terrific comedy in the vein of the Wolf of Wall Street, but the second half offers a lovely bleak balance and shows us that pornography is not an industry to aspire to get into. The seemingly fulfilled characters become much deeper and more tragic figures.There are some lovely scenes. One sequence which I really loved was a montage where all the characters are at their lowest. The music suited the scene so well and it felt very unsettling and intense. I also liked the moment where we're given a glimpse into Julianne Moore's life as she discusses getting custody of her child with her ex-husband. The film stops being fun and starts to become a much more serious beast set in a real world more closer to our own. Boogie Nights handles its many characters so expertly, kind of in the same way Magnolia did, although to a slightly lesser extent.Just when you think the film can't throw up any more brilliance, the best scene pops up towards the end. It involves Dirk's pathetic gang trying to orchestrate a drug deal at Alfred Molina's house. Everything about this scene is pretty much perfect from the acting to the music to the tense, unpredictable atmosphere. Even the firecrackers are a masterstroke! It erupts into a Quentin Tarantino styled shootout and the unpredictability of it all makes for a thrilling watch. In fact, the entire film is filled with so many terrific scenes that it makes for a very high rewatchability factor.My only complaint would be that, like Dirk's manhood, it's quite overlong. I think I would've preferred more of a focus on the 80's segment rather than the 70's. However, Boogie Nights is still a really great film. The thing that stands out the most is the masterful directing by the young Paul Thomas Anderson. Some argue that it's a Martin Scorsese rip-off but I'd argue that his style is even better than Martin Scorsese. It's a fantastic ride which leaves you with a lot to ponder about. So get your glad rags on and hit the dancefloor kids!

Review title: It Ain't Called Boogie Nights for Nothing
Review_body: For more than 20 years, Paul Thomas Anderson has proven to be quite the unique filmmaker for his themes of alienation and loneliness, flawed characters, and distinct visual styles. So it's no surprise that I'd be discussing the film that helped kickstart his claim to fame, Boogie Nights. Although the title might suggest a film about disco, do not be fooled, for this is more about the pornography industry. In spite of such a crazy idea for a film, it actually works well in its favor, because a film like this could not have worked well enough without a little bit of craziness.The movie centers around a teenage busboy named Eddie Adams, who gets discovered by porn director Jack Horner and becomes a world famous adult-film star, Dirk Diggler. Despite succeeding in flying colors, Dirk begins to develop a severe ego and drug problem, which results in his downfall. Admittedly, the story itself is the typical underdog turned superstar plot where a nobody is turned into a somebody overnight but then enters a decline due to certain issues, making the viewing experience a little predictable. However, what elevates the film from its premise is how it depicts the porn business. As the film is set in the late 70s and early 80s, it displays a certain nostalgic representation of how the industry was when it came to classic exotic features. By depicting the business side of these movies, the viewing experience is set more in the shadows than the spotlight, and it's admirable to see the behind the scenes debacles of porno filmmaking.In terms of characters, Eddie is a pretty good representation of aspiring low-key actors who let their career get the best of them, and Mark Wahlberg carries enough charisma to make him charmingly energized in spite of his shortcomings. However, the character who steals the show is Jack Horner. Played wonderfully by Burt Reynolds (may he rest in peace), the man presents himself as sort of a father figure for a bizarre family of porn stars, yet he often seems more subdued with the idea of it, down to never shown having sex himself. In addition, Amber Waves is a former housewife turned porn star who is in desperate need of seeing her child again, and Julianne Moore is able to carry as much sympathy towards her character as she does with her seductive presence. Whenever Amber is with Eddie, she practically becomes a mother figure towards him, even becoming generally concerned for him during their sex scenes.Despite being about adult features, Anderson cleverly limits the nudity in the film, making the reveal of Eddie's dynamite dong all the more surprising. It's often funnier when you approach things like that subtly without revealing much, and the film takes full advantage of that, including a particular scene at a pool party where Dirk shows the financer of the features his thing offscreen for only a few seconds. My only main complaint with the film is the few subplots revolving around the supporting cast. I understand the influence of Nashville and Pulp Fiction with the variety of characters displaying differentiating human qualities in a louche world, but I personally found them to be a tad distracting and rather fluctuating in pace. Then again, at the end of the day, this film is about the fluctuating unpredictabilities that life can offer in such an infamous industry, so I suppose it fits within the context of the story.We'll probably never get another movie like this again, and we don't need to. Overall, Boogie Nights is a great commentary on the adult-film business that paints itself with a bizarre story about the crazy ups and downs of making a living, a cast of highly flawed albeit understanding characters, and a wonderful tribute to the glory days of porno. If you're into films that beautifully explore and comment on a particular subject of art and film, then this is just for you. Although given its subject matter and dark content, just be warned that this is not a movie for the sensitive viewers. If there's one thing you will get out of this movie though, it's that those who live by the sword also die by it, because people like Dirk Diggler may end up selling their dignity for the right and wrong reasons.

Review title: A period piece that's fun, atmospheric and expertly made
Review_body: Paul Thomas Anderson is a director I have a lot of praise for. I thought Phantom Thread was great and I really loved Punch-Drunk Love. Boogie Nights is one of his best.Boogie Nights focuses on the porn industry during the late 70s to 80s and takes us through a range of characters involved the line of work.Paul Thomas Anderson's examination of this industry and the period it's set in is a winner all the way. There's so much to appreciate and so much fun to be had with Boogie Nights. The opening scene alone had me hooked and transported me to its flashy and glamourous world. The use of long takes during some scenes tell me so much about the time period and the lifestyle these people lived. Despite this being Anderson's second feature, he displays a lot of confidence behind the camera by capturing the spirit of the 70s and 80s in great detail. This is a very atmospheric film where you soak in the beauty of the scenery. The soundtrack is easily one of my favourite aspects. Not only did it sound great but it contributed so much to the mood of each scene. The song choices fit extremely well for the time period and the variety of them kept me entertained and engrossed throughout. The camerawork is slick and stylish. There are incorporations of various long takes with action taking place at every corner which is not only impressive but also purposeful in terms of developing its characters and worldbuilding.For its subject matter, Paul Thomas Anderson manages to handle it in a very smart and mature manner. For a film about the porn industry, the film wasn't as sexual as I thought it was going to be. The second half of the film takes a much more dark turn which I didn't expect. The script is fantastic in every way. Dialogue plays a large role in the film and some of them are really funny. Anderson introduces us to memorable characters with interesting personalities. We learn more and more about them as the film goes on. The darker second half plays a great contrast to the first as it peels back the glamour and shows us how troubled these people really are. The acting by everyone involved and Anderson's direction helps us identify with these people during their highs and lows.Mark Wahlberg in his breakout role delivers one of his performances here. His character goes through a range of emotions and Wahlberg proves himself to be a worthy actor by conveying that range brilliantly. There is one scene however where Wahlberg argues with his mum and the acting seemed a tad off then but he did really well during the rest of the film. Burt Reynolds is amazing here and is one of the standout performers in the film. Julianne Moore and Heather Graham are also terrific. John C. Reilly surprised me by how good he was. I've gotten used to seeing him as more of a comedic actor but there are a handful of serious scenes where he shines. I loved Philip Seymour Hoffman here. He's consistently impressed me and once again he shows how good of an actor he is. Don Cheadle is also great here. The entire ensemble cast bring their A game here.I cannot wait to see Boogie Nights again. It's a very entertaining period piece that captures the industry and time period with immense detail. There are many memorable scenes and characters that are fun to watch and go through a rollercoaster of emotions. Paul Thomas Anderson demonstrates his skill and talent as writer and director once again and I hope he continues making great films like this.

Review title: Is this what the fuss was all about?
Review_body: This film is awful. I cannot believe that so many people thought it was wonderful. Trite and ponderous with few likable characters it seems to me to be floundering in its attempt to portray the 70's. Mark Wahlberg is an OK actor but does not convince in this and as as for it being a glimpse of Burt Reynolds best work I will stick with Deliverance for that. A good cast has been tragically wasted in a movie which should have been better written and edited. The constant music soundtrack of 70's hits does not make it any more authentic- feeling. It really just goes to show that actors are only really as good as the scripts they are given to work with and the direction they are given.

BOOGIE NIGHTSThis was a funny movie.The story is about the rise and fall of Dirk Diggler. A guy who washed glasses in a nightclub until he is spotted by a porn movie director. Dirk then goes into the porn industry and his life gets turned upside down.It is a very entertaining story and very easy to follow. I would say this movie was a comedy. There were a lot of funny moments in it, as well as other serious moments, which gave it an element of drama.The cast list was amazing. I knew a few of these people were in it, but I didn't realise this many famous people were acting in it. The film starred Mark Wahlberg, the legendary Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, John C. Reilly, Don Cheadle, William H. Macy & Phillip Seymour Hoffman.Everyone did an amazing job. It is not surprising that this film and the actors were nominated for so many awards, and even won a lot too.It felt like a bit or a roller coaster of a film. The emotions of the movie were all over the place. One minute I was laughing, then something would happen and it just shocked me. The drama kicked in... but then the comedy would come back.The film was set in the 70s and 80s... the clothes and hair was great. and the film also has a pretty good soundtrack.There was a lot of nudity in the film too. I don't know why I was surprised at this. After all, the film is about the porn industry... but for some reason I was shocked to see all these Hollywood actors and actresses flashing it all... and as for Mark Whalberg... he wishes his dong was that big! haha. Apparently, the fake willy that you saw at the end of the movie was given to Mark Wahlberg when filming was finished... he still owns it to this day... but it is not in the same condition anymore. haha.I will give this film 7 out of 10.I really liked it, and it really put me in a time machine and took me back to the 70s/80s. :)For more reviews, please like my Facebook page:https://www.facebook.com/pages/Ordinary-Person-Movie- Reviews/456572047728204?ref=hl

Review title: A Fine Film, Not His Best
Review_body: BOOGIE NIGHTS is a good movie about the adult film industry in the 1970's. It's portrayal of those films is fairly realistic. Some people will love this movie and some will hate it based on the subject matter alone.I thought it was very well done, as I've come to expect from director Paul Thomas Anderson. It's not his best work, but it is certainly good and intriguing. Even at more than two and a half hours it doesn't seem a bit too long. The story and the acting are wonderful. Burt Reynolds gives a terrific performance. Recommend to all but those who would be offended by the topic.

Review title: Excellent film about industry I don't care for
Review_body: I've only seen one or two porn films, enough to make me know I don't want to see another one, and yet I enjoyed this movie quite a bit.  Although it's set in the porn film industry, in a surprising way it's more about the extended family that develops among all these people who work together, and how things like drugs, fame, and money may have stretched those bonds, but not broken them completely (except for William H. Macy's character).  Another nice thing is how much affection Anderson has for these people, even when he acknowledges some of the bad things they may do (like how Dirk acts like a jerk because of his ego).  And the use of period music was inventive, like the 80's songs during the scene with Alfred Molina, which add to the tension of the scene.I wasn't a fan at all of Mark Wahlberg until he turned to acting, and then he started to show some talent, especially in this movie.  He acts on everything he feels as if it just occurred to him.  I'm also not a fan of Burt Reynolds, but he comes through here, because he doesn't condescend to the movie.  But of all the cast (who are really good), it's Julianne Moore who stands out, playing, in effect, the den mother, who is looked up to by her co-stars, but can't get custody of her own children.  She also pulls off the difficult trick of playing a bad actress, and she's the most convincing at it.

The best thing about this film is without a doubt the cast: Heather Graham, Julian Moore and Burt Reynolds are great, Don Cheadle brilliant (as he usually is) in his small role as Buck Swope and Mark Wahlberg is fantastic.The movie is also good, even though it seems to go on for maybe half an hour too long. But the characters are interesting, and so is the story and I found that I was very entertained and interested almost all the time. Boogie Nights is a funny, clever, touching, and really rather sad movie about the world of pornography.

If you want to have a look at the 70s, here is a movie for you. The atmosphere is perfect. If you're interested in the sex industry of the era, here is a perfect movie for you. A realistic approach to the lives of the stars of the genre. This is so well done you may feel like being there with the guys. Great cinema!

Review title: Let's get one thing out of the way before discussing Boogie Nights. Yes, it is a prosthetic device. Ah, the wonders of make-up.
Review_body: Mark Wahlberg plays Eddie, a well-endowed teenage busboy in a San Fernando Valley nightclub. One night he is discovered by blue-movie director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds). Jack takes one look at Eddie's unwrapped package and, presto, a huge star is born. Eddie assumes a nom de porn, Dirk Diggler, and the "acting" jobs start coming his way. His own family life is far from ideal, so Eddie/Dirk is more than happy to move in with his surrogate parents, Jack and Amber (Julianne Moore). Amber, as in Amber Waves, is a porn star and the mother figure little Dirkie needs. He even gets to sleep with her. Soon the '70s become the '80s and the heavy drugs start taking their toll. Video has changed the porn business forever and Dirk's enormous, uh, ego has become even more engorged. Bad times are a-coming. Ambitious young studs are being groomed to take the star's place. Must he resort to hustling? Can he keep performing on cue? By 1983, poor Diggler's just one more limp Dirk. All of this sounds pretty lurid, but young director Paul Thomas Anderson keeps the heady material from dragging us down with the characters. It is all surprisingly buoyant and, at times, even affecting. Boogie Nights does take an awfully long time (152 minutes) to reach a climax. Some serious issues get the skin-deep treatment, but a more diverting R-rated fairy tale would be hard to find. The cast is near perfect. Reynolds has never been better and former underwear pinup Wahlberg shows that there is plenty to life after Calvin. Moore scores the most emotional moments, while sterling support is provided by Don Cheadle, Heather "Rollergirl" Graham, William H. Macy, Phillip Seymour Hoffman and Alfred Molina. The disco-heavy soundtrack is a treasure trove that will have you shaking your own groove thing, prosthetic or real.

Someone once told me that when looking at old photographs and portraits they could not help but think the people in them were dead and that this was a funny feeling. Well, I'd imagine that looking at porn from the 1970s and early 1980s would give the same feeling. This film is like a long, continuous reel of behind-the-scenes footage from old pornos  there are long-drawn shots, shaky and intimate camera movement and it all presents a very 'objective' view of its subject, eliminating the narrator factor in the product.It's an enjoyable product too, featuring an impressively cast all-star ensemble as the broken, bruised, decaying 'old' porn-stars, snorting coke and not really giving a damn about anything besides the art of film-making. Being a portrayal of an era rather than a plot-driven piece, there is really not much else to the story than that, unless you want to count Dirk Diggler's (Mark Wahlberg) claim to fame in the adult industry. "Boogie Nights" is, in spite of its upbeat title, a harrowing film that navigates the themes of decay and out-of-date values. For example, the once big-shot adult-movie director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) is at the height of his career when the film first zooms in on him, but toward the end he is fatally fading which culminates when a frat-boy screams at him: "Your movies are sh it nowadays." He snaps, beats him up, but returns a broken man.Because the film deals with such a 'fun' subject (sex, and the porn industry) in such a tragical way, it manages funny and heartbreaking at the same time. I do not know of many other movies that accomplish this, but "Boogie Nights" perfects it. The scene in which a fantastically broken, defeated and soft-spoken Julianne Moore sits on the bed with Heather Graham  both high as kites, and snorting  and the latter asks her if wants to be her mom, it is a scene so harrowing and simultaneously funny that it's nearly too much to take.The best description I can give of this film is that it is a 2 and a half hours long orgy of sex, drugs and pornstars walking around in a bubble of out-of-touch values, fading fame and a life that will disappoint them. It's well-acted, occasionally poignant and often funny but ultimately it lacks too much direction and a clear sense of point. It leads me to thinking that if you strip it of its sex factor, then would people enjoy this film? For instance, if director Anderson had zoomed in on the car-selling industry during the 1970s-1980s, would we even give a damn? I doubt it.7 out of 10

BOOGIE NIGHTS tells a lie, a big fat whopper of a lie. You know it's lying and it probably knows its lying. But you listen to the lie and are mesmerized by it, because it is a sad, dreamy lie. It's like the uncle who talks about what coulda-shoulda-woulda happened had he not started drinking, or the cousin who wistfully tells of what she plans to do once she wins the lottery. It's a lie you come to believe in because, well, it's just nicer and easier that way.The big lie in BOOGIE NIGHTS is the whole concept of the story. The film is about making porn films in the 1970's. The film somewhat romantically suggests that the ragtag band of filmmakers involved at this one little studio are somehow a family. They also believe they are creating art as pa rt of a family business. The film almost makes you believe it too. The idea that the porn industry is basically opportunistic and exploitive is somehow tucked away in a corner somewhere, vaguely visible, but never pointed out or discussed. To do so would interfere with the sense of community that exists between the characters. And the characters need that feigned innocence in order to justify the way they survive.Don't get me wrong, I have no moral qualms about porn -- to each is own -- but I don't have any delusions either. Porn is a business as cold and impersonal as the sex it depicts. Some pornographic filmmakers may, indeed, take pride in their work and strive to make the best films possible, but that is like striving to make the best hotdog possible. Porn is a product, ground out for fast and easy consumption. And the people who work in porn do it for the money, or to satisfy their own particular sexual kink, or because, well, they haven't anything better to do with their lives. I just don't believe that a life in porn is something anyone aspires to, let alone turns to for social acceptance.But for a few hours watching BOOGIE NIGHTS, you simply accept the lie, just as the characters accept the little lies that make up their lives. You believe Mark Wahlberg's Dirk Diggler really believes the he has found his special place in life by using the special gift God as given him. You believe that Heather Graham's Rollergirl believes that she has attained true stardom. You believe that Julianne Moore's Amber Waves is convinced that you can be a drug using porn star and that shouldn't affect your right to have custody of your children. You believe that Burt Reynolds' Jack Horner truly feels he is making "art" films. Such is the magic web that Paul Thomas Anderson weaves in his long, meandering and amusing slice of the low life.
Alas, reality sets in and naturally things go awry. Everyone must face their lies and the film's characters have to pay. Ironically, the film itself replaces its central lie with an even bigger one: Anderson's Altmanesque epic of off beat reality suddenly gets sidetracked near the end and becomes a Tarantino-like mess of lurid plot twists. The dream world of casual sex becomes an unconvincing nightmare world of violence. The film gains its footing again at the end, but this large chunk of BOOGIE NIGHTS is just unbearably bad. Sex and violence become bedfellows. Anderson loses faith in his lie, just as his characters do.But when it is good -- in a sexually naughty sort of way -- the film is most endearing. Anderson explores a world rarely even acknowledged in polite circles and introduces an intriguing cast of characters. Reynolds possibly gives his best screen performance as the film's father figure and he is backed by a fine cast, especially Wahlberg in the role that moved him into the realm of stardom.A secondary, but relevant, theme in the story is the love of film as a medium. Like ED WOOD and BOWFINGER, BOOGIE NIGHTS celebrates the basic allure of making films, regardless of how questionable the finished movies might be. In a strange way, this is where the film's real honesty lies. A turning point in the film is the realization that film as a community event is fading. Tape and video are forever altering the way films are made and seen. Adult theatres, like the neighborhood movie house, are facing doom as video moves film from the public to the private sector. In wistfully mourning the passing of "classic porn," the film makes a statement about the way technology has demystified cinema: efficient multiplexes have shut down the movie palaces, VCR and DVD changed movie watching from something special to something banal, computer effects are passed off as drama, and anyone with a video camera can be a director.I guess one could be offended that Anderson uses pornography as a metaphor for all that film represents, but then again he wouldn't be the first. But in the end, he uses the alternate universe of the skin trade to make a profound and insightful observation about an art form. What begins as a lie becomes the truth.

Review title: A memorable and well-made "slice of life" film but it lacks a certain, ahem, thrust
Review_body:
I dunno, amidst all its characters and plot lines, in the end it lacks a certain, ahem, thrust, with no clear arc or, heh, climax to speak of (the hypnotic back-and-forth between limo and truck came close but didn't quite land). That said, its "slice of life" structure is certainly done very well, with the majority of its many characters and scenes quite memorable and mull-worthy (Reilly's earnest Reed and the dramatic/comedic drug deal probably top the list). Great music and camerawork too.
7.5/10

Review title: A Filmic Opus by Paul Thomas Anderson
Review_body: Paul Thomas Anderson's 1997 film "Boogie Nights" is a breathtaking ride through seven years in the pornographic film industry. This was a huge undertaking for this filmmaker's sophomore foray into picture making, but as seen with his prior effort, "Hard Eight", he has a knack for garnering career-making performances from his actors and for interweaving story lines on par with Robert Altman. He seems also to have no qualms with wearing his influences on his sleeve, as is clear by the often spoken about three minute long opening shot that hearkens back to Scorsese or DePalma.The film follows the journey of a young man, played by the previously under-appreciated Mark Wahlberg, who yearns for a life beyond his Southern California suburban nowhere. Once he meets up with Burt Reynolds, in the finest performance of his career, and his pseudo-family of skin flick makers and performers, the story is just getting revved up. What follows are two and half hours that wiz by with the deft hand of a filmmaker so attuned to the needs of their story that the frequent subplots and meanderings only add texture and aesthetics to the piece. Though it is basically "42nd Street" with a porn twist, it's surprisingly subdued in its expression of on-screen sex, because the film is about so much more. Although their business is sex and pleasure, it is the variation on the family unit and the hopes and dreams of the characters that are really at the core.Put simply this is brilliant film-making!

I wouldn't know personally but the world of adult films must be a tough life. Sex must lose all its magic and is reduced to a bodily function. Then come the drugs, new "stars" to take your place and loss of self worth since you've given up your humanity.Not a happy future being a piece of meat. Stay in school! LOL.

Review title: Harbinger of the "Go-Go" eighties told through the porn industry
Review_body: AIDS was just beginning to surface.  The "moral majority" had not gained sufficient political strength.  The Mafia was making a killing inventing the home video industry.  And the first "superstars" of porn were coming into the mainstream (Linda Lovelace not withstanding).Lots of money, free sex, a changing technology were all that were needed to burst the balloon that was porn.  The characters of boogie nights were riding the wave until it crashed on the beach.  Although I believe the pressure of having to "perform" probably ate up more promising stars than drugs, I believe this film was an excellent allegory of what was to happened later in the finance industry than what happened in the porn industry.

I must have seen and heard the trailer for Boogie Nights a thousand times. I used to work in a video store in the olden days and its trailer was on a coming attractions VHS playing constantly in the store. I saw the movie as it was released and was floored. I've seen it a bunch of times since then, the last time a couple of days ago.Paul Thomas Anderson released the lackluster Hard Eight just one year earlier, but Boogie Nights feels like it's made by an entirely different director full of confidence.This movie has an amazing energy and is teeming with visual playfulness. It has real characters and great acting all around. I've read about the other actors considered for Dirk Diggler, like DiCaprio and Damon. But they come off as too intelligent. Dirk Diggler has to be a little dim, and in that regard Wahlberg is a perfect fit.It's quite long. I wouldn't have minded if they had tightened the second half dealing with the 1980s.

This was not a bad movie, but not as great as many other reviews I have seen.  The main problem is that the movie tries to make you sympathetic to the characters, but none of the characters are sympathetic.  I mean, it is basically about some people who do a lot of dumb things and suffer the consequences of their actions.  At least in movies like Pulp Fiction or Reservoir Dogs, the characters weren't looking for your sympathy - they were just interesting, unique people in an interesting story.Otherwise, I'm not really sure what the point of this movie is.  Every time I expected some interesting new twist to happen, they went back to the original theme.  Once again I compare: the scene in Pulp Fiction, with Travolta and Jackson and the 3 rip-off kids, with the scene in Boogie Nights where they try to deal the fake drugs.  In Pulp, it has a point.  It adds to the story.  The Boogie Nights scene is interesting, but is really unrelated to the rest of the film.  The whole movie can be described like this - every scene is a mini-movie that does not necessarily have anything to do with the big movie.As far as sex, I'm actually impressed that a movie about pornography had this little sex.  Bachelor Party had as much.  Which is good or bad, depending on what you're looking for :)I gave it 6 of 10.

BOOGIE NIGHTS (dir. Paul Thomas Anderson) This is an unquestionable film classic that concerns a most unusual subject, 'The American Adult Film Industry'. Anderson has directed and written a film of great emotional depth, and the subject of porn is an area where most people would assume that emotions and human feelings are far less important than clothing at a photoshoot. The film boasts a cross section of America's finest character actors, and Anderson took an extremely big chance on a couple of actors who must have seemed like very questionable choices. By the mid 90's when BOOGIE NIGHTS was released, Burt Reynolds tabloid personal life exemplified the most lurid aspects of The Seventies, and his inclusion in the film might have detracted from Anderson's nuanced presentation of the film industry's impact upon sexual liberation. But, Reynolds delivers a perfect characterization of an American businessman who is only satisfying the public's nascent hunger for cinematic knowledge of the country's changing sexual mores.And, casting Mark Wahlberg in the lead role of Dirk Diggler was risky at best. At the time, Wahlberg was primarily known as a member of a boy band and an underwear model, but who really knew that he could be such a convincing actor? The film is very long, but never lags, and there are really far too many fine performances to note. MUST SEE

Paul Thomas Anderson became wordly acknowledged with "Magnolia". But this movie proved that he was a sure bet, earlier than Tom Cruise could say "Respect the cock". Here, stars are born - on and off the screen. Even though he did an unique and superb job in "The Basketball Diaries", Mark Wahlberg suceeds here in creating the ultimate boy-turned-porno-stud icon. But he never gets away with the movie, because the cast is so damn good: from William H. Macy's failed husband, Burt Reynolds headstrong director, Rollergirl's empty blonde, Amber Waves' failed mother, Philip Seymour Hoffman's repressed homosexual to Don Cheadle's hearty, honest character, they all have their chance to shine. Anderson's direction is filled with flare and lust, reminiscent of Scorsese (the frenetic cutting, the abrupt close-ups) and Brian De Palma (those steadycam shots), depicting with an exquisite detail the sensitive era when home movies turned to video, and coke was the big thing. This is a must-see, and a perfect example of how a director's vitality translates in cinematic results.

Review title: You will laugh and cry with both enjoyment and sadness. This movie really grows on you.
Review_body: Boogie Nights has to be a movie that makes a person fill the emotions each time they watch it. I'm glad that Paul Thomas Anderson made a film like this and really had the guts to show just how the porn industry is. Mark Wahlberg is great as a struggling teen just trying to find his way, so he has to take an offer he can't refuse and join an X rated film producer who is played perfectly by Burt Reynolds. This was certain the comeback moment for Burt he's as nasty as ever at the same time a loving man. Julianne Moore and Heather Graham play the roles of porn people so good that it really shows you the life these types of people live with all the sex, drugs, money, divorce, and many social problems they experience. Boogie Nights is one of the better movies I've seen in terms of taking a character like the Mark Wahlberg one and showing the upside with success in the 70's and the downfall to drugs in the 80's I like how it spans two decades. Boogie Nights is one of the best movies for pop culture it really shows reality of how the 70's happened even though I wasn't born till 78 I well know about the disco and styles plus the music from that era is terrific! The two volume music tapes from Boogie Nights is a must buy! Each time you watch this movie you feel like you are right with these characters because it was popular times that we all remember and with liking these characters so well who have the guts to make money from a controversial subject like pornography makes Boogie Nights all that much more of a classic that we want to feel the emotions of. Most of you will soon be like me and tape Boogie Nights and add it to your movie collection and call it a classic.

Porn stars and wrestlers are the ultimate actors for different reasons. Wrestlers never step out of character for a moment, never turn around say .... sure it is all faked. While the best porn stars live the life of their films in real life. Roller girl never removes her roller skates for anything.Boogie nights tells the story of Dirk Diggler, a man with few talents other than his rather large organ (you know the one I mean) and his ability in the act of coitus.Boogie night is a good fun movie that loves the characters enough to also expose their flaws and delusions. We see them rise to success and fall to their knees. We see the hypocrisies (the porn star film maker who is upset that his porn star wife is having sex with other men).It has a lot of weaknesses, but enough strengths to rise it up above many other movies. Most importantly it loves the idea of good pornography. It doesn't get bogged down with much of exploitation that occurs now and before in the porn industry. Perhaps it glosses over this part, but many of the very vocal defenders of pornography are those who most positive experiences.

Review title: Though it goes through a familiar plot line, you haven't seen anything like this before
Review_body: Heard numerous references of this movie from different media sources and always had a confused look as to what they were talking about. It all makes sense now. One of the most star studded movies you will ever come across except that most of them were not stars yet.Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg) has an exceptional natural gift which is spotted by Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) who grooms him, gives him an opportunity to show the world of his gift and also help him achieve his dream. Can Eddie control his ego that came along with his newly successful life, is Horner just a man who exploited his talent or something more? Answering these questions form the rest of the story.Now let me rephrase my synopsis as it sounded more like a parallel story of Rambo 3. Horner is an adult film maker who spots Eddie with a large penis and an ability to go all day long. Their synergy builds a successful run for both along with the entire unit who treat each other like family. One fine day Eddie's ego gets the better of him and the entire unit crumbles with it. Their road to darkness and resurfacing to light forms the rest of the story.I hated Paul Thomas Anderson when I watched Magnolia. Though it had a moving story and filled with excellent performances, it was flat out depressing. I feared a similar approach in this movie too not minding the energetic title. There were quite a few movies that follows the exact same storyline, most of them has either dealt with musicians or athletes but none with porn stars which stands out here. It has its moments of being awkward, cheeky, innocent and informative. It has a number of lengthy purposeful cameos by talented actors, researched portrayal of how the business of adult film industry is run, an excellent background score especially when Eddie, Horner, Rollergirl (Heather Graham) and Buck (Don Cheadle) hit rock bottom. Unlike most of his other movies, Anderson managed to life the spirits at the end of the movie though he takes you through hell just before it.Though it goes through a familiar plot line, you haven't seen anything like this before.

Director and writer P.T. Anderson leans heavily on the styles of Quentin Tarantino, Martin Scorsese and Robert Altman in this attempt to re-visit the 70s via the porn film making industry. With so many good actors in it, its surprising that the performances are not too hot. There are too many key scenes where Anderson should have said "lets do that one more time". The script is only O.K......nothing to get excited about. The use of background music...almost right through the movie is tedious. Tarantinos use of music is EXACT and brilliant. Its a film that should have been much better, given the nature of the material. Perhaps Anderson should get real script writers in future. The last 20 minutes are the best of the movie......so people who were getting bored are finally entertained and may walk from the theater happy.

Review title: Bittersweet human look at the porn industry of the 70/80's
Review_body: Boogie nights is not about dancing, it's about the American porn industry in the late seventies/early eighties and the people involved in it. Despite the sexual subject, there's actually very little sex and nudity going on and none of it is particularly arousing or exciting. In this movie, the porn industry is seen as a mix between business and family. This is a ensemble drama with some comedic elements or an ensemble comedy with some dramatic elements. For me it worked more as a comedy with the best moments coming in where the the "porn" industry is seen by some artisans as an artistic endeavor (cue bad acting or cheesy concepts in the porn films). It's idealistic, rather misguided and a bit touching but mostly amusing. The dramatic elements come mostly from their "real" family ties, adapting to society in the real world and drugs.I thought some scenes were overlong but in retrospect, I see the genius in making the audience cringing or unnerved and without the proper setup it would not have been as effective. There's a very good ensemble cast with the highlight being Julianne Moore who plays the anchoring "mother" to the rest while being rather fragile herself. Roller Girl played by Heather Graham in her break-out role was certainly pretty to look at but was a bit over-hyped as she only shows real acting chops near the end (the bedroom with Moore and the car). Mark Wahlberg in the lead was solid and Burt Reynolds as the director/producer was a nice surprise in a dramatic role. What I particularly enjoyed in this film is that it does not focus on just one character and it shows us a particular inside look at something most of us know very little about and that doesn't exist like that anymore. Keep in mind that several people from the real porn industry of that time have come forward to criticize the accuracy. Be that as it may, it's probably one of the only fiction films made on the subject by an A-list director and that's special in itself. The movie does elicit a gamut of emotions though the comedic elements work better than the dramatic elements.Rating: 7.5 out of 10

This movie was very entertaining! I couldn't stop watching it!                              It was just so good directed and so great actors (he, he). No seriously everyone did a great job in this movie. William H Macy's trouble with his wife was a bit sarcastic but fun.

Review title: Paul Thomas Anderson's Boogie Nights Was a Good Film That Takes Place in Two Decades Between 1977 And 1980 And Focus Center On One Big Family.
Review_body: Mark Whalberg Plays a Young Dishwasher Kid Named Eddie Adams Who Works At a Disco Club Then Meets Jack Horner Played By The Late Burt Reynolds Who Won a Golden Globe For Best Supporting Actor Who's An Adult Filmmaker Who Makes Adult Films And Who Offers Eddie Adams The Opportunity Of a Lifetime And That is Get To Star in Jack Horner's Next Adult Film And To Make Eddie Adams Who Change His Name To "Dirk Diggler" Dreams Come True Until Eddie Adams Starts To Become And Gets Addict To Cocane And Drugs. Boogie Nights Stars An All Star Cast Which Besides Mark Wahlberg And Burt Reynolds Are Julianne Moore, John C. Reily, Don Cheadle, The Late Philip Seymour Hoffman, Luis Guzman, Thomas Jane, Heather Graham, Alfred Molina And William H. Macy. Boogie Nights Has a Good Soundtrack Featuring Lots Of Groovy Songs From 1970s.
Great production design, direction, editing, acting. Julianne Moore was robbed at the Academy Awards.

Review title: A quality film with its flaws
Review_body: Given the time and place of the action and the very theme of the film, it is clear that this is a controversial film. Although there was a danger that the film would be cheap or look cheap, thanks to the great work of the director, this did not happen. The combination of genres, different camera angles and a great cast made this a very high-quality work. I'm not one hundred percent sure, but I felt the impact of Pulp Fiction, purely my impression. However it seems to me that the porn industry is the main character here and everyone else is just there to assist. It bothered me because this film seemed to me like a set of good scenes that don't always have to be connected. Almost every character has a problem, it does not have its own special story with the beginning and / or the end but its only purpose is to get an insight into the second half of the seventies and the beginning of the eighties of the last century.

This is a very hard movie to watch- Mark Wahlberg does a good job as a young man who gets caught up in the porn industry. Burt Reynolds plays the porn director with aplomb. William Macy plays the cuckoled husband sympathetically. The women are also very good. They give the viewer a sense of what makes people go into this industry. The music is good and the overall movie, while confronting a controversial topic does a good job.

Good direction and acting is wasted on a deceptively witty script. Lurking behind some well-written dialogue is a mess of a movie that tries to go in too many directions.A hypnotic and continuous camera can't make up for a muddled story. I don't understand the choices the director made on the final cut. This movie is too long and lacks focus. It's a mood piece, full of dramatic irony without any real drama for balance. When SOMETHING finally happens to make things interesting there is no basis for it - no setup, no motivation. Just a plot point that is supposed to happen to move things along. Director Anderson knows how to handle a camera, but he should let someone else write the script.

Review title: Redemption and forgiveness expressed beautifully through Porn
Review_body: Everything about "Boggie Nights" is sincere and straightforward, and with an wide array of unforgettable characters, it is one of the most distinctive American films made in the late 1990's. Everyone's born with one special thing, and Eddie Adams (Marc Wahlberg) uses his "special gift" and is poised to take the world of porn by storm. Eddie Adams, (also known as Dirk Diggler), is discovered by porn director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) and soars to the top of the pornography industry. After achieving great success in the industry during the 1970's, the 80's did not fair so well for Dirk. A change of culture coupled with a drug addiction, he quickly hits rock bottom not knowing anything else to turn to. At the heart of the story is a group of eccentric, outlandish group of characters, an unorthodox "family" if you will. An incredible collection of actors and performances keep this lengthy film completely engaging throughout the 155 minutes. Despite of what you may think of these people and their profession, you can't help but be drawn into their lives and personal stories. Paul Anderson's attention to the fine details; decor, style, culture, and social attitudes of the era are spot on. It is heart-rendering and darkly humorous with an message of redemption and forgiveness.

Finally saw this on IFC. Ten minutes in and I knew that Paul Thomas Anderson knows squat about the porn industry. The power is wielded not by the male performers, who are a dime a dozen, but by the female performers, who approve their on-screen partners.Anderson couldn't be bothered to do any character development, either. Why is the mother a harpie and the father a wuss? Why would Little Bill (another wuss) marry a nymphomaniac (another harpie), and assume that she'll be faithful? Why would she marry him? There is no hint of anything remotely like love between them, and his "solution" to his woes comes out of absolutely nowhere.How The Colonel's dalliances with underage girls is more repugnant than Jack recruiting an underage boy to have on-camera sex is beyond me, but when The Colonel is thrown into the poke, Jack suddenly gets a moral compass? Give me a break!How does the banker know that Buck does porn unless he was stupid enough to put that on his application? The donut shop scene was so silly and incredulous, I couldn't stop laughing!Amber wants her kid back, but does zip to show why she should regain custody! But not to worry, to Jack, she is still "the foxiest bitch in the whole world". How sweet!Rollergirl drops out of school because some bozo makes a crude gesture, then proves why she is unworthy of the respect she thinks she deserves. To add "insult" to "injury", she gets no "foxiest bitch" kudos from Jack. One other thing: why do wee see Dirk do white girls (and only white girls), but Anderson oh-so-modestly cuts away from Reed and his "Chocolate Love" just before they get their freak on?

Review title: A well done movie I didn't enjoy
Review_body: This movie is very well done. Julianne Moore is great, and this is the best performance I've ever seen Burt Reynolds put forth.The subject matter is gritty and sleazy, but the characters (for the most part) are not. It's not often in a movie where the average viewer is rooting for someone to get back into the porn business! I found this movie down-right excruciating to watch in parts. Some of the more painful ones seemed to last forever.I can appreciate that this movie is well done. It obviously hit a nerve with me.I'm glad I saw it, I didn't enjoy it, and I don't want to see it again.I'm giving it a seven because the acting was good, and the movie was well made. I would give it a 4 for enjoyment.

Boogie Nights is a great movie, and gives a sugar coated insight into the late 70s subculture of the Californian porn industry, before vds became deadly and when porn was shot on film. This is very much a picture of a world after the sexual revolution of the late 60s, inhabited people who are all slightly eccentric, to varying degrees. There is Roller Girl (Heather Graham), who literally goes through life (and school) on roller skates, there is Eddy Adams/Dirk Diggler (Marc Wahlberg, who's character seems like a combination of John Holmes and Jeffrey Stryker) and who has "one special talent" (his humongous dong) and is obsessed with Bruce Lee (who isn't/wasn't), Maggie/Amber Waves (Julianne Moore) and Buck Swope (Don Cheadle, based roughly on the famous porn actor Johnny Keyes, from among many other films, "Behind The Green Door", and/or Jack Baker).I especially like Don Cheadle's character (a great actor), who in an epitome of the way all the characters don't fit in with society, is an almost perfect stereo salesman, who falls down because of insisting on playing the customers _HIS_ (rather than their) favorite music, Country & Western. Buck Swope is continually one style behind, insisting that "country will make a comeback" throughout the seventies, and at new year's eve party 1979/1980 being decked out in an afrocentric/outer space outfit that makes him look like one of the members of Earth, Wind & Fire. He finally finds his style, though, in early eighties Hip-Hop.Rather than being simply a showcase of seventies culture, all of the characters are amalgams of several porn characters, and many of the situations are similar to actual events.For instance, the drug situation at the end of the movie is similar to what happened to John Holmes (he was interviewed by homicide detectives - see the movie "Wonderland" with Val Kilmer). John Holmes, though, in the end died if AIDS, caught in a gay video shoot, rather than just being beaten up by a gang of homophobes (without ill effects).Which is where the sugar coating comes in. In this movie, most of the characters in the end find their places in society, whereas in real life, several ended up dead. Another example, in this movie, the drug of choice seems to be cocaine, but in reality, it was heroine, probably so we don't have scenes of people shooting up. So, you have the situation of several characters overdosing on coke, which is a rare event, whereas od'ing on heroine is quite common. Also, no one ever catches any std.Anyway, the structure of the movie is almost very similar to Oliver Stone's Vietnam movies - the viewer is swept along with the progress of history and time, rather than depending on intricate plotting. The characters do develop, though, but predictably.Either way, this is a unique movie. Go and see it if you haven't already.

Anticipation 2
Conflict 1
Engagement 2
Entertainment 2
Production 1
Total 8

Review title: Where Have You Been All My Life?
Review_body: This movie is unbelievable. It's funny that I've never seen it before. Although it needs some time to tune in into it. At first I thought that I ain't gonna like this film and at the beginning it was kinda dull, though even at that time it didn't seemed like an usual film. The best thing about this film is that it has many twists, some of them unexpected, some of them were pretty predictable but still it was very interesting to watch.
