This film tells stories about few different people from adult movie industry. Probably the most shocking story to me was about Julianne Moore's character. There were many good actors in this film but probably I was the most impressed by Burt Reynolds, I used to see him in comedies and I thought that he isn't suitable for that role, but I was wrong, he did a great job.

One can admire the writer/director's ambition in wanting to encapsulate the entire "golden age of porn" in one sweep and, while this film has many things to commend it, some interesting characters, imaginative direction and some memorable scenes, it lacks focus and could probably do with at least an hour's worth of pruning.Too many story threads vie for attention and several get lost in the mix. Among a number of potentially interesting sidelines which go nowhere are a paedophilia strand and a male co-worker who drunkenly kisses Dirk Diggler. A lot of fairly famous faces appear but are underused.Some scenes are not convincing such as the very contrived confrontation between Diggler and Jack (excellently played by Reynolds) leads to Diggler's prolonged bout of ostracism from the porn family. And there is a strange vacillation between comedy and brutal reality. For instance, the graphic William Macy shooting scene is followed not long after by a video tape sequence in which Diggler refers to Napoleon as king of the Roman Empire, an example of stupidity which Diggler does not exhibit elsewhere. These scenes seem to come from two different films. The scene in which Don Cheatle is the sole survivor in a bizarre robbery and ends up with the cash also strikes me as implausible at least in this contest. Boogie Nights does manage to capture some of the mood of the times in these video tape sequence, but certain details elsewhere do not ring true, such as the presence of silicon implants (too early in 1980 surely?).

There's not much in the way of redemption or positivity that comes out of the world of porn, guns and excess drugs but PTA has sure made one hell of an epic film about the bleakness surrounding it.A real step up from Hard Eight only a year previous to this. The ensemble is handled really well with a sense of each character who are perfectly cast and played right across the board. Its also very funny in parts in the first half especially before it all turns nasty in the blizzard of coke and crack of the 80s.It could have possibly have lost a few scenes in the latter half and i did feel not particular connection to any of the characters as they were pretty unlikable on the whole. The one glimmer of hope we get is with Buck but even this is not clear cut or straightforward enough to really be emotionally engaging in a positive way.

Review title: A fresh, brazenly original finger in the face of the Moral Majority!
Review_body: This completely original depiction of the porno movie industry in the 1970-'80s is some ride, indeed. It's such a fresh finger in the face of any Moral Majority who seriously still think nudity and sex are worse threats to humanity than violence! P.T. Anderson earns at least one star in my book, solely for his sheer brazenly choice of story topics. But also handling it so vividly, funny AND moving is quite an achievement- I really care and feel for these characters! Peppered with a big-name cast that really delivers is another treat. And seriously, Mark Wahlberg IS a "f***ing star" here- simply sensational! Quibbles? Just a bit overlong, and so is the non-stop music soundtrack; blessed silence would have helped some scenes more.7 out of 10 from Ozjeppe.
This is a classic movie. Definitely one of a kind.. perfect 70s movie!

I started watching this movie expecting lots of cheap sex scenes like in the 1970's porno films. But instead, I got lots of beautiful photography, in-depth character development, a story of broken dreams, and the disintegration of members of the pornography industry. All the acting is fantastic, there is not one bad actor in the lot. My personal favorite was Heather Graham (who does have a few eye-catching nude scenes). Mark Wahlberg is surprisingly good considering he used to be Marky Mark, Burt Reynolds makes a well-deserved comeback, and Julianne Moore is both sexy and sad, something I haven't seen her portray since this movie. Supporting roles by William H. Macy, John C. Reilly, Don Cheadle, and Nicole Parker add to the masterpiece that this movie is. Don't go into this movie expecting sex, sex, sex like I did. The soundtrack is classic, too, and 2 CD's have been released of music. They are both well worth seeking out. I am still disappointed that this movie did not win more Oscars and Golden Globes!!!

Review title: The life of a porn family.
Review_body: At first it might look like it is all about the young porn superstar Dirk Diggler, but it moves away from only focusing on him and instead focuses on many different characters not really going too deep into why, how and when. Just gives you a glimpse of it is to be a part of the porn industry and how can you branch out into doing other things after that.It is not a great film, just because it is about the porn industry, as a matter of fact it contains far less nudity than one might expect from a film like this. This movie achieves its goal of showing the careless lives of these people. It does not stress you with many problems, fights and whatever, it just gives a careless vibe of the reckless 70's and 80's.The story might look quite blatant and not really that grasping, but the vibe this film has makes you not care about the story or how good or bad it actually is, it feels different. The first half of the film is more centered around the porn industry and Dirk's success doing what he loves, but the other half is all about character development and barely touches on the porn industry. So all those people who pass up watching this movie just because they dislike porn or porn industry, should know it is not all about porn and is a lot more likable than you might think. Has many likable characters, i even enjoyed Mark Wahlberg, who i am not a fan of. Worth checking out!

What was the point of this movie, other than for a young director to flex his Scorsese-muscle and practically remake Goodfellas.  What is the point of directing a coke-binge as a comic scene?  I've never tried cocaine, but it sure looks like fun when Heather Graham and Julianne Moore do it.  But what do we take away from this?  That porn is good?  Bad?  It is just what it is? That underaged boys in search of family should seek out porn?  That they shouldn't?  The only thing this film proved for sure is that Don Cheadle acts circles around anyone he is in any movie with.

Review title: The Finest Film of the Past Decade!
Review_body: I cannot remember seeing a film that blew me away as much as this film did. So entertaining, so creative, so funny,so tragic, so detailed and so smart. P.T. Anderson has staked his claim as the finest director in the business with this film, which was only his second work. The movie involves a bunch of misfits, each with serious problems, past and present. However, in a way, these misfits are able to come together as a happy family, in the porn business. Not to say that their lives are perfect, but they are much improved. The star misfit is one Dirk Diggler. Dirk has a natural feature that makes him a porn legend. However, as Dirk rises up the ranks of stardom, he and his happy family of misfits start to fall apart. In a sense, the characters start to forget what made them happy and get trapped in the pursuit of money and drugs. What I liked so much about this film are the creative tactics and methods used by Anderson. There are so many underlying themes going on here, that you will pick up new things as you watch it. Moreover, the characters are incredibly well developed. I have trouble describing this film, because it is just too overwhelming, trying to describe all of the many great things in it. No scenes are wasted and many creative twists are happening all the time.This film is a must see for all fans of film. How Anderson and this film were denied an Academy is beyond me. However, certainly the adult themes of the film did not help it with some. That is unfortunate, because there are some very positive themes in the film. This film is not for children, but at the same time it is not a "porn film." I believe that has been the biggest misconception. The film does not glorify the industry and it does not throw stones at it. It simply tells a great story about people involved in it. Perfection!

What a masterpiece, created by the next (already) great American director. Every scene is special, every action and line has meaning, a true labor of love. So detailed, yet so entertaining and easy to follow. The story deals with a young man named Eddie Adams, who has aspirations of greatness. Sadly, Eddie has minimal abilities at best. He is not very bright and makes a living washing cars and bussing tables. Ahh, but he does have one great attribute (try to guess what it is). He will use his one gift to climb the ladder of success very quickly. The only problem is that Eddie or Dirk Diggler (his new porn name) does not have the maturity or life experiences to handle so much at such a young age. The downfall is inevitable. Anderson shows you the meteoric, positive rise, then the depressing, sad fall of the Adult Entertainment Industry's "biggest" star.This film features the talents of so many great actors. Each is given an in-depth character to play. In a way, the wacky characters help form an extended family, that is very supportive, at first. The music is brilliantly worked into the story. The creative camera tricks and angles are evident from start to finish. Guaranteed that you will discover new things every time you see the film. The film was deserving of an Oscar, however the subject matter was much too risque. ***** out of ****.

My Rating: ***1/2 out of ****. Boogie Nights will be remembered as the movie that made Paul Thomas Anderson into a successful director. He got critical acclaim for this film and received an Academy Award Nomination for Original Screenplay, which was well deserved. Boogie Nights ended up on top ten lists for 1997 and one critic called it, "The Best Movie of the Decade."Anderson's films always have some unique look to it. Boogie Nights is no exception. The film gives off a seventies feel that is undeniable. This is mainly due to the set designs and the cinematography. The feeling also changes very well when the film moves into the eighties.
There was alot of hard work put into writing this script. The Academy saw it that way too and gave Anderson a nomination for his writing. The writing is what Anderson receives a nomination for in his movies, he received another one two years later for Magnolia. Boogie Nights has a well written script that only contains a few flaws. Those flaws are mostly overlooked when watching the film, except for one. Acting is a strength in Anderson's films and it definitely is here. Mark Wahlberg gives the least impressive performance but hes still good. His performance is uneven. During the beginning he seems a bit stiff, but he warms up to it and turns in a solid performance. Burt Reynolds received alot of attention for his performance (A golden globe win and an oscar nomination) and he does do a great job here. William H. Macy does some scene-stealing work, in fact I wished he had a little more screentime. Don Cheadle, Heather Graham, Nina Hartley, Alfred Molina, and John C. Reilly all do solid work. However, the standout here is Julianne Moore. This represents her best performance to date and it shows why she is so talented.
Like I said, Boogie Nights is not a flawless film. The most glaring flaw I found in the film came at the end. I did not like how Anderson decided to end this. It was unsatisfying and it also seemed somewhat-immature. However, Anderson does so many things right its possible to overlook the few flaws. Alot of his fans say this to be his best film. Personally, I prefer Magnolia, I thought it was a more mature picture and Anderson put one of the most creative endings on the screen. Boogie Nights is still very good and I give the film a strong recommendation.

Boogie Nights is a very stylish film about the porn industry in the late 70s dating from around 1977 to around 1983. Mark Whalberg is a young man who gets discovered in a bar one night and thanks to his good looks and large member he enters the porn industry. Burt Reynolds plays the porn director in a great career comeback performance. This film is really well shot, some great camera angles and movement you really feel immersed in this world. The soundtrack is amazing. Julianne Moore is also great as a porn actress who has a son she can not see. Her performance is really heart felt. You also see the dark side of the industry with violence and drugs. This is a great film one of the best of the 90s

Review title: Leave it in the 70's with flared trousers, afro haircuts and Starsky and Hutch.
Review_body: Paul Thomas Anderson's tale of the 1970's porn industry in America is probably okay if you were around at the time, personally I thought it was rubbish. For the first 40 minutes or so I was actually quite intrigued with the story of a young bus boy (Mark Wahlberg) who meets a top porn film director (Burt Reynolds) who sets out to make him a star in the seedy world of pornography, drugs and disco. The problem is that after 40 minutes the story takes a nose dive and the result is a total mess. From then on you have to sit through over 2 hours of total mishmash as Wahlberg and Reynolds get more irritating by the minute.  Not even the presence of screen beauties Julianne Moore and Heather Graham make you care what happens as the script plods along through the years. All in all another film which is very over rated. Anderson's first feature HARD EIGHT is far better value for money, and is there really a need for that final scene?

Review title: Why it is cool and not cool to like Boogie Nights...
Review_body: I remember seeing Boogie nights when it first hit the theaters. I was blown away and absolutely fell in love with this movie. To begin, we all have reasons why we like and dislike movies. For that respective reason i will not criticize anyone's review since they all tend to of a personal nature. Much like the reasons i like Boogie Nights is due to the personal way it hit home with my childhood memories and how effectively it registered as truthful and vivid recollections of my youth. Having grown up as an adolescent in the late 70's and early 80's I can relate to Boogie nights that would be hard for me to explain to those who didn't experience them in my eyes. Boogie Nights is a masterpiece. Not only does it represent the desperate human nature of people yearning to be accepted, loved and appreciated, but it also captures the wasteful time of American history where some people actually earned a living without ever doing anything of any value. The 70's for young adults was when some people abandoned any sense of social responsibility. Being a morally upstanding person was disrespected and regarded as uncool, because being risqué, daring and promiscuous was en vogue. As decadent as Anderson presents his characters and the sleazy lives these people lead it is apparent that he shows his characters as people who believe in themselves and their self delusion. Anderson doesn't judge his characters, but rather makes them very real.Boogie Nights is fun and exciting to watch. The story never lags. Anderson uses great angles, jump-cuts and effective usage of popular songs of that era for ambiance. It looks kitschy, slick and vibrantly paced. At 2.5 hours it seems to fly by.Why is it cool to like this movie? For those who can appreciate the period and setting that the story takes place is enough to draw your attention. The characters are also oddly interesting if even completely despicable. The humor is also good when it is harsh as well as uncomfortable. it's also a historical representation of the 70's that beautifully depicts the mentality of people in that time. People were far less socially aware of their faults, hangups and personal flaws back then. Today, we still have decadence and immorality in all of its numerous forms, but at least social media has kept us in check. The younger generation of today is far more informed and reminded on a daily basis the consequences of their actions. In the 70's, being promiscuous and drug addicted was upheld in pop-culture and used to separate the hip from the square by means of peer pressure. In post Y2K America we have learned the ills and setbacks of such a lifestyle and how that leads to self destruction, STD and pain.Why is it not cool to like Boogie Nights? All the characters in this movie are sad and damaged people. They are the losers of society who have chosen a soulless and hideous lifestyle devoid of any positive or meaningful aspirations. Their goals are short-term and have repulsively unsatisfying outcomes. They are all bottom-feeders who have clung together under the patriarch, Jack Horner. Exploitation, moral decay, human desperation, addiction and promiscuity are themes explored in Boogie Nights. This movie serves as a human and historical lesson. Don't watch this movie thinking you want to emulate any of these people, because you should react on the contrary. Yes, the movie does a great job with acting, plot development and authenticity. The purpose it should serve is that what a parable or Biblical story does.

Review title: The best film of '97- should have won the Oscar instead of "Titanic"
Review_body: Sometimes the Academy doesn't recognize the potential of some films, or doesn't nominate them because they are controversial or strong. Sometimes they are nominated, but don't win anything (I hope this doesn't happen this year with "American Beauty"). This is exactly what happened with "Boogie Nights", which was the best film of 1997. The Academy preferred to give the best picture Oscar to "Titanic", a purely commercial and hollow film, and other awards to the overrated "Good Will Hunting" and the irritating "Full Monty". The other pictures which were nominated in the main category were "L.A. Confidential" and "As Good as it Gets", great movies, but "Boogie Nights" is still better and should have been remembered in more categories.This amazing film tells the story of Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg, in a surprisingly great performance), a 17 year old barman who takes the attention of Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds, in a redeeming acting), a director of porn films. Eddie has a special 'gift', and this helps him to get into the world of porn movies. He changes his name for Dirk Diggler and starts to make a huge success. But fame... doesn't last forever. Other characters also have their parallel stories- Amber Waves (Julianne Moore, perfect), Buck (Don Cheadle) and others, including Rollergirl (Heather Graham), an actress who accepts to do anything, but she has to be wearing her roller shoes.What could have been a banal, trivial film, turns into a perfect, memorable one in the hands of Paul Thomas Anderson. What makes "Boogie Nights" such a great film is its execution, added to a clever, well written screenplay, great soundtrack, etc. Each character is very well developed, and each of them has his/her importance in the context. Each feeling, weakness, fear, emotion is explored, resulting in a masterpiece of the modern American cinema."Boogie Nights" is a strong, impacting picture that should be seen by everyone who really likes cinema. Under a plot that seems banal at first impression, there is a wonderful story of highs and downs, things that we face in our lives. It is an amazing portrait of the end of the '70s and the beginning of the '80s, exactly an age of highs and downs. That's what makes this film so special and a true masterpiece. 10/10

Instead of a script with an engaging plot and meaningful theme Boogie Nights presents nothing more than a list of scenes connected only by subject matter.  Some are not really attached to anything, like the wife of one of the film crew fornicating with various partners surrounded by onlookers, all without apparent purpose.  Ostensibly we are supposed to read meaning into this.  Eventually the man shoots her and one of her lovers.  Is this a stab at comedy, tragedy?  Perhaps, we are finally urged to consider, it is metaphorical of the film or the world of Porn.  Ultimately we are left without the real answer.The only thing this distasteful concoction of a film achieves is to push the envelope of probity and civility out a bit further.  Thus, many critics and audiences have shouted, "Brilliant," despite the fact that nothing is brilliant at all here.	Once again, we see the emotionally damaged and others of borderline intelligence trotted out and drawn to Porn, the artificial world of make-believe filmmaking.  This form of filmmaking reduces for us all the quality of life and steps on the triumph of the human spirit.  Indeed, Boogie Nights itself joins Porn and becomes a part of this phenomenon of the declination of the value and meaning of life and the ascendance of barbarism.

Review title: A REALISTIC PORTRAYAL OF THE ADULT FILM INDUSTRY?
Review_body: Since having seen this film and in a previous review where I thought it "realistic," I have made a study of the adult film industry. As a result, I have found that this highly regarded and most entertaining film conveys some misconceptions about that industry. Firstly, if you look at the films in that period (the late seventies), you'll find that much of the acting is quite good and the production values were quite high (it was not unusual for a porno film to be budgeted at $200,000).  Sex scenes and nonsex dialogue or plot scenes ran about 50/50, unlike todays films which are almost all sex and have very few accomplished actors in them. Often foreign locales such as London were used as settings (see Marylin Chambers in "Insatiable," for example)., and the sets could be quite elaborate.  "Boogie Nights" suggests that only the cheapest of sets were used and the performers were a pack of semi retarded dolts, and that was just not true.Secondly, for the most part the performers did not congregate in well-knit groups, although some of that was done.  Most went their separate lives after a scene or a film was shot.  Some just went home to the wife or husband and the kids.  Christine Fugat, in her recent documentary "The Girl Next Door," tells of how much she was impressed by how "normal" these people seemed to her.Next, generally the women were not  dumb and forced  to work for menial wages; many of them were quite intelligent and just chose to work in that industry and aspired (unsuccessfully for the most part) to get into mainstream films, mainly for the money.  Today, it is taken for granted that women rule that industry often setting the conditions under which they will work, the things they will and will not do, etc.Probably the most accurate depiction in the film was the debilitating effects video tape had on the quality of the films produced. There was a period in the 70's were "porno chic" was prominent.  Even Roger Ebert gave a favorable review to "The Devil and Miss Jones," as I recall.  People, often prominent ones, would wait in line to see such productions as"Deep Throat" and "Behind the Green Door."  Marylin Chambers was treated as a true star and stayed at the best hotels and appeared at grand openings, searchlights and all.Next, although cocaine use was widespread, that tended to be true of many professions in that era, including mainstream. Hollywood. The adult film industry was not a glaring exception.If the director "researched" the porn film industry, as he claims, I would suggest that he did a poor and one sided job of it. I still say his commentary track is one of the worst I have heard on a DVD.

First, I think one has to have seen a number of porn films to appreciate what a great take off Boogie Nights is.  It captures just how tawdry and explotive these films were with many of the porn cast sincerely believing that they were "actors," and no just porn machines. Next, how many appreciate how what I think is a marvelously effective score the movie has?  Many scores in movies are superfluous, even unwanted, but not this one.  It adds to the actions displayed in a way that heightens that superbly heightens them.  For example, the bells in one of the later sequences of scenes starting with Dirk getting in to a car to pitifully earn a few bucks.  Or the penultimate scene in the house where the boys go to sell some talcum powder as cocaine. The rock music, although not really a part of a superimposed score, blasts at us to the point where we want to scream, "Turn that damned stuff off."  When it finally is shut off, what a great relief.  This technique I found in some Spike Lee movies, particularily Jungle Fever, although I'm sure other have noticed it in different films too.

Perhaps the greatest story about the porn industry ever committed to a motion picture? Probably. In Boogie Nights, a movie filled with outstanding performances and pop culture for days, Paul Thomas Anderson shows us a movie in which he is truly and utterly in control of. Every single shot in this 2 and a half hour celebration of excess exists for a purpose and Anderson shows us his skill as a director. Like I said, it is a film filled with great performances, but really outstanding work from Mark Wahlberg in a truly committed performance. The movie delivers in a great use of music, filled with popular songs of the 70s and 80s and an amazing use of volume in the music (when to make it louder, quieter).All of this brings me to the ultimate flaw of Boogie Nights. There is a fine line between paying homage to a certain movie or a director and for a while, Boogie Nights rides this line with Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas. But after about the first half of the film, Anderson bluntly just rips off Scorsese. The story in itself is essentially a Goodfellas remake. A story about a young man joining a frowned upon business, starting from nothing, the film explores the inner workings of this business and we see it through the eyes of our main character (fish out of water) and we see his rise and ultimate fall through addiction and excess caused by the very business he started out in. In Goodfellas, it's organized crime. In Boogie Nights, it is the porn industry. Of course, there have been several movies to use the cookie cutter provided by Scorsese's seminal film (including two by Scorsese in Casino and more recently The Wolf of Wall Street), but Anderson also copies many of the shots used by Scorsese: Many tracking shots, the snorting of the coke then rapidly zooming in on the character's face, etc. The use of music (not the songs, but its use in the film) is nearly identical. But the similarities do not stop there. Anderson goes further in copying Scorsese's technique in using almost the same film shots used in Mean Streets. And the one that was just too much for me, personally, were the parts where Mark Wahlberg talks to himself in his dressing room, then by the end of the film it's the same thing but he is now a much different person and he starts shadow boxing (right after showing his giant c**k to the audience, of course). It is literally the exact same camera positioning (or nearly identical) as in Raging Bull. Like I said, this may be purely seen as homage to many, but for me it took it a bit too far.But overall, I can't really not like this film. Sure, Scorsese's framework is used in Boogie Nights, but as its own story it is truly gripping and compelling. It's not only a movie about the porn industry in the late 70s and early 80s, but a movie about addiction, the troubles of life and overcoming them. I have to confess, even after all of the similarities, I really like Boogie Nights and it is definitely worth a watch. The movie is two and a half hours long, but it flies by because it is insanely entertaining to watch. This is a sign of a pretty good film.

Review title: Almost as good as a giant "you know what"
Review_body: This is one of my favorite films ever. I can't begin to estimate the number of times I've watched it. The ensemble cast performances are fantastic. The dialogue is so effortless, but amazing. The costumes, the sets, the music. You enjoy the fast ride even while you know the crash is imminent.

"Boogie Nights" (1997) written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, is a technical statement by an awe-inspiring director in the making.PTA's direction is focused, deliberate, and in line with the great pacing of his own screenplay.Actors are all great, in particular Julian Moore, and as usual, Philip Seymour-Hoffman steals the show with his remarkable talent in a supporting role. Truly one of the greatest actors of his generation. Mark Wahlberg surprises as worthingly competent.Cinematography in particular is astounding and immersive; hereunder the one-takes are incredibly awesome.Editing is excellent - serves the right purpose - lots of dynamics between fast cuts establishing implied references and purposeful long-takes immersing the viewer in the film.Score is great, lots of disco and funk - awesome as well.Highly recommended as a great film by an aspiring world class director.

...of golden age in porn industry in 70's and 80's. Boogie nights is one of these enjoyable, partly documentary, partly "well build story" type of movie, where you can just sit back and really get a feel of the era representing it. The biggest credit goes to director (P.T. Anderson), who has picked the right actors. Always sexy Heather Graham, surprisingly talented Mark Wahlberg and all the others. Well done. Beside that, there is a great music theme that really gets you in (funky) 70's mood. In it's genre is certainly classic and a movie you'll most probably like to return to. 7 out of 10...well almost 8:)

Review title: One of the strongest debut's of a brilliant director in the 1990s...
Review_body: Boogie Nights is a film that should sit with pride in any collection. Its a film about so much more than fly on the wall look at the Porn Industry of the 1970s and the character types that inhabited that world, its a statement about the excesses that permeated the end of one decade and the beginning of another. Mark Wahlberg brings in a confident performance, demonstrating once again, that it can all be about the material that the actor is given. He plays Eddie Adams, a bus boy in the valley of Los Angeles at the club of Luis Guzman who is soon brought to the attention of adult movie director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds in what is probably his best ever performance) and soon turned into super porn star thanks to his considerable talents below the waist. Director Anderson made no secret that the story was partially inspired by the late John Holmes, but here he seems to be represented also by a supporting character, played by a young Thomas Jane.Though initially the journey is that of Eddie into porn star Dirk Diggler, Anderson very capably gives all his supporting characters flesh on their bones and their own stories which endear us to them all. John C Reily, Nicole Ari Parker (Massively underrated actress) Don Cheadle, Melora Waiters (Superb) all bring life to the ensemble of the piece as the rest of the adult stars in Horners circle of friends, all of their characters have flaws and weaknesses, but all of them too seek something beyond the porn industry that they find themselves. Julianne Moore is the mother of the group taking on Dirk and Rollergirl (Heather Graham) as her siblings in place of her estranged son, who her ex husband will not let her have contact with because of her involvement in the industry - She copes with this by consuming vast amounts of drugs and showing her affections on her co-stairs instead. Anderson uses a number of interesting techniques to make dialogue scenes a little more interesting and the film, though long, passes through the 6 decades it covers at a bouncy pace. The production design here must be commended too as its all spot on, and the colours of the film make you feel like you are watching a movie from that era. Anderson manages to blend both the tragic and hilarious moments of very life seamlessly as they often are in reality to great effect here. The fact is the porn industry here is used as the catalyst to study the excesses of the era, but you didn't need to be in the porn industry to be involved them. Although the ending maybe a little unsatisfying, showing you that some characters have moved on while us are much where we found them in the first place, it is true to life and the study of character here is first rate. Every single supporting role has a pitch perfect cast too which include a young Seymour Hoffman, already showing his metal and William H Macy as Little Bill in one of the first roles I remember him in. A recent re-watch of this on DVD encouraged me to leave this review and at first I was thinking 'God this hasn't aged well' but actually yes it has, I just forgot that I was suppose to feel like I was in the 1970s, then I remembered, that is the point. Put this with Studio 54 on in one evening and you will feel you have lived the end of the 70s on both coasts of America. A time before the shadow of AIDS and HIV came into the heterosexual world.

Review title: Utterly Fascinating Look at the Porn Industry, Warts and All
Review_body: 1997 was not Oscar's best year, particularly in the Best Picture category, which consisted of three lousy movies (TITANIC, GOOD WILL HUNTING, and AS GOOD AS IT GETS) and two that were mediocre at best (THE FULL MONTY and LA CONFIDENTIAL). As it turns out one of the lousy ones won, while one of the best pictures made that year unaccountably failed to even make the nominees list. I am referring to Paul Thomas Anderson's brilliant, no-holds-barred, and unflinchingly frank look at a "family" of pornographers (everyone from the producer to the stars to the film crew gets face time here) from the days when "adult films" were made with actual film and often financed by organized crime to the legal but undoubtedly cheesier days of direct-to-video movies.While this is mostly an ensemble piece, the central figure is Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg, sensational here), a slightly dim-witted young man with a huge "endowment" who attracts the attention of porn producer Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds in perhaps his best performance since DELIVERANCE) and is soon a member of Horner's company, renamed "Dirk Diggler" and bearing more than a passing resemblance to the late John Holmes.Anderson makes big movies, and they tend to run long; this one takes a little over two-and-a-half hours to tell its story, but there isn't a frame of wasted film here; this is an exciting, involving, and utterly fascinating film from start to finish. Even if you find the subject matter objectionable, you will not be able to deny the power Anderson brings to every moment of this film.The ensemble deserves mention here as well, because this is a film loaded with some of the best character actors in the business and every performance has greatness in it. One of my particular favorite scenes is a cocaine-fueled stream-of-consciousness dialogue between porn actresses Amber Waves (Julianne Moore) and Rollergirl (Heather Graham) that is as harrowing as a train wreck and quite as impossible to avoid looking at.There is a lot of other great talent on hand here: Luis Guzmán as an aspiring producer; Don Cheadle as an aspiring porn actor with the peculiar quirk of dressing in cowboy outfits that make him look more like BLAZING SADDLES material than a porn star; William H Macy as a member of the crew whose wife (Nina Hartley) enjoys "doing it" with every available male whether or not the cameras are turning, and a slightly stereotypical but nonetheless compelling turn by Phillip Seymour Hoffman as a gofer with a major crush on both Dirk and his "sidekick" and frequent costar Reed Rothchild (John C Reilly); and two brilliant cameos: Joanna Gleason as Eddie/Dirk's hateful mother, and Alfred Molina as a highly-placed drug dealer whom Dirk and Reed make an abortive attempt to rob, nearly losing their lives in the process.This is a great film, rich in both form and content. There isn't a bad performance or a single scene that fails to hit the mark in the entire movie, and if you haven't seen it yet, I urge you to get it. It is proof that great movies are still possible even in this day and age when we are drowning in remakes and silly action pictures.Final note: the most interesting and compelling thing about this film is that Anderson makes no judgment calls about his characters. He shows them for who they are, the good, the bad, and the in-between, giving the film a depth that is rare in Hollywood.A work of genius.

Review title: Didn't know if I liked it or hated it. * * 1/2
Review_body: It's obvious when I watch a movie,I'll usually enjoy it or not.I had seen some films that I liked while there were others that I weren't so fond of."Boogie Nights" to me is a mixture of both.It's a trip through a time that I myself am familiar with being that I was born in 1972."Boogie Nights" is not the worst film I have ever seen and it certainly is not the best.Throughout the entire 2hrs and 30 min of this entire film,My opinions kept changing from "This film is not bad" to "Is it over yet?" and back again.What can I say about a film that gives me mixed opninions."Boogie Nights" is a film I would show some respect for due to it's cast and storyline.The film is basically about the rise and fall of the porn industry and it's star Dirk Diggler,played with a great performance by Mark Wahlberg.The former Marky Mark rapper sheds his light as a dramatic actor which almost earned him an academy award nomination fot best actor.Dirk Diggler is a young innocent teenager who enters into a world of the porn business.He becomes the porn film industrie's biggest porn star and is soon ahead of the game.Of course,Dirk owes it all to one man.Jack Horner.He is a hot porn filmmaker who in one scene discovers Dirk at a restaurant who immediately notices potential in Dirk.Although Dirk's real name is Eddie Adams. We see the kind of life Eddie lives with his parents.His mother represents the kind of parent that he probably wouldn't like to live with being that their relationship is not so mother and son.The only father Eddie(Dirk Diggler) has is the man who has caused him to be a sensation.Burt Reynolds plays the filmmaker who would rather shoot his films on film rather than video.Burt Reynolds was recognized with an academy award nomination for best supporting actor.From what I heard he was ignored of a nomination for "Deliverance" due to a centerfold he did.I do not know if that's a rumor or not but it was not a rumor when he finally got his respect in the form of an Oscar nomination.Watching this film was like playing with a bag of mixed emotions."Boogie Nights" is also on the goodside due to it's performances by Don Cheadle("Rush Hour2",'Family Man" and "Traffic"),Julianne Morre and Heather Graham.The film had certain points that irritated me.I was never fond of the 70s or early 80s which is why I was blocking my ears on the way home listening to that Rick Springfield song "Jessie's Girl" in my head.That took me back into a time that I did not want to go into.The 70s to me were dull but then I was a kid.But I was old enough to look around and see for myself and watching "Boogie Nights" was like opening a door that was meant to be locked."Boogie Nights" is not a bad film.it has great performances and a decent story but the film gave me to many mixed emotions.What can you say about a film that confuses you like that?Roger Ebert gave this film **** which means that he really enjoyed it.I am not Roger Ebert so my opinion is this:Everone has their own opinions.Only problem with my opinion is it zig zags in different directions because of this film."Boogie Nights" will be remembered as an important film to some people but to me,I had no idea what to think of it.

"Boogie Nights" is a masterpiece it tells a great story with flair an great direction from a very talented director. This film features a cast which turn in outstanding performances. Though the subject matter is very controversial but it is handled with great care by very talented people. This movie has an unexpected emotional impact also, you will remember it long after it is over.

Review title: Did John Holmes take the nod?
Review_body: **** May contain strong spoilers ****This is a review made by StoneDraim... and that means that if you want to read a probably different kind of review, keep reading....This is my personal experience, my personal point of view/perspective and my personal opinion... and my opinion is just one of like 7 billions in this world.Perfect startoff for this kind of movie. A solemn little piece of music placed right into the 70's adult industry is in front, just to get cut off with a solid funk act... known and placed in the 70's. Really nice!There is a sense of a theme park during this film as it begins and stops with a typical theme taken from the late 70's and the early 80's adult industry. A little charming and careful tune as from a barrel organ that sets the entire tone for the movie. There is things going on all the time during the around 160 minutes of movie... something around every corner.Is this sarcasm to the adult industry? Is it a show off in how the stars and crew behind the scenes acted and acts? It can be both. It 's all in the eye of the beholder.The naive and total lack off integrity in the adult business is shown off in a huge comic sense during the whole motion picture. A lot of examples could be taken care of here... see for yourself. Burt Reynolds and Mark Wahlberg is excellent together and touches that "fake innocence" that the adult industry tries so hard to develop and force upon the viewers.Over to the movie as a product: - The production : Good work and well performed production. "Best written screenplay written directly for the Screen", Academy Award nominee. Amazing excellence in the costumes and the surroundings during the era of 70's and 80's. - The actors : Julianne Moore and Burt Reynolds nominated for Academy Awards. Burt Reynolds won a Golden Globe for his performance. - The story : As it is almost 20 years ago since the movie settled, it was and is an important movie. Before the global phenomenon of the internet "amateur adult" industry came into the light. About this time, there were documentaries about the adult industry and business getting television time globally. Yes, an important movie and I would say the time was right. Maybe there could be a Boogie Nights 2 now with the same actors to shed light on today's industry in the same business. - Entertainment : Tragic, sad, little laughs here and there. All in a positive entertainment way. - Age : 15... or 18, depending on the sexual explicit, language and violence.7,4 out of 10. (The final rate is based most on my own entertainment of the movie. Short elucidation of the rating: 8 Excellent movie and a solid production 7 Well made movie. Proper entertainment.)

I enjoyed Boogie Nights, but it seemed to be a less successful precursor to the 1999 film 'Magnolia', recounting the stories of various characters that we're supposed to fall in love with and then marvel at, shaking our heads at their respective ill-gotten fates by the end. Most of the characters were wholly likable but far too shallow to really care about - worrying about superficial values, appearances or how many lines of coke they can snort at a time.Initially I was wary of the impact of Boogie Nights, expecting a sordid, dark, sinister type of experience, instead of a frivolous tale with tongue-in-cheek humour throughout. I new I was going to like it right from the start, with it's star-studded cast, excellent soundtrack and visual style, but it started to lose steam after an hour because of the non-discernible plot progression and novelty level that had worn off.The film has lots of swearing, epic amounts of cocaine abuse but not that much nudity or pornography, surprisingly. It's also graphically violent in places, but didn't shock or affect me in the way I expected. In fact, Boogie Nights is a film about gullible, often charming, not very sensible people that ultimately lose their way in life, later trying to redeem themselves, accepting that they're ultimately pretty f**ked up as a whole.But somehow it didn't gel together well enough, emotionally, by the end.Definitely worth a watch, but not as shocking or ground-breaking as you might think.

Review title: Simply one of the best films ever made...
Review_body: Boogie Nights is a modern classic and, quite frankly, one for the ages. This is a bold statement to make, but this will surely be a movie that will be studied and remembered for years to come.  Some people I have spoken with regarding "Nights" consider it appalling and unwatchable.  They cannot be further from the truth.  It is probably the subject matter they find awful, hence, they trash the movie.  You must watch the film with an objective attitude towards pornography, or miss one of the most truthful, realistic films ever presented on-screen.  Brutal, perceptive, sad, hilarious, tempting...it's all here!Dirk Diggler is the epitome of misled youth, as well as a prime example of taking advantage of a situation that presents itself to you.  The film's tag-line rings very true, saying everyone has something useful.  Diggler's something happened to be very marketable back in the late-'70's madness that was the porn industry.  Aside from this, the film must be looked at as a slice-of-life, historical document because of how sex is portrayed and thought of then and now.  Porn, of course, is still booming.  I don't think as many people are being hurt.  Boogie Nights shows both sides of this world where love is hard to come by and you can lose it all in the blink of an eye, yet, it is an extremely tempting lifestyle to so many.

Boogie Nights can be divided into two halves: the rise and fall of a porn actor. In that it follows the same kind of structure as an archetypal gangster film. And, like with most gangster films, the first half of Boogie Nights is a feast for the eyes and ears. Anderson lets the camera swoop through one entertaining scene after the other, accompanied by a terrific soundtrack. All actors are in top form but it is Burt Reynolds that steals the show as a totally believable porn director. The second half of the film is less impressive. The story at times gets too far fetched (the Molina cameo although great, the scene is a bit too much), too Hollywoodesque and subplots (like Cheadle's) that are not interesting only distract from the main plot. First half an 8, second half a 5. So a 6,5 is my final verdict.

What if a person thinks they are talented but they are not? What if this person has a burning desire to be in the movie business and it is the the 70's before independent film took off? One answer, porno movies.
Boogie Nights gives a glimpse into the world of skin flicks in their hey day in the San Fernando Valley. Writer/director Paul Thomas Anderson is masterful in capturing the energy of this time with disco scenes, parties with the right clothes and music. But better than this are the quirky characters. They believe that they are terrific actors, artists and musicians. What they will not admit is that they make poorly made porno films. The pain of life is too strong for them but it can only be held off for so long. Time and again the facts come crashing in finally leading to an ending which feels like a bad hang over. Paul Thomas Anderson's style is impressive. It sometimes looks like Scorsese with the long tracking shots and a great Raging Bull dressing room scene. There is a little bit of Tarantino also. But better than this is how well the actors perform under Anderson's direction. This is Burt Reynolds' best work since Deliverance. Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, Don Cheadle are great portraying people who have turned their back on much of the world, trying to create their own. These characters grow on you after a while. They are there for each other including taking in Mark Wahlberg's Dirk Digler who is the most convinced of his "greatness". I can't help but think of Ed Wood when I see this film. He also brought together a group of misfits that struggled to create movies. When the B movie business died, he went on to make porno films which was the only place where a person with his "talent" could go.Boogie Nights wrestles with the question about how people express themselves. And more than that, it is about dealing with life. It does it with rare humor, style and heart and how often can you say that about a movie?

P.T. Anderson's epic following the lives of porn filmmakers from the 70s to the 80s in one of the most un-Hollywood Hollywood movies since "Raging Bull" or "Schindler's List".  Beautiful shot in long takes with superb cinematography.  Mark Wahlberg, playing a porn star who rises to fame, and Burt Reynolds, playing the director of the films, deliver their best performances before or since - but everybody in this ensemble cast is stellar.  Full of unique and colorful characters - yet the movie feels honest and real all the way through, with lots of emotional power.  One of the few movies of that last few years that qualifies as a real must see.

When this film was released there was a lot of viewers who didn't understand what the purpose was. Instead of purpose , the viewer is advised to just watch the story unfold because there is stellar deliverance from many of the actors here e.g. Julianne Moore as an aging B movie actress, William H. Macy as the obsessed husband , Burt Reynolds as the sleazy producer. As a 70s child, I have a deep acceptance that the rules were not that defined and there's this transition from the flower power to the hippie era where the borders of sex are oftentimes too open and too easy to abuse. There is escapism to easy money but at the same time aspiration to make it better. Philip Seymour Hoffman is true to form as member of the film crew who lusts after Dirk Diggler ( Mark Wahlberg) . An entertaining film with sublime life lessons and heart-poking moments.

When a film's title comes from a song, you just expect it to be in the film! I don't know why this eponymous tune isn't, but that's a very minor quibble. Paul Anderson has demonstrated since this masterpiece came out that he's no one trick pony, with one bold story after another and no treading on the same terrain like some other directors we could name.His script is sprawling, in the best sense of the term. So many people looking for happiness and finding it interwoven with pain, boredom, cyclical frustration and growing, if not wiser, certainly older. The song titles are like what silent movie insert cards were so many years ago and push the drama along. "Fooled Around and Fell In Love", "Do Your Thing", "Ain't No Stopping Us Now", "Brand New Key", "Livin' Thing"... they pretty much speak for Dirk Diggler/Eddie Adams and his voyage.The barely old enough to shave youth takes all the tests the world has to offer and with his wide eyed self absorbing it all in, he becomes a person who gets in over his head before his head even leaves his pillow in the morning. Mark Wahlberg ended any doubts as to whether he was a gifted actor with his firecracker performance. Eddie became "Dirk" and nothing is ever the same for him and the motley crew he adopts as his new family.Burt Reynolds gives a beautifully philosophical touch to his Jack the director. Having reached an age when he can look back on his half decade stint as the top box office star with some wisdom, now a lifetime of seeing the rise and fall of many actors (including himself) gives the role great depth. Who understands the excitement, ennui, despair and release of stardom better?The late, great Bob Ridgely appears as the Colonel, the ever reliable Wiiliam H. Macy plays Little Bill like his life depends on it and the incomparable Philip Baker Hall lends his regal presence to a tiny, but huge in impact appearance. Heather Graham, Joanna Gleason and Julianne Moore are more believable women than 99% of the female roles other actresses get to play. The rest, too many to all list, are just so wonderful, this is one of the few films which deserved the kind of cast award SAG gives out. It's an acting picture as much as a writer's or director's.

Review title: "Boogie Nights" Remains An Enlightening Masterpiece Of '90s Film-making, While Viciously Exposing The Other Side Of The Film Industry
Review_body: Boogie Nights charts the story of infamous porn star Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg), a young man striving to become something in the wide world. He is not the sharpest tool in the shed, but he has a talent on one side of the life spectre and quickly becomes a media icon. Boogie Nights shows the rise and fall of Dirk Diggler and the close-knitted friends he works with. Generally speaking, the film is based around the real facts, capturing the needed essence and realism of the porn world. The core of Boogie Nights is that it is a reflective character study that entertains, amuses, shocks, thrills and educates the viewer.Boogie Nights is a film where you become part of a journey, this journey is one that shows you just how exploitive and derogatory the porn industry is Think "Goodfellas", but instead of gangsters you have pornographers. You can tell Paul Thomas Anderson has been influenced by Martin Scorsese's '90s cinema because there is an edge of Scorsese-flair direction hanging over Boogie Nights. At first look I thought Boogie Nights would just be a highly entertaining study telling the story of the porn industry, however Boogie Nights holds a message and rather than just being a film, it becomes a deeply insightful study.Boogie Nights pulls the viewer inside a world fuelled by casual sex and drug abuse. At heart, Boogie Nights is extremely anti certain elements of the porn industry. Boogie Nights slowly changes from being a highly enjoyable drama to becoming a demeaning study of wasted life and a lesson in social history. The film depicts everything, it does not hesitate to show the truth and reveal to the viewer the fascinating warped lifestyle that some people live.Everything is so fast, a plunge into a new lifestyle, a new culture, a new group of people, who at heart are a new family and the people who represent the confidence that Dirk Diggler never had from his parents. You are supposed to pity Dirk Diggler because he never had the love and care that he needed. There was not enough hope for Dirk Diggler before his success in the overpowering porn industry. But porn was his freedom and his route away from his mundane life. Yet, does it make him a better person? The answer is a simple, no, because he soon becomes a nasty person, controlled by his self-indulgence and loss of respect. You see, Boogie Nights is not about sex, it is not meant to turn us on because what it is about is a business that has shattered many people's lives.Boogie Nights is not a sleazy film, nor is it not a lurid film; however it is an extremely honest film that is not afraid to educate the viewer on what the porn industry does to the people. Boogie Nights made me think that porn is not just "fun and games", but it is actually exploiting people who have very few options in life. Another sad fact was that the actors and filmmakers consider what they were doing to be excellent and they truly felt they were making good films; it saddened and amused me to see them considering their work to be "well made". It made me sad to see just how ignorant they all were, what at heart is nearly as bad as an Ed Wood film.Paul Thomas Anderon's talent bursts onto screen with a vivid and colourful spectrum of material. He gives a script that pulses with hysterical humour, quotable dialogue, brilliantly structured narrative and a raw edge. The story layout is glorious and has many twists and turns, showing every little effect. One of the film's most memorable film-making characteristics is the use of tracking shots, arguably the finest to ever be put on film. Boogie Nights has that authentic vibe that captures '70s and '80s pop culture with a delicate force. The use of tracking shots gives the film a needed documentary effect. It is a visionary experience and one where Paul Thomas Anderson loves his wonderfully flawed characters which he has carefully crafted. The film also sums up the contrast of how violence becomes a trial for the lives of the characters, it is a perfected transition. Paul Thomas Anderson captures the pop culture with excellence and hilarity, by using a variety of '70s and '80s iconic songs you feel pumped inside the era. The editing is amazingly clean-cut and with the use of quick shots, close-ups and a variety of unique techniques we become plummeted into the world and introduced to many characters through incredibly '90s film-making.The ensemble cast is awe-inspiring, it adds to the mixture of quirky comedy and emotional driving force. There are so many talented actors and actresses who deliver career defining performances, which are some of the finest in modern cinema history. The entire cast light up the screen and create amusingly likable characters, who you manage to feel sympathy for. The actors and actresses control the viewer and help draw you inside the underworld of the porn industry, shedding light on what really happens and the unpleasantly genuine effects.I would consider Boogie Nights a depressing film, yet one that also has an element of hope and edge of inspiring attitude because it shows that some people are able to change the nastiness they have dug themselves into. It works as a brilliant comedy, an insightful drama, a detailed study and an entertaining work of art. It has everything a true masterpiece needs. Many aspects of Boogie Nights are unpleasant One of the best films ever made, there is no questioning the sheer force and wonderful charm of wit which Boogie Nights holds. I guess Dirk's motto is true to Boogie Nights, and much more, "everyone is blessed with one special thing".
Brilliant multi-story film. Lots of stories to follow that intertwine. Dark. Funny. Engaging. Great direction and camerawork. Great music, performances and stories/story.

Superb acting. Tremendous direction. Wonderful ensemble cast of incredible actorsInteresting storyline, and hilarious script.You get to see Heather Graham naked too, which is nice.The soundtrack will either take you back to the seventies, or take you there for the first time, in colour.The music will make you pine for a time when the music in the charts was actually good.If you haven't seen this, it's worth watching a number of times.This is a great film of complete and utter quality.

Review title: An impressive trip through the 70s and 80s
Review_body: Boogie Nights is one of those movies that you never expect to be good.  The previews look OK, perhaps even funny, the cast seems attractive, but overall you simply cannot imagine a movie about pornography will be very good. Well, you would be wrong.  Boogie Nights is quite simply one of the best films of the 90s, and definitely one of the best period pieces I have ever seen.  Given the 70s and 80s were not that long ago, but writers and director really demonstrate a reasonable understanding of not only the porn industry, but the societal changes that turned it into a profitable business.While Boogie Nights does not seem to glorify pornography in any way, it also does not fall into moralizing mode and become an indictment of the people of the industry.  Most of characters managed to expand beyond their conventions and become living, breathing creatures.  Wahlberg is phenomenal in this film, surprisingly so, he really brings a sense of pathos to an otherwise stupid and unsympathetic character.  The scene where his mother is taunting him and ripping his posters down is genuinely moving in a wierd sort of way (although she is not ultimately wrong).Most of the characters are equally as complex and engaging and the plot is beautifully done and ends on a rather strange kind of upbeat.  Overall, I would advise this film to anyone who was genuinely interested in the 70s or 80s, and to people who have sort of an off-beat sense of art.  Boogie Nights transcends the conventions of the biopic drama and brings something very interesting to the mix.

I kept hearing about how great this movie was and when I saw it all I could think was what were they thinking when they made this movie. This movie has been made better (9mm, hardcore) the story jumps from scene to scene without making any sense. A total waste of money
This film was incredible. The casting was masterful and the rollercoaster ending was breathtaking. I loved every minute.

Epic in scale, brilliantly acted and utterly mesmerizing to watch, "Boogie Nights" is one of the greatest American movies I've ever seen, a rival to the "Godfather." I don't think it's a coincidence that both films are about criminal empires (the mob, the porn industry) and there are some heavy Oedipal undertones to both (Michael and Vito Corleone, Dirk Diggler and Jack Horner). Only when we're watching underworld figures can we confront the ruthlessness necessary to succeed in American society: we can understand why a gangster like Michael Corleone will have his own brother-in-law killed, we accept that a semi-literate hustler like Eddie will prostitute himself to fame and fortune, but it's a bit more disturbing to think that people who conquered on the right side of the law might be just as vicious or amoral (witness the sanitized, vulnerable Howard Hughes of "The Aviator" or the noble "Patton"). As for father-son conflict, it's a staple of storytelling and film-making and what's remarkable about both "Godfather" Pt I and "Boogie Nights" is that the breach is healed . . . and that's not necessarily a good thing.Where "Godfather" was visually grandiose, with vivid, almost lurid uses of shadow and color, "Boogie Nights" has a sunny, bleached-out look appropriate to its Southern California setting, a nice illustration of a point made about that particular region of the country, and all the nefarious industries that occur there: the weather is so nice you don't really notice all the evil. Anderson's boldest move is his deployment of the soundtrack to underscore the narrative, which harks back to opera and its use of leitmotiv: the songs playing always comment on the action either blatantly ("Driver's Seat" when Floyd Gondolli enters) or ironically ("God Only Knows" when Amber Waves drags Dirk Diggler into his house for a cocaine binge). Anderson also uses montage, which would be trite except for the way he subverts the cliché by making the characters look silly (although it's probably impossible to retain too much dignity when "Boogie Shoes" by KC and the Sunshine Band is playing in the background).As for the actors, well, they're all pretty damn remarkable and they all throw themselves wholeheartedly into these anti-heroic characters. Mark Wahlberg exposes himself in every way imaginable (and yes, I mean emotionally). It's hard to imagine a braver performance, especially when he sings (oh yeah, he sings). Julianne Moore is charming despite the fact that she's playing a psycho, and this film dates from the period when she couldn't get noticed without taking her pants off so you can look forward to that, too. Heather Graham is both cute and scary (and sweet Jesus, is she hot). As for Burt Reynolds, I'm not sure the entire film wasn't an excuse to make him look good -- he's Burt Reynolds playing Burt Reynolds, but in this case, it just f**kin' WORKS. The movie is a brilliant achievement, perhaps underrated because of its sleazy subject matter -- but honestly, is there a better metaphor for capitalism than the porn industry?

Review title: The struggles and thrives of a new formed family on the background of the lusty, lively, illegal, bitter and enthralling world of late 70's to early 80's porn industry
Review_body: Though he doesn't insist on it as much as in his first feature film, Hard Eight, you can tell that PTA brings successfully, once again, the motif of family and paternity on the screen. His skills in terms of cinematography are getting better and his choices of soundtracks delighted me and drained as much emotion from me as they could, aside from the well-made characterization and the attention given to every single character, be it secondary or a main one. 9.5/10

Review title: The struggles and thrives of a new formed family on the background of the lusty, lively, illegal, bitter and enthralling world of adult industry
Review_body: Though it didn't insist on it as much as in his first feature film, Hard Eight, you can tell PTA successfully puts on screen the motif of family and paternity once again. His cinematography is getting better and his sometimes bizarre choices of soundtracks delighted me and drained as much emotion from myself as they can, aided by the complex characterization and attention given to details/secondary characters. The acting is priceless, the distribution fits the kind of story. 9.5/10

Review title: I really wanted to like this movie
Review_body:
I like P.T. Anderson a LOT (_Magnolia_ is one of my favorite films of all time), so it hurts to admit this: _Boogie Nights_ is not a very good movie. This is a mystery, in light of an excellent director, an excellent cast, and excellent camerawork.  In fact, nearly everything about this movie is perfect, EXCEPT the script.  To put it nicely, the script just plain stinks. While I can see that the film is supposed to make some sort of point about loneliness and interpersonal relationships, the story is completely jumbled and just doesn't make very much sense.  Characters never really develop as well as they should and are not very interesting.I'm not really sure why anyone does anything in this movie; motivations are never an issue.  Although the film certainly succeeds in evoking certain moods, I was never sure why I felt the way I did about a particular scene and ended up getting annoyed.  Finally, the ending, which could have saved the entire film, kind of petered out and left me feeling disappointed.
I can see why this film made money.  It contains excessive drugs, sex, and pornography.  It's not that these ruin the film for me; it's just that the film never really gets beyond these into any meaningful story. 
In summary, this is a nice technical film.  However, _Magnolia_ is superior in every way (incidentally, not only to this film, but to many others as well.)

The camera work is amateurish (to the point of being comical in parts), half the acting is laughable (esp Wahlberg - his performance in the actual film is as stiff and unnatural as his performance in the adult films they're supposed to be shooting). It's basically a low budget film, trying to be an independent artistic film, but only succeeding in being so far up its own behind that (despite the number of truly talented actors like Julianne Moore), it manages to succeed only in patting itself of the back for bringing the shallow vision of a depraved pervert to life.
Don't get me wrong, I'm no prude, but there's zero artistic redemption here - just an excuse for "actors" to pretend they're making porn.
How this garnered any sort of accolades or attention beyond ironic laughter is beyond me.Literally, as I'm sitting here, re-watching it, every time Mark Wahlberg is on the screen, I'm taken out of the moment and reminded that he's just a horrible actor whom Hollywood is trying desperately for everyone to consider a star.Pure and utter tripe.

Curiosity drew me to this picture and I was not disappointed. It was very well casted and entertaining. Burt Reynolds, like fine wine, gets better with age. He has gone far beyond his Smokey and the Bandit days and keeps the focus of the film. The music was a big part of the 70's and is a big part of the movie as well. Don't expect Shakespeare, but overall, this is THE definitive disco era porn industry picture.

A richly told, compelling, fictional look at the porn industry in the late 1970's/early 1980's.  Somewhat surprisingly, the film isn't particularly glamorous or sexy  in fact, at times it's incredibly sad and depressing. The overall story deals with the successes that the characters enjoy within their own secluded little world of adult films . . . and the failures they encounter when they dare to reach for more.  The rest of the world views them as perverts, as criminals . . . or, worst of all, as pathetic jokes, which probably hurts most of all.The ensemble cast of `Boogie Nights' is nothing short of awesome.  Mark Wahlberg is Dirk Diggler (loosely based on the real adult film star John Holmes), a man endowed with a rather large gift  unfortunately, it isn't a brain.  He puts in a great performance as a very earnest, self-deluded guy who hasn't the faintest idea how to deal with his own success.  Frankly, I'm amazed he wasn't nominated for an Oscar for this role, and I never thought I'd ever say that about a guy who used to call himself Marky Mark.  Julianne Moore is terrific as Amber Waves, the porn starlet who acts as a mother figure to the other people (particularly the men) in her films.  William H. Macy is pathetically funny and tragic as Little Bill, and Phillip Seymour Hoffman is excellent as Scotty, the production guy who hangs out with these porn stars as his sad little way of being close to fame.  Don Cheadle, John C. Reilly, Heather Graham, (even Nina Hartley, an actual porn actress!). . . the list of knockout performances goes on and on.  I'd also be remiss if I failed to mention Burt Reynolds' turn as Jack Horner, the porn producer who likes to think he's making quality films for the masses.  Watching Reynolds in this film put in a quiet, understated performance without his typical mugging or hamming it up for the camera was a real treat, a remind of why Reynolds was once considered a truly great actor.Director P.T. Anderson is clearly a fan of Robert Altman and Martin Scorsese  their influences show up not only in how Anderson deals with an ensemble cast, but in his choices of sweeping camera shots, of music, and how he often chooses to unfold his story.  That's okay, because he also manages to take those influences and make something quite original  and very gut-wrenching. `Boogie Nights' is a marvelous tale.  Watch it.  A

Review title: Brilliant! Nothing short of a firework! **minor spoilers**
Review_body: The cast is great, Anderson's direction is beautifully visual and character based. Boogie Nights has a real feel quality. That said, I think Alfred Molina almost steals the show. The fire cracker scene is brilliant. The guys have come to sell bad drugs and are already nervous and what is there waiting for them..? A rich yuppie on dope, bodyguard the size of Grand Canyon and a little asian fella throwing fire crackers all over the place. Humor at it's best. Boogie Nights is warm, but funny. On the edge, but still respectful. A masterpiece!***** / *****

This is the first movie of Mr. Anderson's that I became acquainted with. The second was "Magnolia" Obvious parallels can be drawn between the two in terms of style and presentation."Boogie Nights" is an awesome achievement and is the first movie you come to realize just how good an actor Mark Wahlberg really is. This movie elevated him from more than just another pretty face to a true actor courtesy of a magnificent performance. It was actually heartbreaking to watch at times. Of course, the fact that he was surrounded by a stellar cast certainly contributed to such an impressive performance.This is a biting look at the porn industry of the 70s and is supposedly loosely based on the life of real-life porn king, John Holmes. Nonetheless, the performances are positively phenomenal. With a cast including Don Cheadle, Julianne Moore, William H. Macy, Phillip Seymour Hoffman, Burt Reynolds, John C. Reily, the often overlooked Luis Guzman, Heather Graham; need I say more? It is an unflinching look at the industry and a rather disturbing one to be sure. There is also no real or structured "plot" per say, but the focus is on the impact this particular lifestyle had on the personal lives of the participants and those closest to them.This is an excellent exercise in character study and is most worthy of any movie collection. Do yourself a favor and pick it up. You will NOT be disappointed.

I remember when initially wanting to watch this film I thought it would be very juvenile and risqué for the sake of being risqué, but in the end I found something different: a great film that was entertaining and at times fairly meaningful. It was very well-written, well-filmed, and a sad, dark portrayal of how the world can be as a place. Although this film is undeniably for mature audiences, it is the sort of film that has enough meaning built into the shock to really justify the shocking nature of it. Not to mention that, but it is the sort of film that satisfies the curiosity into the world in which Dirk lived. Throughout the whole film the acting is exceptionally well, being such an easy film to get sucked into. I think that the wide appeal for the film comes from its' thoroughness in character portrayal as well as the depth that each character has when it is cultivated in such a short amount of time; each person who appears in the film is more than just an image on the screen, but with the passage of time, you really see them as actual people. It is a movie that, while watching it, you simply forget it is a movie due to the perfection that Paul Thomas Anderson achieves in his realistic, no-holds barred film. I especially enjoy how Dirk Diggler is portrayed with his beaming innocence and simple mind: it makes one see nothing sinister about him, but it lends to the viewer an air of a certain objectivity and lack of judgmental sentiment as they watch the entirety of the porn world unfold around this character.Overall, I recommend this film to everyone who can appreciate good film and has the stomach for sometimes rather edgy and racy material.

Review title: I want 2 hrs of my life back!
Review_body:
This "film", for lack of a better word, is so bad and on so many levels that a book could be written about it. The only good thing about it is that it shows complete lack of story or character sense among Hollywood crowd and actors who participated in it.
The plot is beyond boring, characters are shallower than any of the Marvel Comics, and the pacing is so bad that I had to fast forward through most of the scenes, The film actually starts around the 2 hour mark, but even that is hardly made worth of a big screen or any screen at all.
Funny, I've been wanting to see it but something always made me leave it for later, Now, 24 years after it came out and I finally saw it, I wish I never even knew about it, it is that bad. I don't even recommend it as an example of a bad film - only maybe as an example of a worthless, time-wasting, self-indulgent stupidity.
The movie is 2 hours and 35 minutes. It could've been 1 hour and 30 minutes. Too long.

Could anybody tell me what the hell this movie was all about. Please! It deserves none of it's reputation, it is utterly boring, with characters that never develop, who we never get to really know, or understand or give a damn about,a meandering storyline that never goes anywhere. One thinks this would have been possible in a movie that is almost three hours long. Sheesh! Forget it.

There are a lot of familiar faces in "Boogie Nights" which combine with an interesting story and imaginative directing to make for a very good movie. Set in the late seventies in "the Valley" (across the Santa Monica Mountains from LA) the movie chronicles a small group of people who have found themselves in the business of producing pornographic films; in particular a young man who assumes the stage name of "Dirk Diggler" (Marky Mark himself in a surprisingly earnest performance).A high school drop-out busboy at a nearby nightclub (not unlike the set-up for the vastly inferior "54") Marky Mark is noticed by an "Adult" film producer (Burt Reynolds) for a specific anatomical aberration conducive to a career in pornography.  Leaving an unhappy home situation, he joins the film making family of Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, and Philip Seymour Hoffman, among other actors who have since become "stars" in their own right.  (Luis Guzman and Don Cheadle also appear, foreshadowing an appearance together a decade later as the detectives in "Traffic").As this group struggles to maintain some sense self amongst their failed lives, false celluloid intimacy and cocaine induced escapism we follow their stories and the (mis)fortunes of their industry.  There is no overwrought preaching (or rationalization of drug use) and the harshness and sadness of their lives is somewhat compelling, and even touching as they try to move on. The hokey dialogue and cheapo sets of the porno films are convincingly reconstructed (or so I can only assume...) and the tawdriness of their lives made transparent without resorting to becoming what it describes (although Miss Graham and Miss Moore are briefly shown "at work") or alienating the audience from the people of the story.It is a brilliant piece of film-making, and very well worth a look, not only as the recreation of an era (very well done with music and dancing of the period) but also as a very human story.
So many great characters, so many great arcs, an outstanding character piece. PTA's direction is bolstered by such an amazing cast.

Review title: A movie about the sex industry that tells a solid tale
Review_body: Boogie Nights was for me a spectacular movie. What I was expecting and what I got were very far apart, but I liked what I saw better than the preconceived notions I had before seeing the film. Mark Wahlberg, Julianne Moore, Burt Reynolds, Heather Graham, John C. Reilly, and the rest of the ensemble cast put on a great performance for this movie, and I liked how it told a cohesive story from the good beginnings to the tragic middle to the sort of redemptive ending. I liked the whole main narrative, but of particular interest to me was the subplot that surrounded the character played by Don Cheadle. I think that one could've been a story of its own. For a movie about the 70's sex industry, there was surprisingly, a lesser amount of sex than you might have thought there would be. I think the decision to do the movie that way paid off in more than avoiding an NC-17 rating. With the sex not as explicit, there was more time to focus on character development and plot. I remember thinking to myself that although not exactly the two parents, 2.2 kids, picket fence and garage stereotype, that the characters were a family, with all the good and bad events that happen in a time frame, and they for the most part managed to survive all that was thrown at them.

The three names that mean the most to this film are Burt Reynolds, Mark Wahlberg, and Julianne Moore. These three deliver the strongest performances, but the entire cast does a wonderful job. The film although about the porn industry does not let itself get out of hand with it's own sexual premise.
