Burt Reynolds was great as Jack Horner, the director who made money with young energy and the coming trends, but realized he had to be "father" to all those aging stars who had nowhere else to go once the bright lights began to flicker and the money was getting thin.

Don't waste your time! How did this film fall in the hands of the greedy marketing business people who hyped it out of all proportion. Yeah, a film about the 70's could have been really cool, but that's exactly what this is not. This is a third rate film with bad acting, and no plot. Go rent Saturday Night Feaver instead!

Posited on the not uninteresting notion that cinematic entertainment is to be found in the lives of a bunch of people who spend most of their time in a state of undress, Paul Thomas Anderson's `Boogie Nights' is less a reminder of its intended era  the 1970s  as of some 100 years earlier, when `The Emperor's New Clothes' was all the rage.Satire purveyed as fairytale, this attacked the self-serving pomposity of a European cultural elite as represented by a sycophantic Court so in thrall to its Emperor that whatever he said, and whatever he did, was unfailingly marvellous. Even when he appeared stark naked and invited admiration of his new clothes, response was fulsome and unquestioning.Fast forward from Andersen's fairy tale to Anderson's film and it's clear from the reviews of so many US critics that the court is still in full swing: the references to Boogie's richness of tapestry and brilliance of detailing could just as well have been culled from the parroting so deservedly ridiculed in `Emperor'.Like Andersen's fairy tale, Anderson's film is about people with no clothes: porno actors doing their thing in 1977's California. Directorially, Anderson is at one with his subject because he hasn't any clothes, either, hence two and quarter hour's worth of the ransacking of other directors' wardrobes.Unfortunately, cinematic dress sense is lacking: where others went for style with purpose, Anderson goes for style per se. The opening sequence is Nicholls-out-of-Altman-out-of-Welles, a three-minute tracking shot concluding with a character on roller skates who promptly absents herself to go for a pee. Dramatic, or what? (One assumes that, out of shot, she then handed over the skates to the camera operator, so that thereafter the lens may hurtle around one static set-up after another in hope of signifying vitality). Anderson, however, has more in his armory than tracking shots and roller skates: Nicholas Ray is in a sub-sub-Deanish confrontation between the film's hero and his deranged mamma; Tarantino arrives as soon as people start shooting each other; Scorsese gets comprehensively ripped off in the unintentionally hilarious climactic scene. As for the bit when Anderson follows a character into the swimming pool and under the surface, a round of applause seems appropriate for Jacques Cousteau.The problem with all this laborious artifice is not that it's there, but that it's there for no reason: you swoop your way into a night club and find absolutely nothing happening, plunge into a pool and, er, find absolutely nothing happening. In fact, so often do you find absolutely nothing at all happening that it's no wonder Anderson finally gets bored himself and moves from sex to its stereotypical concomitant, violence.As a comedy about the porn industry, about the fatuity of its mainstream aspirations and the self-deception of its principal exponents, `Boogie Nights' could have been a refreshing entertainment, audacious yet affectionate, searching yet sympathetic. Unfortunately though, Anderson's script never gets over the novelty of its own pitch -- a movie about 1970s porno people: gosh, wow, how radical!  and, thus mesmerised, plots its characters' rise and fall in more pedestrian fashion than any porno chronicle of tumescence and aftermath.In the role of the hero, Mark Wahlberg is defeated from the outset: Anderson's script makes him a sleazoid from scene 1, thereby denying any opportunity for examination of innocence traduced. Wahlberg's little sleazoid is disowned by his bonkers mother and becomes a big sleazoid courtesy of his ability to handle a very large part in a succession of porno movies. At this point, Anderson could have found the iconoclasm these dismal proceedings so urgently need and had Dirk Diggle' living in a mansion and endowing a new hospital. But no: middle-America knows porn is bad, so ergo, the people in it must all come to a bad end. And so Anderson obliges the Moral Majority, trying, but failing, to obscure the predictability of the redemptive route by constructing setpiece events more bizarre than anything encountered by Bunyan's Pilgrim. Discarded by the porno people because of the so-sad truth that there's always a, how can one put it, a new up-and-comer, Dirk sets off to be a singing star, a surprising career move given that he hasn't so much whistled in any preceding scene. More surprising, however, is the fact that Dirk has somehow lost house, car, and bank account in remarkably short time, a disaster that might have elicited some sympathy had Anderson's script bothered to mention it. Instead, all the audience discovers is that the world's most famous and richest porno actor is cruelly thwarted his dream of being a recording star. . . because he can't afford the cost of a demo. Hmm. Sad.Inexplicably bankrupt and demonstrably unmusical, you'd have thought Dirk's mortification was complete. But no: he's now landed in a Tarantino setpiece filmed through one of Fellini's old view-finders, and thus winds up with two ex-porno friends in the baronial living room of a rich loony to whom they'd dearly love to sell baking soda masquerading as coke if only the loony's Asian houseboy would stop running around letting off Chinese fire crackers. Breathtaking cinema? Had an introduction been here effected of a nun on a pogo stick playing a bugle, it's likely US critics would have signed a petition to ensure Anderson's Oscar.As to the fate of others, two are worthy of mention: porno film director Jack Horner, played by Burt Reynolds, and porno actor Buck Swope, played by Don Cheadle. Reynolds, inexplicably nominated for an acting award, decides early on that Jack Horner sat in a corner and thus spends most of the movie doing just that. His expression is glazed and his directorial input, zilch: it's as if the material over which he presides has a life of its own, and somnambulism is all that's required. (The same thought probably occurred to Anderson). Cheadle, whose career  unlike Reynolds's -- at least looks like surviving this tripe, has a more lively time of it: his character wants to move from low-life to hi-fi, to have his own store in order to sell the eight track cartridge players depicted by Anderson as quintessential 1977 regardless of the fact that by then they were all museum pieces anyway.Although the bank refuses to provide the substantial financing a hi-fi store clearly needs, Cheadle strikes it lucky by first walking into a small bakery to buy doughnuts and then, Bruce Willis-like, by finding himself the Last Man Standing when a homicidal maniac rushes in (as they do, as they do) and everyone else winds up dead. Drenched in gore or possibly, raspberry jam, Cheadle stares at the money the maniac would've taken. There must be all of twenty dollars there. Can he resist the temptation? Apparently not, because in his next scene there he is, proudly opening a new landmark on the block, his very own hi-fi store.That you could buy and equip a hi-fi store with just 20 dollars will come as a surprise to all those who remember the 1970s. Anderson, at 26, doesn't, so it's little wonder that the film overall is about as historically accurate as "Ben Hur".Still. `Boogie Nights' is a triumph of sorts, in much the same way that Cheadle's hi-fi store was. With minimal investment in wit, originality or imagination, this unlikely construct has nevertheless been hailed as a landmark on the cinematic block, its distinctly rightwing triteness blithely misrepresented as exactly the opposite. There's no doubt Anderson does have talent, and once he gets over the preoccupation with being young, radical, and free to nick everybody else's directorial styles, he could well assert an identity of his own, beginning, perhaps, with a script that surprises and characters that engage with more than each other.For the US critics though, no redemption is in sight: they're probably still in court now, praising the clothes of the naked director, still listening to their eight tracks and claiming it's real fidelity. . .
ends
Usually I don't watch dramatic movies but I really enjoyed this. Great acting by everyone, especially Mark Wahlberg. Not one for the kids but if you haven't seen it, check it out

Review title: Some much has already been said...so I'll add these few thoughts...
Review_body: This is a film so solid and well-crafted that I can't come up with (nor should come up with) a lengthy diatribe on why I liked it. So, here are five simple reasons why it's one of the greatest films of, if not simply the 90's, the last 40-50 years of cinema:1. Potentially the greatest ensemble cast put before a camera (Hoffman, Hall, Guzman, Moore, Macy, Reilly, Reynolds, Wahlberg, Cheadle, etc.)2. Absolutely the most danceable soundtrack that can double as a time capsule of the greatest dance hits of the 70's.3. Any film that can generate enough quotes to be used extensively in an ESPN.com article as allegories for the NBA and NOT be a film about basketball is a sign of a golden script. (By the way, the article I speak of, "Boogie Hoops," is hilarious.) Say any line from this movie at a party loud enough, and you'll have another shouted back. Go on. Do it.4. It shows, in raw, realistic fashion, the classic hero arc--and set against the contrasting values of the 70's and 80's, no less.5. It makes you care about the characters without telling you that you have to.(Bonus Reasons: 6. Any film that includes the song "You Got the Touch"--originally from "Transformers: The Movie"--needs to be bowed down to. 7. Heather Graham.)

What a movie.I really have never seen a better mix of surprise, drama, action, and even subtle comedy, with amazing camerawork and a mindblowing script. Within two years, Mark Wahlberg will be known among the top two or three actors out there, he is that good. Aside from his performance, great work was turned in by Burt Reynolds, Julianne Moore, and Heather Graham. John C. Reilly, who played Wahlberg's partner, and fellow star Don Cheadle were amazing in smaller roles.No lie, I would recommend this movie - gratuitous sex, violence, and dialogue included - to anyone and everyone. I have truly never seen a better movie. It will blow your mind.

Review title: One of the worst of the very bad 70's era movies I've seen yet....
Review_body: Somewhere between "Requiem for a Dream", "Magnolia" (both of which I appreciated, if did not enjoy immensely), and "Saturday Night Fever" and "Fast Times at Ridgemont High", this movie might sound like it should be funny or clever, but is just painfully long, overdone, with too many characters and too little plot/meaning, etc.  An extreme waste of time, in my humble opinion.... but I'm glad there are those of you out there who like it... more power to you.  The one thing movies like this do for me is feel like "Man, have I got my life together!" (not something I usually think about...

A small town kid working in a big city becomes a huge star and then spirals out of control. It shows you the rise to fame and then fall from fame and back to a little rise. Great cast of actors, and a great director = a great, great movie called Boogie Nights.P.T Anderson. An amazing director who made Boogie Nights amazing. From the moment the movie starts to the moment it ends you can feel how beautiful this movie is. Some scenes are breathtaking, literally. A great story, a great movie. Mark Whalberg was fantastic, Philip Seymour Hoffman was wonderful as he is in everything. Thomas Jane also was magnificent and although he only had a small part he played it to perfection. There is one scene in this movie I can't get over, "The Drug Deal Gone Bad Scene" it was amazing, music acting and cinematography combined to make it amazing. I hadn't seen Boogie Nights and thank god I did, its so well rounded and I am now a HUGE fan of PTA (Paul Thomas Anderson).Do whatever you have to do and watch this movie.

Review title: It could so easily have been ruined!
Review_body: Here I am ten years later writing about what a good movie BOOGIE NIGHTS was; of course I'd heard about it, but...It's a movie about the porno industry for God's sake. And they didn't go overboard like BRYOND THE VALLEY OF THE DOLLS, or maudlin like STRIPTEASE or for that piece-of-garbage look that that thing with Kyle MacLachlan In it (SHOWGIRLS) went for and achieved.Brilliant casting makes for a pretty good show. My favoutite casting job was MILLER'S CROSSING, but there were also LORD OF THE RINGS, GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS and many more. BOOGIE NIGHTS raised the bar for predictive casting. Let me see ... who did I know before I saw them in this movie? Okay, Burt Reynolds. I knew Ron Ridgely was in PHILADELPHIA and William Macy starred in HOMICIDE. I had heard of a few of the rest but Burt Reynolds was the only household name; Now reflect on how early in the careers of these great actors was BOOGIE NIGHTS: Macy, Don Cheadle, Julianne Moore, John C. Reiley, Mark Wahlberg, Alfred Molina, Phillip Seymore Hoffman, Heather Graham. One last comment: I have never seen a movie with Philip Baker Hall or Rickey Jay that I didn't enjoy a lot.

Dear lord! This movie was too long and just dumb. There were so many scenes that didn't make sense and weren't really needed. I mean what were they thinking when they made this movie? The plot line was a good idea, but the movie itself sucked! And I'm sure we all know that once you've seen one pair of boobs, you've seen them all! Seriously! And there are two questions I'm sure we all want to know: Was that his real penis? AND was that really 13 inches.. doubtful. I don't think I can ever look at Mark Wahlberg the same in any movie now. So, Mark Wahlberg congratulations on being the greatest porn star ever, in the worst movie ever. This was one movie I would NEVER tell a friend to watch because it just sucked that bad.

Review title: When sex was safe and business was pleasure
Review_body: Boogie Nights opens with a shot that lasts for 2 minutes and 55 seconds. The words Boogie Nights appear on the screen, but within the universe of the film; the name of a nightclub, which the camera spins away from and onto the entrance of another nightclub. The camera snakes inside, following several primary characters interacting with each other, while patrons dance and drink, all soundtracked by a rocking 70's soul tune. What a way to start a film. Paul Thomas Anderson was only 26 when he made this.In fact, looking at the context of the writer-director's age, it's a ridiculously ambitious movie. We are thrown, for 148 relentless minutes, into the world of the 70's porn industry, a challenging topic to make into an accessible film; but Anderson succeeds with ease. We sympathise with these strange characters and their strangely innocent world, and with Mark Wahlberg's well-meaning and well-endowed Dirk Diggler. "Dirk", real name Eddie, is a lowly dishwasher at that nightclub in the first scene with a reputation for his gigantic member. Taken under the wing of Burt Reynolds' director, he grows to become a porn superstar. And then, just as Diggler's career hits its peak, it goes downhill as the 70's literally turns into the 80's. The fall side of this rise-and-fall plot is catalysed by, at a New Year 1980 party, one of the most shocking and brilliantly handled screen deaths I've ever seen. The film's second half is chaotic and messy, but feels intentionally so; the tight structure of the opening hour unravelling as the character's lives fall apart. I mentioned before the strange innocence of the porn industry. It's seen in the hilarious in-porn dialogue, in the Margherita-soaked parties, in Reynold's dream to be a real, artistically valid director making real art. As film gives way to video and that visual aesthetic is lost, we start to see the effects of drug abuse, of ego, of exploiting women, and of an industry that is dangerously linked to real crime. There is a violent scene in a donut shop that seems indulgent and pointless, and a subplot with Julianne Moore that doesn't really go anywhere. Some may feel that the running time is excessive, and they'd have a point; but I wasn't bored for a second. It's funny, shocking, sexy, ugly, and frightening at all the right moments. There's an obvious debt to Goodfellas in style, plot, and yes, the long shots; but it's never a pastiche or ripoff. That's partly because of Anderson's assured and confident direction, partly because California and porn offers such a nice contrast to New York and gangsters. John C Reilly and Philip Seymour Hoffman offer excellent supporting work, and the soundtrack is fantastic. Boogie Nights is vibrant, effortlessly entertaining and intelligently made cinema.

Review title: A funny and engaging saga of dreams, debauchery, and the search for belongingness.
Review_body: The very beginning of Boogie Nights sets the tone for the entire picture. A melancholy piece of sentimental music plays over a black screen before being quickly drowned out by an explosion of upbeat disco. It's almost as though PT Anderson wanted the audience to feel like they just snorted a line of cocaine. The brilliant tracking shot that follows does a fantastic job of introducing all the characters, but it is that first screen that sets the tone; Boogie Nights is not about the glitz and glamor of its time period, but rather the sadness and desperation that lies beneath the gilded surface.The film follows a well-endowed and starry-eyed teenager named Eddie Adams (Mark Wahlberg), who escapes the turmoil of his home life by immersing himself in the sex and drug-fueled world of disco-dancing and hardcore pornography. Porn mogul Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds)and the sexy yet maternal Amber Waves (Julianne Moore)take Eddie under their wing, adopting him into their own twisted 'family', which Eddie is eager to join. As Eddie changes his persona to Dirk Diggler, the line between his real self and his on screen persona begins to blur, and the humbleness of his Eddie Adams is replaced by the ego-crazed arrogance of Dirk Diggler.After watching Boogie Nights time and time again, I have come to realize how truly unique it is in that the tonal shifts of the plot seem natural rather than jarring. There is a lot of humor in this movie, and at the same time a lot of sadness. Like all great filmmakers, PT Anderson is a master at playing with the audience's emotions. Boogie Nights, as well as his next film Magnolia, are emotional roller coaster rides. The key to mastering this is good characterization and seamless tonal shifts, both of which Boogie Nights succeeds in getting right.Tone is hard to define, but it can make or break a film. If a comedy is too serious, then it doesn't work. If a drama isn't taking itself seriously enough, then it doesn't work. Boogie Nights somehow manages to find that balance throughout its many tonal shifts, and for that it is a unique film watching experience.Perhaps the biggest strength in PT Anderson's films is his attention to detail in regards to his characters. In this ensemble cast, almost all of the characters undergo an emotional journeys of some sort. The fact that even the most ancillary characters have a storyline makes the film seem more realistic, and this makes it easier for the audience to sympathize with their struggles.The acting in the film is mostly superb, although truthfully I found a few scenes a bit too melodramatic. Mark Wahlberg did a good job, but in some scenes I feel he has a tendency to overact. However this is a minor gripe, and in the overall scheme he does a fantastic job revealing the emotional nuances of his character. John C. Reilly plays my favorite character in the film, Reed Rothschild, Dirk Diggler's best friend and eternal man-child.Julianne Moore gives a highly emotional and affecting performance, and Burt Reynolds is, for once, not completely annoying.On the contrary, he gives another fantastic performance. Heather Graham is great eye candy for the film, but her character has a lot more depth than her 'rollergirl' persona might suggest. In some ways I find her storyline more interesting than Dirk's.As someone who is a big fan of the music, films, and culture of the late 70's and early 80's, the setting of Boogie Nights appeals to me a great deal. The soundtrack is phenomenal, and the film uses it in some very unique ways. For example, who could forget Dirk's rendition of 'The Touch'? If you haven't seen the film yet, its worth watching for that scene alone! The film seems to have an appreciation for the time period, but also uses the changes of the period to represent changes in the characters, such as when the primary medium of porn changed from film to tape. This is masterfully done and a unique way to tell the story.Boogie Nights is a finely crafted and emotionally engaging film that engrosses you not only in its story, but in its characters and setting as well. Its one of those films you can watch time and time again and never get tired because there is simply so much to appreciate. The only things holding it back from masterpiece status are some stilted performances, but for the most part it is a great achievement.

This film IS utterly amazing, their are no faults that are apparent in the viewing of this modern masterpiece. the music is exciting, fun, sometimes sad and fits it appointed scene perfectly, the characters about as prolific and interesting as ones you'd see in Pulp Fiction or American Beauty and the story... from dish boy to porn icon, the story of Dirk Diggler is one that'll stay in the mind of those who care to watch not only because it's so heart breaking, original and crazy but also due to the absolutely extraordinary portrayal by Mark Whalberg whose accompanied by other actors who give their all; Burt Reynolds, John C Reilly, Julianne Moore, Thomas Jane, Alfred Molina. All this is brought together by PT Anderson and his writing and directing that make the film perfect.

PTA's new comedy "Inherent Vice" to be released, I saw this title again.Every time the long take of the opening is overlooked. In the commentary, the director said that he was influenced by Martin Scorsese movies, but I think that the long take is a good match for Good Fellows and others.
There are quite a lot of characters, but each one has a perfect view, all of which plays a role to complement the main actor and the story, and it is calculated.I like the last in the same way as Raging Bull, but unlike that I'm in the last with salvation, which I like this.Directing, acting, screenwriting, music, arts I think that it is very first class, one representing the 1990s.RIP Philip Seymour Hoffman and Burt Reynolds

P.T Anderson, is one of America's best directors. This is no Magnolia yet, but still a compelling film that gives a great inside of the adult film industry. In 1977, when the story starts, porno movies are shot on film and play in theaters, and a director can dream of making one so good that the audience members would want to stay in the theater even after they had achieved what they came for. By 1983, when the story closes, pornos have shifted to video and most of the movies are basically just loops. I think many people pass up "Boogie Nights" cause they are anti-porn, or just flat out hate the adult industry and can't overlook that aspect of this film. But underneath that is a great story about characters losing everything and battle to regain themselves. This is a beautiful film... and it's too bad that enough people can't see that.

I viewed BOOGIE NIGHTS recently (Feb.2005) and thought during the DVD that the film would have been banned everywhere including Korea,several years ago. Mainstream Hollywood movies could not show a man and a woman in bed together and if they did , both actors had to have one foot on the floor during the scene. The words such as "Pregnant" and words referring to a woman's breasts or a man's penis were never allowed so this film means Hollywood has moved farther OR sunken deeper in trying to find what the public wants to see and spend it's money on. Burt Reynolds was the first man to appear in a nude centerfold picture in the woman's PLAYGIRL magazine and played a woman chasing Senator in the movie STRIPTEASE, so he is right to play the Porno film director in this movie that tries to show the way pornographic films were made during the 1970's to 1980's. Mark Wahlberg(later in the Planet of the Apes remake?)plays the young stud that Burt finds to star next in his porno flicks. Julianne Moore,Heather Graham(Austin Powers)and actual porno Star Nina Hartley("Head Nurse",etc....) have parts in the film. In a scale of one to ten with ten the best, I give Boogie Nights afive.

So great movie, nice story .. but there were flaws which added extra B.S to the Movie,,,, No doubt the movie is good but the movie is so long which which becomes boring at certain point n makes you think of these certain scenes which were completely irrelevant. These are as follows Firstly useless characters like the guy shooting himself n his wife, the gay one, n the black guy .. their roles dint matter in the movie ... was in fact leading somewhere else. The Movie becomes boring when the director fires(not exactly) the main character .. This was just something to increase the movie timings nothing else .. but its better to work on quality rather than quantityN one more thing ... i don't think the movie name goes with the movie , if it had been the adventures of Dirk Diggler something like that, it would have been great .. Now coming to the GOOD POINTS .. it was good combination of Exotic n Erotic Scenes .. a couple scenes were very good n its always good to watch celebrity sex ... kind of gets u turn ON .. Most importantly it tells the history of Porn industry , how the golden era of porn changed through 1980's .. n the introduction of sex videotapewell at the end i should tell u that i have gone too deep to provide my reviews n u may consider these flaws have been explained in to detail, so overall i consider it a good movie and a must watch moviei'll give it a 7.5/10 ..

It would appear that my appreciation for this film is in the minority, and without much support from other viewers. If anyone shares my feelings, maybe they have enough sense not to watch. I wondered why this topic would qualify for a satire, and because of its critical acclaim and awards/nominations, I decided to watch to find out. For me it was a waste of time. I'm not especially offended by porn, but I'm not excited by it either. It's not a substitute for the real thing, and if you've seen one porn film, you'e seen them all. And if this film has any more to offer, it was lost on me.

Review title: A cartoonish ripoff of Goodfellas meant to appeal to adolescents who like the topic of porn
Review_body: Having grown up on watching movies and having no reason for making them other than to ape his idols, Anderson lifts the template from Scorsese's Goodfellas in this adolescent ripoff. Tell me - Which film am I describing here? Narrative structure: Set primarily over the course of the mid-1970s through the 80s, a young high-schooler has troubles at home and has to live with abusive family members. He feels trapped in this environment, and to help him escape, he grows attached to a surrogate family whose activities revolve around moral and societal vice. He finds that he excels in this environment and rises quickly in this new family hierarchy, earning both respect and riches from it. He eventually becomes fully initiated into this new family when he passes a test that demonstrates his commitment and talent to the vices that they support, and he is then rewarded by this new family with a celebration. At near mid-point, a "retro reel" involving 8mm or 16mm home movies and photos are used in a montage to express the passage of time and the deepening relationship between our protagonist and the other members of his new family. Things are going swimmingly until, at what is supposed to be a fun social occasion among friends, violence unexpectedly breaks out, resulting in murder and death. This scene mid-way through the plot tells the viewer that not all is well within this "fun" social structure, and that its very mores helped to contribute to the mindset that would lead someone to murder. But our protagonist tries to brush aside this violent event as a mere aberration, not wanting to question social world he has embraced. After eventually reaching a pinnacle of success, cultural shifts along with an infusion of drug abuse drag our protagonist down to the point where the same elements stemming from the vice and the surrogate family he joined now work against him until he hits rock bottom. When he hits rock bottom, he has a falling out with his surrogate "father figure" who turns against him for his betrayals and now uncontrollable drug use. All of this nearly kills him - but he still manages to survive rock bottom (unlike some of his friends around him). He is eventually able to pull himself up from rock bottom and settle into a less-than-ideal but by no means awful life, wistfully thinking back on the good times and how they are likely gone forever. Stylistic elements: Wall-to-wall music to help set tone, establish the time setting and occasionally provide an additional commentary on the action itself. Swish-pans, rapid editing sequences to convey frenetic energy, punctuated by extensive dolly and tracking shots to convey more leisurely times of our characters and cover the spaces of the lively nightclubs that they frequent. Title cards placed late in the film in order to subtly tell the viewer that the upcoming scene, times or sequences will be especially significant to the lives of the characters, followed by a shift in editing style to highlight the stresses that the protagonist has gotten himself into - which systematically builds the dramatic tension in the sequence until it results in a conclusive tipping point in his life. Which movie am I describing here? Boogie Nights? Or Goodfellas? Which one came first again? The final scene where our protagonist talks to himself in the mirror and looks back on his experiences is obviously ripped off from Raging Bull rather than Goodfellas, but that is still another Scorsese work.Anderson has nothing to say other than he wants to be thought of as a great director, but he needs to ape the true pioneers that came before him to make that happen. He just needed to make sure he adapted Scorsese's work into the porn world in order to appeal to his adolescent male fan base that eats up anything that helps mainstream their sexual fantasies. Don't fall for the hype. This is an extremely derivative, mediocre work.

This is such a good movie. P. T. (Paul Thomas) Anderson's first attempt was with the 1996, Hard Eight, starring Samuel L. Jackson and Gwyneth Paltrow. This was a good attempt at an Inde movie but Boogie Nights blew my mind!! The character study was amazing! The most interesting part was during the 80's when they go to make the coke deal. Anyway see it for yourself!! 10 times better than Titanic!!

Review title: Good period piece about the pitfalls of the porn industry of the late 70s-early 80s.
Review_body: Boogie Nights is an excellent period piece of the late 70s and early 80s porn industry, but is really just a fable about the dangers of egotism and self-indulgence. We watch Eddie transform from a simple good-hearted busboy to the biggest star of the adult cinema industry, with all the money, women and drugs that come with that fame. The movie ends with the predictable moral that taking yourself too seriously leads to failure, as we watch all of the actor-characters sink into their own personal hells, as they mistake their fame and money for personal talent and success, only to realize too late that they're being consumed by the business that feeds their instant gratification. Burt Reynolds is excellent as the father figure director who is the center of the group of porn actors he recruits. Bill Macy turns in his usual great performance in a small role as the cinematographer whose wife (played by Nina Hartley, as an inside joke to all the porn fans in the audience!) can't stop having very public sex with other men, every chance she gets.

Review title: One of the top five, where were the Oscars?
Review_body: Boogie Nights was absolutely one of the top five films last year. The intense heat of the script and the performance from the actors is on such a level that I thought it was a great shame that this film didn´t get any Oscars at last year´s Academy Award. The film reminds me a lot of Pulp Fiction and Goodfellas in terms of characterization and dialogue. The scene with the "Chaotic" new years celebration as well as the scene with Alfred Molina as a crack-smoking drug customer must go down as one of the most exciting moments in  a film for a very long time. A must see!

Review title: How did they manage to make this film so boring?
Review_body: Most people have a view on pornography... except it would seem Paul Thomas Anderson. This film fails to tackle it's subject matter with any depth, it is neither funny, moving or shocking. It could and should have been all three. Instead it looks like PTA spent too long in film school instead of the real world. I kept waiting for the film to start... it eventually seemed to get going an hour and a half into the film. But by then it was too late... I didn't care about any of the characters and it descended into formulaic pap about divorced mum misses kids, good time girl wanting an education, arrogant stud turning cheap tricks, arrogant film maker having to face up to reality. A slice of violence and a happy ending. This is pure vomitsville...

Review title: They handled the subject matter very well with little exploitation.
Review_body: This  was a very good movie that showed the late 70s and early 80s realistically.  They showed a human side to the  adult film industry.  The sound track was very good.

Review title: Brilliant, masterful piece of filmmaking. A classic.
Review_body: Brilliant, original, thrilling, hilarious, touching.  Please choose from this list of words in describing what is, quite probably, my favorite film ever made.  Paul Thomas Anderson showed flashes of genius in his debut, Hard Eight, in 1996; and in 1997, he all but solidified his place in the Director's Hall of Fame.  Everything about "Boogie Nights" is pristine, from the 5 minute one-shot introductory scene, to Anderson's fluid camerawork, to the pinpointed details of a turbulent social era.  Mark Wahlberg is perfectly cast as Eddie Adams AKA Dirk Diggler, the boy wonder who makes a HUGE name for himself in the adult film world.  Julianne Moore and Burt Reynolds were properly praised for their career-making and reviving roles, respectively.  And the strong supporting cast of John C. Reilly, Heather Graham, Don Cheadle and William H Macy provide enough comic relief to make it through the 2 and a half hour epic.  The most impressive aspect of this late 90's classic (besides the terrific music) is that these pornographers/drug users/general lowlife actually warrant sympathy and even sometimes, love.  Anderson's amazing script makes you FEEL for these people like no other script could.(with this subject matter anyway)  WARNING: This movie's biggest knock is that it's far too long, but my tip is this....become a slave to Anderson's masterpiece, and you won't find a better two and a half hours you could spend.  Paul Thomas Anderson is the man to watch for the 21st Century, and with his new movie, Magnolia, slated for a late 1999 release; with all due respect Mr. Lucas, there is only ONE movie I will wait in line to see this year.

Review title: Emperors New Clothes, aka the Woody Allen syndrome
Review_body: A worse film I don't think I will ever see. I just found it hard to care about any of the characters...and it didn't really tell me anything I didn't expect about a sordid industry. I am no prude, far from it, I have watched the films that this film portrays on many occasions. But to make a whole film about the making of them was scraping the barrel. All the characters were shallow, despicable, two faced and that was their good points and the plot went nowhere fast. At the end I said to myself "Did I miss something here?" But then I realised that I had been through it all before with every Woody Allen film that is ever released.

This movie has it all. Great actors, good dialog, drama, comedy, and excellent writing and directing by Paul Thomas Anderson. I have seen this film several times and enjoy it more each time. It doesn't get old, it is consistently entertaining and stimulating. Easily Burt Reynolds best role, and he does a great job. John C. Reilly and Don Cheadle also give excellent comedic performances. There is not a weak element in this film.

Review title: Boogie Nights grooves but is too long.
Review_body: Some excellent performances are made in Boogie Nights. Especially Burt Reynolds is doing a convincing job playing the porn director Jack Horner. Julianne Moore is also great as Amber. The story is well told and you get a good and realistic picture of the porn industry in California in the 70'ties and 80'ties. The sound track is groovy and gives a perfect atmosphere to the movie. In spite of all this, Boogie Nights is just too long. The story could have been told in less minutes, which would have made Boogie Nights even better.

Review title: (my cliche' line for the day) DON'T MISS THIS ONE!!!
Review_body: Boogie Nights, true, is not for everybody.  But if you either A: like to be entertained, B: enjoy the 'magic of movies', C: are interested in film, or D: all of the above, then there is no reason what-so-ever not to see Boogie Nights.To put it quickly, the movie takes place during the transition from the 70s to the 80s and focuses on life of Eddie Adams/Dirk Diggler/Brock Landers (superbly played by Mark Wahlberg).The viewer is graced with stunning performances by the entire cast (Burt Reynolds, John C. Reilly, Don Cheadle, Julianne Moore, et al...), and for two and three quarter hours is taken on one whirl-wind of an emotional roller coaster (sorry for my adjective filled sentences, but I LOVE this movie!).  Each character is well developed, and is given ample time to make you love them and possibly hate them simultaneously.  The emotions they emit are true, and I can completely empathize with them at times.In the end, Boogie Nights is funny, poignant, smart, sexxy, and - though parts might enrage you (due to the phenomenal performances) - should leave you with an over-all good feeling.

Review title: this is cinema at it's finest
Review_body: Paul Thomas Anderson is possibly the only good thing that has come from the 90's. Along with David Fincher and Danny Boyle, he's most certainly the best director to immerge from that hard decade for film. Pardon the cliché but `this is a must see for film lovers', the script is amazing, the performances are stunning, a plot to die for, excellent soundtrack, editing and the cinematography is mind blowing. Throughout the film Anderson puts a whole new meaning to the word steady cam, he uses it to great effect and again and again, meanwhile we sit there and go "wow". And the main thing is that he's not trying to over stylise the film just for the hell of it, like Guy Richie or even David Fincher with Fight Club. Each shot is meticulously planned with the audience in mind as well as the films narrative, enabling us to dig deeper into the characters in the film that struggle to find dignity in their lives. One particular shot in the film that I favour is when the camera holds close up on Mark Wahlberg's character for about a minute, intensifying the situation and enabling us to relate with his character. Ultimately this is a film about humans, people being people, something that we can all relate to, watch and enjoy. Of course there is the language, violence and sex scenes, so it wouldn't be suitable for younger viewers but I don't see any other reason why anyone should miss out on a marvellous piece of cinema. And if you enjoy this then check out his other films Hard Eight and the three hours masterpiece Magnolia, which he should have, without a doubt, won best director for. But as for Boogie Nights 10/10.

Review title: Over-Rated Waste of Time and Money!
Review_body:
This movie was terrible...Poorly written, distracted and incoherent. This movie has been over-rated and somehow mystified, apparently due to the fact that at the very end of this movie, some special-effects guys were hired to throw in  what was very obviously an over-sized dildo masquerading as a real porn star's legendary penis.If this movie really wanted to be a INSIDER's view of the porn industry during the 70's and 80's -- TOO LATE! -- its already been done, and done better!If this movie wanted to be semi-autobiographical, then it should have used REAL porn stars, or even a documentary-style approach.  At least porn stars KNOW how to fake orgasm, without embarrassing the audience.
This movie was banal, insipid, boring and extremely uninteresting from nearly ANY artistic or let alone intelligent perspective.  I saw people walking out of this movie, and I think I understand. Perhaps, they had better things to do with their hard-earned entertainment dollars... Like, I dunno, throwing them into a wishing well, perhaps wishing that this movie had been able to live up to its very undeserved hype.

All I can say about Boogie Nights is that perfection has its price.For people that are not looking for a typical plot, typical timing or a typical camera work, this is your choice; I say this because I know people that didn`t like this film and I really wonder why?. Let me comment on the genius behind all of this: Paul Thomas Anderson, who first surprised critics and audiences with his first film Sydney a.k.a. Hard Eight, he is simply the most intelligent film maker that appeared in Hollywood in the last 10 years ( in my personal opinion ) and he keeps surprising people around with Magnolia ( a genius masterpiece ) and his music videos. I`m just looking forward for his next film.

Review title: Coming out film from one of the future greats in the industry
Review_body: credit both anderson and the cast for making this one of the best films of the 90's...the ensemble cast is perfect, from mark wahlberg on down...for fans of dialogue-driven movies(i.e. Pulp Fiction), this is a must see...anderson uses the numerous characters not so much to drive the story, but rather to describe an era...

with one of the best names for a film character outside a cameron crowe flick (lloyd dobbler, penny lane, etc.) julianne moore's amber waves was the perfect way for mainstream America to be introduced to ms moore. as someone who has made her mark embodying characters so convincingly one almost expects her to step of screen in this persona. unfortunately, this is the same reason why she never had a chance in hell of winning when she was nominated for an academy award for her work in boogie nights. let's face it, a large percentage of the academy's voting members are unlikely to find a cocaine addicted porn star deserving of their highest honour. what is so infuriating about this slight is the complexity of this character that was apparently ignored due to how gifted an actress played this role. few actresses could bring together the varying aspects of amber waves character in such a way that they were not so heavy-handed you were beat over the head with them. as evidence of this i remind you of the scene shown at the Oscars when her name was called as a nominee. instead of one showing the internal conflict she endures between being a mother and being a porn star we were treated to the part where amber and roller girl sit a room, get all coked up and freak out. perhaps the most unsophisticated scene for this character and yet it was the one chosen as best representative of how the academy saw amber waves.
Incredibly good, every detail thought through. Amazing story telling, amazing playing it all just leaves you mind blown.

Review title: One of the Greatest Films Ever Made
Review_body: An absolute masterpiece. An absolutely perfect film. Seemingly under-appreciated. The casting, direction, cinematography, acting, music, writing, story. Flawless. PTA's masterpiece that certifies him as the best filmmaker of all time.

Boogie Nights is full of surprises, nothing quite prepares one for it its soul. Yes, it does have soul, whilst tackling the tackiest of subject matter, with both a wry smile and respect.  Brillantly cast and wonderful character development, the performances somehow combine the best of stage acting with improvisation within a cinema verite style.The plot proved richer than I expected and the underlying themes are teased out quite profoundly as each "B grade" human being is brought, through crisis, into perspective.A sociologist's dream case study, the film resonates the raw truth of what we all know about self-esteem, parental love and lack of it, attention/love deficit and its manifestation in adulthood, the desperate need to belong. Something for everyone here.. almost camouflaged as issues of untouchables and their separate milieu but of course they are universal.The film works on a number of levels. The ironic loop is that the milieu portrayed exists only because of the voyeur, who happens to be watching the film...Boogie Nights is non judgmental of its subject matter and characters, a rarity. It deserves every accolade it has achieved and more.

Review title: I guess even Burt Reynolds has to work...
Review_body: Without question, this has to be one of the most overrated movies in recent memory.  I'm a not that familiar with Anderson's other films, but I sincerely hope if he has tackled any other "based on a true story" themes, he has indeed been more ACCURATE! For starters, the film claims to have been based "loosely" on the famous (or infamous) porn star, John C. Holmes, and his turbulent life.  They may have gotten the "meteoric rise and fall" part right, but in no way did this film reflect anywhere close to what John Holmes' life was like, especially in the pornography industry.  I guess Anderson must have felt, for the public to truly accept it, he must sugarcoat (if that's possible) the story a little. It wasn't nearly as tragic or brutal as Holmes' life, so apparently that would never sell. More so, everybody has raved about the cinematography of this film, and to be honest, it's just average.  That goes to show that in the post-modern world we live in,  people's standards have slipped, have less knowledge about art and art in film, and are obviously more easily impressed by not their own opinions, but the media's... Burt Reynolds at least got to salvage his career by not taking a totally cheesy role again, and that's about all the credit I can give Anderson on this film.  Mark Wahlberg is clearly a terrible actor, and anybody who believes he IS good, must be in the 14-21 year old demographic somewhere. Further evidence this film is a lemon, long time porn star Juliet "Aunt Peg" Anderson clearly stated that the film's "behind-the-scenes" vibe regarding the industry in the late 70's/early 80's was vehemently wrong!

"Boogie Nights" made me want to become a filmmaker.  This film has it all and is one of the best films of 1997.  Even though it won no Oscars, it did not need any.  The film was nominated for three.  The film also includes a killer soundtrack which is very rare.  PT Anderson wrote a brilliant script which I own into a nearly three hour masterpiece.This film revived the career of Burt Reynolds.  It also launched careers for Mark Wahlberg, John C. Reily, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Don Cheadle, Luis Guzman, Thomas Jane, and Heather Graham.  Julianne Moore and William H. Macy also put together great performances."Boogie Nights" is a look into the adult film business of the late 1970s and early 1980s.  Dirk Diggler, played by Wahlberg, is a seventeen year old with one special thing, a 13 inch long you know what.  You watch him as he rises to the top of the business and his terrible fall to the bottom.  Which includes drug use and even attempting to cut a record.Burt Reynolds is Jack Horner, an adult film director who discovers Diggler. Moore is Amber Waves, a mother who loses her child because of her occupation of an adult film star.  John C. Reily is Reed Rothchild, Dirk's best friend and sidekick in most his films.  Philip Seymour Hoffman is Scotty, who works on most of the films.  Heather Graham plays Rollergirl, who is just a very interesting character.PT Anderson really proved that he is the one of the best filmmakers in Hollywood with this film.  This film is just truly a classic.  A lot of memorable lines and scenes.  "Boogie Nights" is not a porno and is a must see for anyone who wants to see a great film.

Review title: Please don't let aliens in the year 2256 find this movie.
Review_body: Please don't let aliens in the year 2256 find this movie. They will have no choice but to destroy earth.Wow this is so bad my head still aches from watching it through trying to figure out why anyone would accept this script and act in this movie yet it's loaded with stars. Reynolds probably needed the money but Graham, Cheadle, Hoffman, Wahlberg, Moore, Macy, Guzman and Riley have no business being in this waste of good film. With great irony this mostly "A" list of stars each turn in a disgraceful performances.Not the first terrible movie I've seen but it certainly is the worst movie I've ever seen. If you want to waste some money this is a the rock solid choice.

Superb ensemble piece.  The writing and direction capture the late seventies without the stupid cliches that drive most other films set in that time (eg. 54).  This movie is a must see for fans of and detractors of the adult movie industry.  I have played in my mind the different casting possibilities that could have been chosen if any actor were available for any role and I think that this is as close to a perfect cast in each and every role as you can get.  This is typical P T Anderson excellence.  What more can I say except that it is a shame that there is not an "ensemble acting" category for the Academy Awards because this group would have either won it hands down or been robbed.  Cinematically, the final scene, with the camera following Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) through the house to the studio is a breathtaking piece of work.  I consistently rate this film as one of my all time favorites and it is on my personal top twenty five list.

This is not so much of a review as it is a testament that it has been proven, yet again, that the Academy rewards money, not artistic accomplishment. And I must say I am saddened that this usually artistic and intelligent band of imbd members have left this off the top 250. Boogie Nights is powerful, raw, and gutsy through script, direction and acting. Very few movies can claim this triple crown.

Boogie Nights is an interesting film first because of the interesting history of pornography as told by the director, but secondly as a story of family. Burt Reynolds is amazing as a father in the movie. This film, though about pornography, was one of the two most moral/family-oriented/value- centered films of the year. The other was The Apostle. Boogie Nights is one of the great films ever made because it integrates so completely the world of values with the power of the flesh and how each informs the other.

Review title: Just like Magnolia, brilliant, and bittersweet.
Review_body: The movie was a brilliant piece of work. The acting great and the story unique. It all comes together greatly for a bittersweet ending you won't forget. I saw Magnolia first, and LOVED it. And so I rented this and felt the same way. I liked Magnolia better, but this is up there. If you want a great movie to rent. Rent this. If you want a better one to rent. Get Magnolia.You might just even get both. I am 13 and I think that P.T. Anderson is a genious. Some don't like his work, they think it is vulgar and disgusting. But when you think about it. All of these things happen or happened. And Paul just decided to tell them on screen, which I think personally is a great way to explain something with a weird tale. And boy does he layout his stories perfectly.Go Paul! Waiting for yet another one of your directorial masterpieces.

Review title: "Boogie Nights" - PT Anderson gives Porn the Goodfellas treatment
Review_body: "Boogie Nights" is a classic Hollywood film of dreams and dreamers  the twist is its set in the porn business of the late seventies and early eighties. Writer director PT Anderson was just 25 when he made this homage - or should that be expose - and the movie shows him experimenting with techniques clearly borrowed from Scorsese and Altman amongst others. What's amazing is that it all comes off confirming his reputation as one of the most exciting young directors to emerge from the nineties.The film follows the life of the creatively named Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg) as he leaves home determined to make it by using the only asset he has  and it is quite a substantial asset. Along the way we meet the varied characters that inhabit the porn scene, most of whom are introduced in a stunning long take through a nightclub that opens the movie which is reminiscent of both Scorsese's "Goodfellas" and Altman's "The Player".At 156 minutes this film is very much an epic but Anderson wisely keeps the explicitness to a minimum, making this very much a piece of drama rather than erotica. What we are shown is a world where sex, drugs and money act as substitutes for artistic dreams and emotional need.The large cast produce uniformly excellent performances from Burt Reynolds porn director through cuckolded William H Macy to Jullianne Moore's drug addicted pornstar facing a child custody battle. Anderson handles his large cast with the assuredness of a seasoned veteran none of the characters get short changed by having their story lines abruptly abandoned.Both funny and disturbing in equal measures this is an excellent film, with bravura directing from Anderson and a style that perfectly evokes its setting. If there is a criticism to be made, and it's a harsh one, it's that Anderson occasionally seems too fond of his characters. Don't let the subject matter put you off, this is an excellent film that heralds the rise of a potential new auteur.9/10 - Excellent

Review title: It was OK - Lots of sex & nudity, but not much realism
Review_body: It was alright, but not the great piece of work everyone raves about. Also, it was obvious that the director had absolutely zero knowledge of firearms. Like a shotgun blowing out a rear windshield from 50 yards away. Also a crack-head who had been shot through the heart by someone he hadn't seen turning and making a perfect shot from 30 feet on the guy who just shot him then turning and making nailing a head shot on someone else all while he was falling and dying. Trying too hard to make an anti-gun statement. Not very believable. Also with all of the shootings that happened inside peoples homes and the police don't show up even once? Pretty 2 dimensional. But if you want to see Heather Graham & Julianne Moore naked, this is the movie. Just don't go looking for a believable story.

Though it is 2003 I feel that the comments on this film are rather weak and I would like to update them.The opening sequence is one of the best in the films. The first few shots introduce all the main characters that are important to the story without it even feeling like that was the intention. We are shown the dance club, roller girl, Maurice, Jack and Amber/Maggie, Eddie/Dirk, and Little Bill (William H. Macy). Amazing that Anderson could be so blunt with that and not even feel like you're being smothered with characters. Brilliant directing.Boogie Nights is one of my favorite films. It deals with the rise and fall of numerous characters during the peak of pornography in the 70's and early 80's. Mark Wahlberg gives probably his best performance we might ever see. Burt Reynolds plays Jack Horner, a filmmaker trying to tell stories through pornography. Hard task but he's a man of vision and the character in my mind is a genius. This too was a great performance by not my favorite Burt Reynolds.This film should be studied by cinematographers and writers alike. My best and easily acceptable example is the donut shop scene. Cinematographers note that in this scene there are so many opprotunities for reflection but not once do you see the camera. Not once. This, in my opinion is one of the best scenes. The beauty of that scene shows how simple the human mind really is. Don Cheadle had numerous options after what happens and you could see it in his face that he was thinking about what to do. He chooses selfishness, takes the bag and runs, which I believe most of us would choose.Writers take note that Boogie Nights goes into great character development and has a number of characters to build. Paul Thomas Anderson is I think one of the best writers of our era. His understanding of human suffering and confusion brings his characters to life. Especially Eddie Adams and Jack Horner. Anderson shows even more depth and emotion in his film Magnolia. But that's another story.If you don't like Boogie Nights that's perfectly alright. The beauty of Boogie Nights is that the film is about the 70's porn era, but there is barely any nudity when plenty could have been put in. The film doesn't glorify pornography, it shows how great and terrible it can be. Or at least how quickly something good can be swept out from under you. Boogie Nights is about people and their belonging in this world, whether it be the porn industry or anything else. It's not about porn, or sex, or making drugs seem great. It shows how easily people can be corrupted and ruined by the things around them. I love this film and recommend it to anyone who is going to study film.Why Anderson hasn't recieved an oscar for writing and directing I don't know. His films keep getting better and deeper. The thought provoking movies he has made keep me coming back for more. I'm sure he has plenty of ideas for the next decade or so to entertain the masses.

Yes, this movie is about the pornographic industry. If you are not a fan of such an industry, the movie might not "grab you" as much as it should. But, think about it: it is interesting to know how this kind of "world" works around. This movie didn't get a 10 from me because it reminds me of lemonade. Let me make this clearer: the plot is interesting, but the story line is too light. This is not necessarily a bad thing. Sometimes, movies turn out better when they are more "light weight". Due to the volatile natures of the characters, this lightness fitted in quite well. It's almost perfect. A certain heaviness of the story is embedded into this lightness with a very "merry" soundtrack following it around throughout the entire movie. However, it was not embedded enough. I mentioned the soundtrack. Before I comment on that, I must say that I think that soundtracks are VERY IMPORTANT in a movie. If the soundtrack does not fit into the movie, it is very possible that I will dislike the entire thing, even though the movie itself without the music might be good enough. The OST of this movie is: TERRIFIC. The music goes along with the characters and especially the story, but in some instances: the music was too happy, when it should have been more solemn.It would be a shame not to watch this movie. It's a good movie. Perhaps not perfect, but it still can be charted in "a movie you must see before you die". I hope you enjoy it.

Paul Thomas Anderson's stylish and compelling take on the 70s porn industry follows Eddie Adams, aka Dirk Diggler (Mark Wahlberg), through six years of sex, drugs and disco. His chance meeting with pornography director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) starts his career as one of the greatest adult actors of the time. Dirk's character is based on real-life porn actor John Holmes, who, like Dirk, was renowned for being extremely "well-endowed". This is where Dirk finds initial success.The main themes in Boogie Nights are the obvious ones relating to a film of this genre; pornography, drugs, sex, betrayal, violence and music. Boogie Nights deals with the pornography theme with some control. It is not overplayed and the sex scenes are surprisingly minimal, but mentally explicit when they take place on screen.Throughout the film cocaine is abused enormously, and the film's setting, Los Angeles 1977-1983, reflects the popularity of the drug at that time, which the film captures perfectly. However, Boogie Nights does not promote cocaine, as there are some scenes involving addiction and overdoses. For example at Jack's party, they find a girl who has recently, and graphically, overdosed; blood pours from her nose and she begins an unconscious fit. The film, before this scenes, has been fairly upbeat and comic, but from this point it foreshadows the darkness that it will occur.The music scenes are executed brilliantly, from superbly-staged disco scenes to a down-and-out Dirk singing terribly in his new music career. The soundtrack too is excellent, featuring tunes from The Emotions, ELO, The Beach Boys and the unforgettable Sound Experience. The standout scene in the whole film comes down to the music; Dirk, Redd Rothchild (John C. Reilly) and Todd Parker (Thomas Jane) visit drug dealer Rahad Jackson's (Alfred Molina) house in order to make some quick cash from selling phoney drugs, but Night Ranger's Sister Christian, which is playing in the background, increases the intensity of the scene incredibly, proving that music can bring so much more depth to a scene. Boogie Nights is filled with those kind of scenes, which makes the film even more fantastic.The standout performance in Boogie Nights is Burt Reynolds as the enigmatic, yet moody, film director. In the scene where he attacks a young guy for slating his movies, it is a complete shock for the audience, because before this point he has been pretty mellow and content. Other notable performances are Julianne Moore, Heather Graham as the beautiful Rollergirl, John C. Reilly, and Mark Wahlberg, who delivers the performance of his career.Boogie Nights is also a surprisingly original film, using common themes but filmed in its own sharp and realistic way. Anderson's approach has been fully captures these characters in a time when nothing seemed to be going wrong, or at least until the 80s arrive. From then on, things turn very dark indeed, and all signs of the recognisable characters and situations from the first part of the film have gone. This does not, however, reduce the high level of engaging entertainment that this film offers.Boogie Nights was not a box-office success, earning only £2 million at cinemas in the UK. But this is not the film's, or the director's concern. Anderson recognises quality, not popularity, which is evident in his three other films, Hard Eight, Magnolia and Punch-Drunk Love. I would recommend this film to anyone who enjoys a simple parable filled with excellent and variable situations, because at the end of this film you will realize that Boogie Nights is a simple morality tale, but one which will stay in the mind days after you watch it. Boogie Nights is at once shocking, hilarious, devastating and both visually and audibly outstanding.

Go away naysayers, move past the porn theme and see this film for what it is. The greatest movie ever! Paul Thomas Anderson captured magic in a bottle. The dialogue, the music, the cinematography all works in sync. I'll take the pool scene over some sled any day. I await your blah, blah , blah. This is a real movie!

Wow. Not only does Paul Thomas Anderson write a brilliant script, but he makes every moment of the film shine. I don't recall ever being bored through any of the one hundred fifty minutes either. Now I know many people are turned off by the idea of a movie about the porn industry, but it's done in a tasteful way, but still maintains it's entertainment. At the base of the film, it all comes back to family and how everyone searches through their soul to find themselves for what they really are. In particular, John C. Reilly, Mark Wahlberg (best role of his career), and Philip Seymour Hoffman light up the screen. In my opinion, the best film of 1997, and one of the best films of all time. That's all there is to it.

Review title: A film to remember Burt Reynolds by
Review_body: The brilliance of this story delivers at least one skillfully crafted message to each viewer in the audience. This story is about success, it's about failure. It's about the choices you make in life and the choices others make for you. The story deals with self realization and determination on a scale so large, no camera angle could cover it. Within the grasp of each scene is resides an element marked for depiction within your imagination. Keep this in mind as you watch the movie; it's more than eye candy. The sexually suggestive, rarely explicit scenes serve only to distract and entertain you during the tedious process of character development.

There is very little that I can add to the huge amount of positive word this film already has other than saying it is superb in every way. Mr Anderson is a brilliant filmmaker. The time he spends setting up the characters and situations this film portrays so well is brilliant. The cast is flawless and the music the party tape of a generation. I cannot recommend this film highly enough. And don't get me started on how good Mark Walberg looks! Even Burt Reynolds (who looks a little strange after some obvious face work) gives a performance that makes us realize how much more this guy has to offer than Smokey and the Bandit. Finally, if you're still not convinced, Phillip Seymour Hoffman is in it, need I say more?

I had so many problems with this movie. I understood that it was cinematic genius and ended up with cinematic excrement. I came into the movie uninfluenced by the good reviews it naturally gets, but it was still to no avail. Here's my beef:First, Boogie Nights tried to hard to have that deep message about how a life of moral decadence leads to regret and a general waste of innocence. We all know this, we all think about how empty the dirty stripper is on the inside. Second, I have no beef with Anderson, it's just that his cinematography was so over the top. I fully understand that he has the capability to make long shots on tracks, cranes, dollies or with a steady cam, but not every single shot has to be a long shot. I don't want a porno version of Raging Bull. Third, Burt Reynolds really didn't deserve an Oscar nomination for his role. It was a good character, but not nomination worthy. The only thing he deserves is the Awesome Mustache Trophy Fourth, this movie gets so much damn praise from people. I can't figure out why. I think it's the classic ideology that something risqué has to be good. This movie is over inflated because of the type of content (in this case, the pornographic type) in Boogie Nights instead of the quality of the content (which was weak). Fifth, this movie was filled with too many 70's stereotypes. It was overdone. Sixth, Mark Wahlberg's acting wasn't that great. It was subpar at best. I'll give it him on that he was good in the scene recording his album because it was pretty funny. Regardless, he was too dramatic and and over worked the nonchalant attitude of his character. Seventh, too many useless characters. I love William H. Macy, but his character was useless. I'm indifferent on Phillip Seymour Hoffman, but he too was useless. Eighth, this movie had that feel where if you keep waiting patiently, it will get better. It never did. I hate when movies do that. Ninth, I personally think the writing for this movie was unimaginative and boring. Such a cliché story, boy goes on his own, boy makes porn and becomes rich and famous, boy finds drugs and hits the gutter, boy finds his way back to glory. Seen it before, let's write something new. Tenth, too many useless side stories. If Anderson would have completely cut out the black guy making it in the stereo business with stolen money, Phillip Seymour Hoffman's homosexual journey, Luis Guzman's club adventures and William H. Macy's marital frustrations and this movie might have been somewhat less aimless.Overall 2.3 out of 10.

Review title: Great Movie and Launcher of Many Careers
Review_body: I looove this movie. I think I've seen it about six times now and I never get tired of it. What a novel idea to make a movie about the porn industry in the 1970's. And that's exactly what is fun about it too...all the music and style of that decade are brought back in living colour. What a blast! Every time I watch this, I notice an actor that is now famous that wasn't famous the previous time I watched it...but I think I've now covered off all the main characters in the movie as they all seem to have gone on to bigger and better things; most notably, Julianne Moore, Heather Graham, Bill Macey, Tom Jane, Philip Seymour Hoffman, and of course Mark Whalberg and C. Thomas Reilley. A notable mention also to Don Cheedle who was just nominated for a Best Actor award at the 2005 Oscars. This guy is awesome and sooo cute in this movie! I definitely recommend this one...but keep in mind it is not for the easily offended as there are fictional depictions of working actors plying their trade in the world of "video" porn.

Review title: This is a long drawn out movie
Review_body: I was told over and over that I had to watch this movie. I would have been better off watching an ant wander around a sandbox. It was on IFC, and it stole 3 hours of my life. There just doesn't seem to be a plot. Nothing in the film seems to get resolved. The acting is OK, but the directing is awful. There are several instances where you're just looking at someone staring off into space for perhaps a whole minute or longer. You don't get to see what they're looking at, or what they're thinking about, you just see the blank look on their face and that's it. At the end of the movie, I'm sure that's how I looked. The only good thing I can say about it is that I got my nails painted while I watched it.
Will forever cherish this as Burt's best movie ever. Love Burt.

Review title: An interesting story made incredibly boring
Review_body:
It seems very interesting at the beginning, but gets boring as the story progresses.Some scenes just make no sense and seem completely out of place.The movie about porn should be made to entertain people with food for thought. In this case it's all the way the food for thought. Maybe it was the director's point, but the movie didn't entertain me at all.5/10 for good acting, 70s atmosphere, music etc
It wasn't a bad movie, but overrated imo & definitely not worth 2h 30 min of watching it.

Boogie Nights **** out of **** ...was my personal favorite movie of last year.  It is an excellent film with an extraordinary cast. In this movie, it isnt just 2 or 3 characters, Paul  Thomas Anderson introduces us to so many (Jack Horner, Dirk Diggler, Amber Waves, Rollergirl, Reed Rothcild....to name a few). The story by Anderson is amazing and is held together by his great directing job, and outstanding acting by the entire cast and is topped off by a great score that takes you back to the 70s (even though I wasnt born yet).

Review title: Starts out fun but becomes a tedious violent polemic
Review_body: At the beginning the period music, clothes and atmosphere are a hoot.  The performances are great, especially Burt's and Mark's; the initial scenes of making very low budget porn are clever and amusing. But soon enough the story turns formulaic as too much coke is vacuumed up and everyone pays for the character's excesses, especially the audience.  Violence and degradation descend, then more violence, and yet more violence.  I didn't see the end because after a character is gratuitously splattered with brains as witness to a robbery, enough became enough and I hit Stop/Rewind.

Mark Wahlberg was excellent as Dirk Diggler. The movie was an entertaining look into the world of porn. Excellent supporting cast including: Burt Reynolds and Heather Grahm. I have this movie on VHS and DVD and watch it all the time. To me it's a classic!

Review title: Paul Thomas Anderson is a talented director
Review_body: P.T. Anderson has created a world for us which is hard to look away from. His characters are so good at what they're doing in this film.  Mark Wahlberg gives a great performance as the bus boy in Torrance to the rising porn star Dirk Diggler of L.A.  All the actors were very good but this film really belongs to Burt Reynolds who gave a tour-de-force performance as Jack Horner. For this being Burt's greatest performance, he got royally screwed by the academy.  Like Robin Williams was THAT good in "Good Will Hunting". P.T. Anderson who did the equally good "Hard Eight", has great poise and energy in his writing. How could you every forget a name like Dirk Diggler?  "Boogie Nights" in my book was the best film in 1997 and is near a masterpiece to me.  Others will find it boring, disturbing, gross, whatever, the point is, that this is a film that people are going to remember for years.  P.T. is a breakthrough talent who in more years to come will be giving us more interesting films and this man will win an Oscar some day. Mark my words!

As long as you can get past your puritanical instincts and realize that pornographers are people too, you'll realize the depth p.t. anderson gives to his characters.  Also, an incredible soundtrack.  The songs are so tightly tied to their scenes, you won't be able to hear them without thinking about the movie again.Philip Seymour Hoffman is worth the price of admission alone.

Review title: good characters, plot, acting; a little slow in parts
Review_body: Basically a good performance by the cast, delivering good performances, especially Mark Walberg and Burt Reynolds.  However, the plot does drag a little at times, and tightening up the script could have improved the somewhat chaotic branching into multiple subplots.  Still, a movie I would recommend if you've got time to burn...

Review title: Great movie a must see for those who enjoy dramatic cinematography
Review_body: Truly amazing movie, not only for the great and fab, 70's but Mr. Anderson, does a spectacular job of cinematography.  You can actually see and feel what the actors are going through.  Facial expressions, beautiful scenes and the music just makes it what it is, a fantastic movie all around.

Review title: Whats that song they play before Jessie's girl????
Review_body: When that guy is smoking crack while the kid is setting off fire works.... the song that was playing, cant find it on the sound track, then he played Jessie's girl but I think this song was first anyone know??? I have it stuck in my head. IT sounds like a famous song in the 70s but I don't know which one.If anyone knows please reply Anyone Anyone That scence is so cool when they have to hang out with that crazy guy and the fireworks keep going off and they are all wound up ready to flip out, I feel so tense when I watch that scene. And Whats with that Chinese boy with the fireworks? Anyway I would really like to know what that song is.

I was born at the beginning of the seventies and I could appreciate this look back in time. It was well written and I really felt for the characters. I give it ten out of ten. This movie has everything and the soundtrack is a time capsule in its self

Review title: Great camerawork, great music, great script and the greatest and one of the most underrated pics of the 90`s!
Review_body: When I first heard about this movie it didn`t appeal to me. But when I saw it (about one year ago) i knew at once that I had missed out on probably the greatest film of the 90`s!! I sat for two and a half hours and I was simply stunned! I cried, I laughed and when the end came I was sad. I really didn`t want it to end. First of all, I was deeply moved and touched by this film and I can`t say it enough, Mark Wahlberg is simply magnificent in this film and portrays Dirk Diggler with passion and skill. It`s really a kind of sad story and you begin to feel sorry for Dirk, but you know that he has himself to thank.The best thing about this pic maybe, is the acting. Academy Award nominee Burt Reynolds in the role of his life! Great and if nothing less, SUPERB!! Don Cheadle, Luis Guzman, Julianne Moore, Melora Walters, John C.Reilly, P.S.Hoffman, William H.Macy, Phillip Baker Hall and Heather Graham!! Every each and one of them delivers blistering performances and makes this movie unforgettable.The director/writer Paul Thomas Anderson is one of my personal favourits and i do believe he will continue to make great films in the future. His excellent style in camerawork and his intense and brilliant scripts are all known qualities. I think and I mean that he really deserved that Oscar for Best Original Screenplay!! I would already categorize P.T.Anderson as one of greatest and most promising director/writers of all time.The best movie of the 90`s and why stop there?! This movie is the best movie I have ever seen and I think it`s one of the all-time top-ten!! I give it 10/10!! So, see this movie and do not miss out on the great soundtrack that is also a strong part of the film."I am a big,bright,shining star"-Dirk Diggler-

Just got around to seeing this overlong (pun intended) effort.For such a stellar cast , a very feeble offering imo.I was obligated to fast forward through much of it as It wasn't worth the time demanded of a real time viewing. I rarely do that, but I was obligated for sanity's sake.That so many, including respected reviewers , love this, is an amazement.Speaking of amazement, the 10 line minimum here is ridiculous. I can understand 5 or 6 , but why should I have to invent something to say just to pad it out?

This movie is one of those classics that are entertaining from start to finish. It's almost like an adult industry version of Goodfellas. I love all the songs in the movie too. PTA definitely knows what he's doing.

I break out this movie every couple of years... Well written, with great performances that have held up well over the 20+ years since the movie was released. Get your Burt fix, along with a unique "niche" window into the 70s and 80s.

Review title: Boogie Nights OR "How I learned to ignore the consequences, and love the freedom of the 1970's."
Review_body: Boogie Nights is perhaps one of the greatest examples any would-be filmmaker should take a long hard look at.  Sure, you could spend loads of quality time reviewing the clasics from Hitchcock to Scorsese; but lets follow suit for the modern generation and study half-heartedly.Where to begin, I suppose one could look at the film as simply a story, perhaps even docudrama which focuses on the late 1970's porn industry-and what an industry it was!
