The other half could focus on the incredible detail one brillant filmmaker can achieve simply by using polyester and *ahem* rubber.  But honestly, Boogie Nights brings back the pure, no-bul!shi$, in your face kind of cinema I haven't experienced since the film greats of the 1970's...ironic...or stroke of genius.  The story is full of richly detailed characters, all of which you either can relate too, love, or hate; but the impact is clear-you are feeling something for them.  Among the characters the two performances which stand out are: Burt Reynolds as Director Jack Horner, and Mark Wahlberg as Eddie Adams/Dirk Diggler. Julianne Moore is also brillant, as is Heather Graham...but if I focus on any one actor it would have to be John C. Reilly.  John's performance is a perfect balance of comedic timing and character driven emotion...I'm a sucker for the line "Ever see the movie Star Wars?...People say I look like Han Solo."  Anyway, the look of the film is incredible, the Director of Photography and Director/Writer/Producer, have come up with a vibrant colour, and flashy style that compares to Martin Scorsese, and Stanley Kubrick(in terms of his perfection of his craft); but with creating his own unique look, and pushing the edge with the longest single shot I'ver ever seen...that being the New Year's party sequence.The music, like in any great film, is a character of its own.  At times, it consumes oneself with sorrow or grief...but mainly its all about fun, dancing, and having a good time; the spirit of the 1970's. OK, back to the performances.Burt Reynolds plays the character of Jack Horner, a porn director who feels the burden of what the future of "film" means to his genre.  The awful transition from shooting on film to recording on magnetic tape. The lose of his art, as it were...and the changes in mentality to the people he works with.  Walhberg adds the perfect blend of innocense and sexual bravado needed for the character.  For all those individuals who have seen Burton's Planet of the Apes, pay no attention to the performance of Wahlberg in that film...rent boogie nights and see what a difference a good script can make!Julianne Moore plays the would-be mother to all, and with that comes the torment and anguish she feels, as life imitates art; and she loses all those close to her.  Heather Graham is the eye-candy, but later holds her own, and steals some of the scenes from even the great Mr. Reynolds himself.  Each character is multidimensional, rich with life, and performed by actors that seem to be picture perfect for the part.The film itself is often funny, tragic, exciting, and provides a uncompromising look into the turblulant lifestyle of the fast-pace 1970's. It makes no excuses, and tells no lies; and offers the audience a trip back. But even more importantly, the movie gives us a grand example of how films should be made; and a new director whose bold visions bring back art in film.

Review title: I'll say two things: Don Cheadle
Review_body: With an older and more seasoned eye, this really is a very well-put together film. It has just enough entertainment, just enough great acting, just enough of everything. As a younger person, in the 1990's it was shocking, now it is mild in subject matter, but the subject matter is why I took off one star -- there were too many nude scenes. The other star is taken off, because, for all of its grit, the movie was a happy one, with a happy ending. That's not how it usually goes in life. The most wonderful aspect of the movie was the performance by Don Cheadle. His character was just sweet. I loved the scene where he changed his look, and met his new love. I wish that he had more starring roles with comedic value. He is a human heart!

Review title: Beautiful film of a somewhat touchy subject matter...
Review_body: What can I say but that this is a simply beautiful and amazing film.Right now, let me say that it's NOT a movie my grandma would approve of but hey...I know that the whole subject of the 70's porn industry isn't exactly something that people would admittedly want to outright say that they admire, and I myself am somewhat reserved in recommending this movie to others because everyone will look at it differently.  But still, it's just such a great story!  Eddie's rise to stardom and the life of luxury and then his eminent downward spiral.Another aspect that most people might not notice or admire (although all movie buffs would of course) was Anderson's use of extended shots to capture many different conversations and actions going on in the same scene.  The transitions are really cool.  Sometimes I wonder how many takes it might have taken them to get just what they wanted out of a single shot.Finally the part of the film that really makes it stand out for me is the amazing use and choices of music throughout the movie.  The music really gets you into the groove of that swingin' party life of the 70's.  If nothing else, go get the soundtrack.Overall for me, I would say that this movie is an 8.5/10, but the music just bumps it up to 9.5 or 10/10.  It's just that good.

** Thematic Spoilers **Since the debut of Boogie Nights, critics have observed P.T. Anderson's movies become more abstract and metaphorical.  Some would say that Boogie Nights is his only fully intact movie, in that it's main purpose isn't to reveal some other hidden meaning.In contrast, many casual viewers thought Boogie Nights was simply the story of a porn star. None of these people paid attention to the plot of the movie, and to whom the director is at the same time.  P.T. Anderson certainly didn't attain his joy for hidden meanings all of a sudden.  As anyone who has followed his career knows, it's in everything he makes. It's the kind of filmmaker he is.In short, just as several great movies before it, Boogie Nights is the story of America in the 70's through the 80's.  The climate in the movie follows that of the nation to a T.  The soft, fun and enjoyable 70's make way to the drugged, over-indulgent 80's with the striking image of, well, how's a double murder by and suicide of a jealous husband?Another P.T. Anderson trait, being coincidence of events, is overwhelmingly present in the movie.  A prime example being the night of 2 beatings and a very strange robbery, as well as the colonel's house being a magnet for Corvette's.Off the topic of the script itself, the acting is superb.  Rarely do you see so much acting talent in a movie.  The atmosphere of the movie fit the time it is set in perfectly.  The music fits well, and isn't over used (a trend that many 70's-80's movies were unable to resist).  It's very hard to find significant faults in the movie.I give it 4 stars (out of 4). The movie is extremely enjoyable. It's clever without being overbearing, it has all of the major cinematic elements, it succeeds in dissecting a delicate subject matter (pornography) without being overly vulgar, and the quality is exceptional.  To top it off, this is of a relatively amateur writer & director.See it.

What did the 70's look like? Grime and brown looking at documentaries etc. But there was a sleazy glamour about the time which the 1980's clean look didn't have. Boogie Nights captures the feel for the era remarkably well its this which makes the film so good. Set in the 1970s porn industry at a time when employment rights in porn were are distant as any sense of rights in the decade of Watergate.Burt Reynolds as Director Jack Horner shows all the sleaziness and exploitation. Excellent casting as Reynolds fame as a hunk with a sense of danger in all the 70's macho action movies which had little sense of moral direction.The story of the film of a 1970's period piece has been revived by the like of Quentin Tarrantino in the form of homages and have failed because of their insistence on referencing the 1970's instead of the atmosphere. Boogie Nights instead uses full characterisation of the roles: Reynolds, Julianne Moore, Heather Grahame all that is essential to make a film good instead of just successful.A great film on a tacky subject from a gloriously tacky era.

Boogie Nights was not Paul Thomas Anderon's first film--that was 1996's Hard Eight-- but it was the first one he had full artistic control over and the result is a real tour de force. Except for Citizen Kane I have probably never seen a movie so enthusiastically cinematic. He is not afraid to use split screens and other unfashionable film techniques, and because he is not afraid to use them they work. This is one of the most confident films I've ever seen. Anderson's camera moves through the scenes like a kid in a candy store, floating about gayly eying everything around it but never coming to a full stop because there is so much other stuff to see. And there is certainly a lot to see. Boogie Nights is a huge ensemble, but Anderson never really gets lost in the scope (there is admittedly one storyline that doesn't really go anywhere, but it serves to advance the other threads so it's fine). Take the opening scene of the movie. Faced with the problem of introducing such a huge cast, Anderson decides to "dive right in" and brings us to a nightclub where the entire cast is partying. We don't exactly meet anybody during this scene, as the camera just floats from booths to the dancefloor to the kitchen and back around, and we overhear out-of-context blurts from the characters as we pass them much as we would were we walking through the club ourselves. However, the blurts are revealing--Luis Guzman wants Burt Reynolds to put him in a film someday. Don Cheadle's fashion sense is questionable. Julianne Moore is like a mother to Heather Graham. William Macy is more concerned with business details than the carefree Reynolds. By the end of the scene we feel like we have a pretty reasonable grasp on the scene these people run in.This speaks to Anderson's other great strength as a filmmaker--his writing. People often talk about his camera and how it relates him to his idols like Scorsese and Ophüls, but rarely mentioned is his ability to create wonderful characters. Boogie Nights, like another great ensemble, Robert Altman's Nashville, is a movie that really feels lived-in. We do not for a second doubt that these are real people, and they occupy our imagination long after the runtime is up. The movie is bursting at the seams with life. Anderson is anything but a lazy filmmaker. He loads the characters with traits that might not seem "essential" to a lesser writer, but end up giving the characters the necessary human qualities to make the story really touching. Would Boogie Nights be as moving if Mark Wahlberg wasn't obsessed with karate, and didn't pump himself up by doing punching exercises in front of the mirror before porn shoots? Or if John C Reilly and Don Cheadle didn't have ambitions of becoming a magician and a stereo equipment salesman, respectively? I think not. Boogie Nights is a classic film in the same sense as The Godfather--the filmmaker takes us into a world unknown to most of us, one many of us might think unsavory, and creates a truly moving piece of human drama. And like Nashville, it being so full of life makes it truly life-affirming. Boogie Nights is one of the few movies that not only makes me feel like I've learned more about human beings, but also makes me truly happy to be one.

This is one of the best movies ever for many reasons.  Anderson is one of the most talented new directors in Hollywood and has an amazing cast that play off each other very well.  Every actor was cast perfectly for each role and all deliver great performances.  This movie's setting is the 70's pornography industry, so many people expect the movie to be close to soft porn.  Nothing could be further from the truth; there is very little nudity considering the setting. The movie is not about the pron industry, but instead on the lives of a few main characters, who happen to work in this business. This is one of my favorite movies ever and anyone who enjoys movies set in the 70's and 80's should see it.  I hope Anderson can keep delivering films like this and Magnolia.

When I first heard about this movie, I thought it was gonna be graphic, with no story and very bad acting.  Boy, was i wrong.  The movie was like nothing I had ever seen up until then and I don't think any movie has compared to it since.The story telling was great and the acting was top notch, performed by one of the best all around casts ever put together.  Everyone has one special thing, and thanks to P.T Anderson, we all have this movie to enjoy.

Review title: Simply put, one of the best films of the 1990's
Review_body: "Boogie Nights" follows the lives of "film maker" Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds) and his stable of porn stars over a six year period from 1977-1983. The story starts when Jack introduces himself to 17 year old high school drop-out Eddie Adams in San Fernando Valley nightclub after hearing rumors that Eddie is 14" long in the "Mr. Torpedo" area.At the same time we are introduced Rollergirl (Heather Graham), a high schooler already making a career as a porn star & Amber Waves (Julianne Moore), a 30 something cocaine addict who lost visitation rights to her young son because of her chosen career. Over the course of the next few days Eddie moves out of home after a fight with his mother and into Jack's house. Where we are introduced via a party to the rest of the characters including Reed Rothchild (John C. Reilly) The Current king of Jack's stable, Buck (Don Cheadle), is the only character in the film who sees a life for himself outside of porn, Scotty J. (Phillip Seymour Hoffman) a young, overweight, gay man and Little Bill (William H. Macy) whose wife seems to be screwing anybody who isn't him.Before long Eddie has become Dirk Diggler, the biggest thing to have ever hit the porn industry, not suprisingly he quickly starts to falling into the trappings of his own success, introduced, via Amber to cocaine and becoming too big for his own boots, he falls, hard. The people around Eddie are falling too but they always stick by one another. All the performances in this film are stellar but it is Moore's Amber Waves and Cheadle's Buck that standout as truly stunning, P.T Anderson has written a brilliant screenplay complemented by his great direction. This movie has a invloving story that leaves you wanting more.

Review title: Boogie Nights or 'sex, greed, envy and cocaine set in the 1970's through to the 80's.
Review_body: Boogie nights tells the tale of a quiet young dishwasher from Torrance, his name is Eddie Adams and he is played very well by a young Mark Wahlberg.Unlike another PT Anderson movie 'Magnolia' Boogie nights does not open with a narration but instead goes straight to a shot of a club that Maurice played by Luis Guzman owns.We then meet Amber Waves, played by Julianne Moore and Jack Horner played by Burt Reynolds, of which id like to add how great that casting is. We also meet Reed Rothchild played by John C. Reilly and Buck Swope played by Don Cheadle.These characters are all brilliant, Julianne Moore becomes the mother hen as we learn that her child was taken away from her due to the porn business she is in and the main character Eddie Adams (who re-names himself Dirk Diggler as his porn name) slowly slips into drug problems and greed.My favourite scene in the whole film is when Dirk, Rothchild and Todd played by Thomas Jane, go to see Rahad Jackson played by Alfred Molina for drugs which then escalates into violence as when he gets his pump-action shotgun out.overall Boogie nights is a must see, an exuberant film and if you like Boogie Nights I also recommend the directors other films 'There will be blood and Magnolia.

Review title: a movie about a porn star, that isn't about a porn star.
Review_body: Starting against a black screen with fade in credits, Michael Penn scores broken circus music that whistles triumph and failure of the grandest scale. The warped tones and drowned out laughter provides a foreshadowing of the gradual downfall of a man we all see ourselves in. This score leads into the epic one-shot opening of Boogie Nights, set to Best of My Love, which shoots us into the glamorous world of the social circle we will eventually join.Paul Thomas Anderson makes his mark by direction in every front. Sporting Mark Wahlberg, Julianne Moore, John C. Reilly, Phillip Seymour Hoffman as an incredible ensemble as is, PTA directs these actors to preform their roles as simple-minded humans who are just trying to find self-assurance of their own worth in a complex world. All characters seem to have a heart of gold, but lead themselves into disaster by no fault but their own human mistakes. PTA refuses to let us find their job as machines in the porn industry as an excuse to pass them as lesser human, as he sets them in scenes with one another that establish their puppy-dog-like loyalty to one another in hope to feel and be loved, to feel a sense of belonging, to find a home which can celebrate them for their own achievements and be proud in one another alongside themselves.Beyond the raw emotive scenes of ones darkened past and fuzzy future, we are drawn in by all stylistic choices that make this epic feel incredibly intimate. PTA directs cinematographer Robert Elswit to capture the story a very distinct way. Seeing influences such as Marty Scorsese in his quick zooms, stylistic incoming vignettes, heavy steady cam and dolly shots between drawn out nearly theatrical drawn out scenes with complex blocking, challenge traditional film making standards of quality, in that it draws sever attention to the audience of the film being in fact, a film, and fictional. However, his direction to his cast and writing which previously mentioned, is impeccably human, seems to cancel this heavily orchestrated style to challenge the viewer to choose what is in fact real or unreal, to suspend disbelief and yet honor the film as a film in a rather superficial and frankly dumbed-down manner that puts us in the same position as the characters.In addition to all external direction PTA approached for this movie, we see heavily influence and reflection from PTA himself. Besides being set in the 70s in San Fernando Valley around the protagonist as a 17 year old, we have several other moments and key features that we see PTA projecting from himself. Early on we have a glimpse into the life of Eddie Edams (Wahlberg) in his dysfunctional relationship wit his mother through a heated, raw exchange that ends in his estrangement. In commentary of this film, PTA shares this is merely a glimpse into a real-life exchange between his mother and himself. He has admitted on other occasions to being estranged from his mother. As we as an audience question the reasoning to the anger, accusatory sense, and aggression the mother has for her son, PTA is there with us, questioning the motives of his own mother, of questions he himself could not answer.The real word that emerges to describe this movie is "momentum". From literal camera styles of quick pace pull ins, to a blossoming storyline that illuminates us with the wonders and woes of ambiguous characters who we don't think to question their origin but accept their presence in the most intimate nature, this movie has an unexpected "edge-of-your-seat" nature that keeps your heart in an emotional roller-coaster. In the end, we are left to feel a sense of home as we learn, with the characters, that it shall be wherever you strive to make it.

I just finished watching this movie a couple hours ago. I can honestly say this is one of the finest movies I've seen, especially in terms of character and storytelling. The story allows for each character to be fully realized by the audience, and they interact with each other spectacularly. Each and every scene is vital to the story and never is there a dull moment. This movie keeps going and going without breaks or lulls. It is an absolute treat watching these characters as they transition through the late seventies to early eighties in the porn industry. I recommend this highly to anyone who has an afternoon to watch the story of Eddie Adams unfold.

Review title: What a movie.....!!!!!!!!! a must watch.
Review_body: I was desperately waiting to watch this movie ever since I learnt wat this movie is all abt and for ur knowledge, this movie is abt pornography and pornographers(actors,technicians,etc.). Well, before watching this movie I thought this is a movie which portrays the backstage of the pornography which may show us anything abt drug trafficking and Human trafficking,but, I was proved completely wrong after watchin it. This is one of the best movies I hav seen in the recent past where the story of it revolves between the pornographers,it is set in late 1970's and early 1980's, like, wat were the conditions of this pornography at that time and how well would they fare and how these porn films hav slowly transformed into videotapes(less story with hardcore sex), more importantly the emotions of the pornographers(actors,technicians,etc.) and how hard is life for these pornographers out there in the contemporary world.The concoction of all these elements is 'Boogie Nights' and the director of this movie,Paul Thomas Anderson did complete justice to the script.And each and every actor of the movie (Mark Wahlberg,Julianne Moore,Burt Reynolds)gav their 100% to the movie, it's really a team effort. It's the director of the movie who should be credited for his work which will make our asses stuck to the seats from start to the end.Trust me frns u'll enjoy watchin it. In my concern I loved this movie esp. the pre-climax part, definitely worth for the academy awards though it settled wid 3 nominations, gr8 Hollywood movie,definitely it should be in IMDb's top 250.

One of the greatest portrayals of the American dream and its falsehoods. A shockingly accurate depiction of Suburban life and the inferiority felt by many adolescents. Watching this film brings more tears to my eyes than that movie "Beaches" because I really could feel for Eddie Adams. Many people attacked this movie without giving it a chance because they felt that it was a porn movie, but that couldn't be farther from the truth. This could have been a movie about training lemurs and still would have been great if PT Anderson had given it the same message. The  shot of Dirk's gift was a brilliant touch that many directors wouldn't have the gonads or the vision to add to the film.  I give it 10/10

This movie was essentially a family film - since this is what the folks in the movie were to each other. Burt Reynolds was the caring father figure and Julianne Moore, frustrated by missing her biological son, became the mother to both Mark Wahlberg and Heather Graham. When Mark Wahlberg is introduced to the family, everyone is open and friendly and he quickly becomes the favorite child. But when he becomes jaded by easy praise and another "new boy" appears, he acts like a spoiled child who has been introduced to a new sibling. What sets him off is his "mother" Julianne Moore kneeling next to the new guy and talking to him. Anyway, they all support one another and hang out at parties together during the holidays (instead of Christmas parties, it's New Year's Eve parties). At the end, Heather Graham is actively calling Julianne Moore "Mom" and is back in school getting her GED and Mark Wahlberg is back in the bosom of his "family" because they always forgive you there. A beautiful film, tribute to one of the many alternative families out there. Music, lovingly orchestrated by Michael Penn (seen in cameo) is appropriate, moving the scenes effortlessly onward.

Review title: One Of The Best Ever; Undeniably Entertaining
Review_body: It's not every day you see a new film as brilliant as Boogie Nights. PTA has crafted a film that shines in every area possible. The writing, directing, acting, camera, music, comedy, drama, suspense (I could go on forever), they are all completely amazing. This is a perfect film if there ever was one and I hope it is remembered forever as a true masterpiece.I've rewatched this dozens of times and its always held up. I still can't believe it wasn't nominated for best picture when it came out. What a missed opportunity, but I guess many of the great ones are overlooked. The subject matter and style and perfection was just too good.

Review title: Some of the best storytelling I've ever seen on film.
Review_body: This is a great film. It has a great story, a great cast, a great director, great dialog. Everything about this movie is great.In my opinion, this is Paul Thomas Anderson's best work. I'm a fan of his, although I have yet to see Hard Eight a.k.a. Sydney or The Master. There are three living directors today (or directing teams) who write their own screenplays that can really tell the best stories on film. Quentin Tarantino, Joel and Ethan Coen, and last, but most definitely not least, Paul Thomas Anderson. (I'd like to give Martin Scorsese honorable mention for Goodfellas and Mean Streets, though he doesn't write his own screenplays very often). Boogie Nights is one of my favorite films. I'd place it in my top 20, if not, top 15. And I've seen a lot of movies. So, watch Boogie Nights. Please. I doubt you'll be disappointed.

Review title: One of the best movies of its time
Review_body: Boogie Nights was most definitely one of the best movies the 90's had to offer. The plot line was very good, and the drama kept you hooked to the screen, all 152 mins (a rather long film). Though Boogie Nights was a long movie, the story line maintained to the main plot, and there was never a dull moment. Boogie Nights had a great cast, this film was when people started to notice Mark Wahlbergs talent. Julianne Moore was a great actress in this movie and did her role very well, but it was hard to accept Julianne Moore as a prostitute when she normally does more serious mature roles

This movie starts out with a feeling not unlike that of a pornographic film. It has a sort of anxious, low budget ambiance, exemplified through Paul Thomas Anderson's use of long camera shots. After Dirk leaves the porn industry in pursuit of a music career the film takes an amazing change in an almost Quentin Tarantinoish sort of way. People are being shot left and right, cocaine becomes a prominent crutch in the lives of the people involved in the film as they try to clean up and move on. Dirk's downfall almost reminds me of the film Citizen Kane where Kane's lust for power inevitably leads to his demise. I must say that this film left me amazed, and I believe it belongs on the top 250 of this website.

Ahh the 1970's a time of jaded innocence. This is the era in which the movie 'Boogie Nights'is set in. A time when cocaine wasn't thought of as addictive, sex would not kill you, and god forbid disco was king. A story of a rise and fall and rise in the span of six year's (77 to 83) of a none to bright SoCal youth brought to prominence, discovered by chance and championed by a wily mentor played by Burt Reynold's in an Oscar nominated role. (lost out to Robin William's for Good Will Hunting) not to mention a prodigious member and an insurable sexual prolactivity makes this the best movie of the nineties. Told in an over the shoulder you are there film style and buoy'd by numerous top forty chart topper's of the 70's and 80's director and writer Paul Thomas Anderson second feature is a tour de force of nihilistic hedonism at it's wretched best. Brutal and thoughtful this is a film that through it's very arch the character's become the epitome of which they disdain be it the Reynold's characters resolution of resorting to the disavowed use of voyeur intrused videotape to the SoCal youth's (Mark Wahlberg) degradation of homo erotic act's for ten dollar's a pop the character's arc are on the same line yet still point's on the curve. This film is an echo of John Holme's rise and degradation in the same industry yet fictionalized and paralleled in spades.

Review title: One of the worst films I've ever seen.
Review_body: I rented this movie with high expectations. I heard all the stellar reviews from the critics. I was anticipating a great film. About an hour and half into it, I was looking at the time counter on the DVD player wondering when this film was going to end. It takes a non-talent like PT Anderson to make a film about the 70's porno industry so boring. Anderson rips off Scorsese at every turn, and when the script seems to hit a quagmire, he throws in gratuitous violence. Oh, by the way: cocaine is not a powder, it's a rock. All a coke head has to do is open the bag and smell it. Baby powder will fool no dope fiend. Finally, this film is loosely based on scumbag John Holmes, who pimped out his 15-year-old girlfriend for coke, and beat her when she arrived with the cash. Glorifiying a low-life like John Holmes is a crime in itself. I hated this film. I'm mesmerized by the positive reviews of this film received.

Review title: Downfall of the sex cinema civilization
Review_body: After having it watched for the fifth or sixth time since I had first seen it when in came out cinema back in 1997, it struck me that this film only gets better with age.The second half of the 1990s saw few, more or less successful, cinematic re-examinations of the late 1970s. Spike Lee's "Summer of Sam" is a worthy example."Boogie Nights" is a historical account of certain eminent trends, social structures and patterns that existed at the time. Set between 1977 and 1983, the film portrays the pornographic film industry in California at its peak, and its imminent downfall, invoked by the introduction of the video tape - something that reduced the creative ambition of the porn filmmakers to a simple push-button recording and introduced competition from anonymous amateurs to the business.It appears that the people involved in the industry (actors, producers, directors, technicians) all lived in a sort of a ghetto (flashy and glossy nonetheless); had they ever dared to part from it, they would have had inevitably gotten burned - either by the stigma that had been cast on them, or in the face of the fact that their abilities in the real world were never held at a high price, which is what lured them into the industry in the first place. It is obvious, then, that inside this little world, these people have found a haven where they could appear important, a universe which was built upon and sustained through all sorts of hedonistic temptations and dubious financial sources. It was a cocaine-fed lie, and they knew it."Boogie Nights" describes the paradigm shift of the sex cinema industry in a similar manner in which "Gone with the Wind" approached the abolition of slavery as an eclipse of the civilization of the South. One of the film's features is that it loosely depicts real-life characters and situations, like the film's Dirk Diggler (Wahlberg's character) posing for John Holmes in real life. This is what makes characters of the film all the more believable; they are ignorant, shallow, terrified and self-indulgent. The soundtrack of the film is impressively appropriate.Certain scenes definitely make cinema history, like the one in Alfred Molina's character's apartment, where an unexplained Chinese character, probably in an opium-induced frenzy, explodes fire-crackers every half a minute or so. The story-telling in scenes such as this one hits the mark in expressing the state of the characters' minds. The film is simply brilliant.

Review title: One Of the Greatest Films Ever Made
Review_body: Truly a masterwork. Alive, intense, funny, heartfelt, loud (in a good way), quiet (in a great way). Performances are standouts across the board. Cinematography is some of the best I've seen. Music is pervasive and well thought out- one of the best soundtracks ever. Rivals Pulp Fiction as both one of the best films of the 90s as well as one of the movies that changed filmmaking forever and has influenced a new generation of filmmakers (myself included). Hats off, PTA. You are what we strive for. Pay close attention to the second half of the film, for it is profoundly made. Some of these scenes (including The New Year, Dirk in the truck/Taxicab confession, Sister Christian, Buck in the donut shop, and God Only Knows, as well as the ending), will stand the test of time as some of the most well made scenes in history. In all, as close to perfect as a film can get. No matter if you are a cinephile, or just a casual fan of one of the stars, be assured this is not only a roller coaster rides of extreme emotional peaks and valleys, it is one of the most moving and entertaining things ever committed to celluloid. Seek this one out. Watch it twice, three times, ten times. There is always something new and amazing about the masterpiece that is Paul Thomas Anderson's BOOGIE NIGHTS.

Being a child of the 70's i could really appreciate this film about excesses in the entertainment industry and all of it's bonuses that came with that.So if you ever felt like going back to the 70's or experience what it was like in the 70's this is a film that will do it for ya.Mark Wahlberg was amazing,his portrayal of a 70's porn star was right on baby,i have always found it difficult for directors to capture the true essence of what life was like back in the 70's without the characters becoming cartoon like and unbelievable to the audience,but the director managed to make them all believable,being someone who grew up in the 70's i can't believe we lived,dressed and acted that way,the story-line was simple but so was the 70's,the conflicts were the way i remembered them, between parents and their teenagers etc...so if you want to experience the 70's all over again or would like to see what the big deal was about that your parents lived through,buy this movie,eat your popcorn and just have a groovy night all over again.
The whole movie is boring,and the leader female actress doesn't open her mouth when she talks.

I saw Boogie Nights for the first time on HBO a few nights ago and it's left me deeply thoughtful and overwhelmingly, unexpectedly, entertained. The cast is perfect, they "nailed" their roles. The cinematography is seamless, fresh, and immensely creative. Very well written script conveying the characters' complex personalities and emotions. The soundtrack invokes moods I didn't even know I had. All elements of this film are superb and I plan on purchasing the DVD. Boogie Nights is a very pleasurable and stimulating experience and I would recommend it to anybody.-Nicole Tuscaloosa, Alabama

Of all the characters that were tied up neatly at the end, Becky Barnett was left without an fair ending. I would have preferred to see a short scene somewhere in the last 10 minutes where we see Becky's new life -- rather than a mid-film exit after such an important role in the early scenes. She was clearly a part of the "family". A big improvement to an already amazing movie would have been to show us her "new life" -- whatever that turned out to be.I wish it would have shown her in a church, personally, having someone ask her a question about her former life in LA -- then seeing her respond with a lie such as "I was a teacher". The implication would have been that she is going to live the rest of her life trying to hide and repent from her years in porn. It would have been yet another tragic ending as Becky lives in self-exile and constant fear that her shameful secret will somehow be revealed...

Review title: Everyone' s blessed with one special thing...
Review_body: ~The first film that ever forced me to look at cinematography... ~

Review title: A tongue in cheek look at the heroes of porn
Review_body: Last night I watched "Boogie Nights" maybe as a sort of a tribute to Burn Reynolds, none of whose movies I've seen up till now. I"ll be talking to a limited number of people who haven't seen it yet, but here goes!If you're expecting lots of cheesy 70s fashion and disco music the movie delivers a tiny bit of this, but it is primarily a drama, not a period piece. The movie's focus is the rise and fall (pardon the pun!) of its main character, Dirk Diggler, who is based on the real life American porn star John Holmes. The movie begins with the young Dirk being spotted as a seventeen year old in a club by porn director Jack Horner (Burt Reynolds). Not particularly intelligent, he determines that he can use his one particular talent (being good in bed) to make something of himself. After having a vicious argument with an emotionally abusive mother he accepts Jack's offer to pursue a career as a porn actor and moves in with him. As the protege of Jack and Maggie (Jack's porn star partner) he makes friends and becomes successful. The movie shows Diggler winning awards and beginning a series of movies that combine porn with light entertainment, however it all begins to go wrong when he is introduced to drugs by coke addict Maggie. In the following months his mood swings, egocentric outbursts and inability to perform result in him being fired. In order to get by he resorts to prostitution, a failed attempt at a singing career and finally a drug deal that goes spectacularly and cataclysmically wrong in what is perhaps the film's most memorable scene.There are notable character performances in Boogie Nights from Don Cheadle, Heather Graham and Phillip Seymour-Hoffman but it's Mark Wahlberg who really commands attention in every frame. He portrays Diggler with only slight comedic overtones as an earnest character who really wants to believe in the artistic integrity of what he does. This is played opposite Burn Reynolds' Jack who acts as a father figure in this world in which sex is mundane and openly performed without embarrassment or moral significance attached. This is the source of the movie's comedy, but I suspect for the average viewer it also makes the characters hard to relate to. In short, it's a movie packed full of gutsy performances and memorable scenes. However personally it failed to resonate with me immediately and might require one or two repeat watches. The strange nature of the characters makes it difficult to understand the world that Diggler is moving through, and this is the flaw that detracts from an otherwise excellent movie.

Review title: One of the best films of the 90s
Review_body: Boogie Nights is possibly one of the most completely watchable films i've seen, it has everything going for it, a great ensemble cast, a cool soundtrack, fantastic dialogue and amazing camera-work. I used to seriously doubt Mark Wahlberg's ability as an actor, but after seeing this film i saw that a good script and good direction can really bring out the best in him. To be honest there's not a bad performance from any of the actors in his movie,. Those i found most noteworthy besides Wahlberg were John.C.Reilly and Don Cheadle who really excelled in their roles. Also the cameo from Alfred Molina as the Russian roullette playing drug dealer is simply class. This movie depicts the pitfalls of showbusiness in the 70's and 80's wonderfully and although its quite long it never lags and in my opinion is an instant classic.
